*The Rainbow Spanning Heaven*
Compiled by the JiuLin DouShan Scholar [Qing Dynasty]

*The Rainbow Spanning Heaven*, compiled by the JiuLin DouShan scholar of the Qing Dynasty, contains numerous accounts concerning the karmic retribution of gods and demons. Only volumes three through five survive, now held in the Institute of Chinese Opera Studies at the Chinese National Academy of the Arts. The identity of the JiuLin DouShan scholar remains unattested in academic circles.

(...previous text missing...) she stepped out of the room and turned past the courtyard, only to see Madam Qu and Old Lady Pu standing there in a daze. You-sheng, catching sight of them, was startled and hurried back to his study to sleep.

Madam Qu and Old Lady Pu took Chao-yun back to the chamber and asked, “What did the young master say?” Chao-yun dared not conceal anything and recounted the whole affair from the beginning. Old Lady Pu was so enraged that she beat her chest and stamped her feet, wailing, “Such a trifling matter—yet it has ruined my daughter!” She wept without cease, tears and snot streaming down.

Madam Qu said, “I told you earlier to cry out when the time came. Why did you not make a sound?” Chao-yun replied, “I wanted to, but the young master stuffed his sweet, honeyed tongue into my mouth, so I couldn’t call out at all.”

Just then, Xiao-chuan walked over and asked, “What is this about?” Madam Qu repeated Chao-yun’s words to him. Xiao-chuan said, “If that’s the case, she’s clearly no fool of a woman. Tomorrow, I’ll speak with him.”

Madam Qu said, “This was our fault—what does it have to do with him? But on the sixth, he must perform the wedding rites. If he refuses, we’ll have to discipline him properly to vent our anger.” After grumbling resentfully for a while, they all retired to bed. (The rest is omitted.)

Meanwhile, You-sheng, on account of Chao-yun, stayed for several days in a row. Each evening, he would wait until the second or third watch before retiring to sleep.

He thought to himself, *"If Chao-yun’s parents find out about our affair, they will surely show their displeasure. If they don’t know, why has she stopped coming? There is great cause for suspicion. Tomorrow, I must ask her in private to set my mind at ease."*

The next afternoon, he saw Chao-yun alone by the side gate. Glancing around to ensure no one was near, he approached and asked, *"Chao-yun, why didn’t you bring tea this evening?"*

Chao-yun replied, *"Mother found out. Even my dowry isn’t safe."*

Upon hearing these words, You-sheng needed no further thought to understand her meaning. He smiled and said, *"If fate is so unkind, what cruel destiny is this!"*

That night, he went straight to bed, pondering, *"I must not hesitate. I should leave tomorrow. If I delay further, I’ll be trapped in their scheme. Of all plans, fleeing is the best."*

At the fifth watch, he dressed, slipped out of his room, and hurried through the back gate, escaping without a trace.

Upon returning home, his parents had not yet risen. He went to his room, gathered his bedding and silver, and instructed Qin-si to carry them. Without even bidding his parents farewell, he hired a small boat and set off for Wangzhou. (The rest is omitted.)

Meanwhile, Xiao-chuan rose early in the morning and sent Pu Yi to summon the cooks and arrange for opera performances, making the household bustle with preparations.

After a flurry of activity, Pu Yi’s wife rushed in, flustered, and announced, *"We’ve been robbed last night!"* The back gate was wide open, but nothing in the house was missing. After searching everywhere, they realized only one thing was gone—the son-in-law.

They quickly reported this to Xiao-chuan. Knowing You-sheng had fled home, Xiao-chuan sent Pu Yi to fetch him.

Pu Yi arrived at the Lu residence and said to Tian-cheng, *"My master sends his regards and requests the young master’s presence today to perform the wedding rites."*

Tian-cheng replied, *"Since he came to your house that day, he has not returned."*

Just then, the gatekeeper entered and told Tian-cheng, *"The young master knocked at the door before dawn, had Qin-si carry his luggage, and left—I don’t know where."*

Tian-cheng relayed this to Pu Yi, who took his leave and returned to report to Xiao-chuan.

The household was left utterly disheartened, their anger so fierce it nearly cost them their lives—needless to say more.

Meanwhile, You-sheng had traveled all the way to Hangzhou. Delighted by the sights of West Lake, he lingered for several days, reluctant to leave. Yet fearing his parents might send someone to pursue him, he knew he must flee farther. Crossing the river, he traversed mountains and ridges, enduring hardships on the road. After half a month’s journey, he reached Jiangxi and took lodging at an inn. Thinking himself far enough from home, he decided to settle and find a place to stay, where he could devote himself to his studies.

Just then, another traveler entered the inn, seeking a room. As the hour was late and no vacant chambers remained, he was shown to share You-sheng’s room. The two clasped hands in greeting.

You-sheng asked, “May I inquire your honorable name and hometown?”

The man replied, “This humble one is Yan Zhen, a native of Wu-men.”

You-sheng likewise introduced himself, revealing they were fellow townsmen.

“What brings you here, sir?” You-sheng asked.

Yan Zhen said, “My elder brother, Yan Yue, is currently the prefect of Ji’an. His yamen lacks staff, so he sent me home to recruit a private secretary. And what brings you here?”

You-sheng replied, “A friend of mine serves as magistrate in Ji-shui. He invited me to join his staff, but en route, I received word that he had returned home for mourning. Thus, I’ve been delayed here.”

Yan Zhen asked, “Would you consider joining my brother’s yamen?”

You-sheng demurred, “I fear my meager talents would be unworthy of your brother’s guidance.”

Yan Zhen, however, found his speech refined and his demeanor uncommon—clearly a learned man. Hoping to spare himself the trouble of returning home, he invited You-sheng to accompany him. He called for the innkeeper to prepare wine and a dish, and the two drank together. Their conversation flowed so smoothly that they soon became fast friends.

The next day, Yan Zhen settled You-sheng’s bill, and the two hired sedan chairs and horses to set off for Ji’an.

After You-sheng’s departure, Chao-yun pined for him day and night, falling ill for a year. Her once rosy complexion and jadelike beauty withered into a skeletal semblance. Medicines and prayers brought no relief. As death approached, she told her mother, “I fear I won’t recover. There’s a handkerchief with a poem in my trunk—please be sure to bury it with me.”

Pu Yi and his wife hurriedly searched the trunk and found the handkerchief, which they handed to their daughter. Chao-yun gazed at it, her sorrow redoubling. In an instant, her eyes closed forever—her fate no different from Qiao-qiao’s.

It so happened that their spirits, unwilling to let You-sheng go, lingered on. In the underworld, they met by chance, and both proved to be his creditors of karmic debt. Kneeling before King Yama, they tearfully recounted You-sheng’s faithlessness and inconstancy, longing to return to the living and reunite with him.

The King consulted the Register of Marriages and saw that Lu Shi-shan’s predestined bonds with Qiao-qiao and Chao-yun Feng had already been fulfilled—no reunion was possible. Furthermore, he discovered that Lu Shi-shan was originally fated for early success in the imperial examinations, but for abandoning his wife without cause, the Heavenly Court had revoked his prospects. Hearing this, the two women collapsed in grief.

King Yama said, “Though your allotted lifespans are not yet exhausted, you have already departed your bodies and cannot return to life. I shall permit you to wander as unrestrained spirits in the mortal realm until your natural lifespans end, at which time you will be summoned for judgment.”

Thus, their forms dissolved into the wind, and they left the underworld, making their way to Ji’an Prefecture.

*Enemies bound in past lives,
In this life, enemies still they become.*

This aside, let us return to Pu Xiao-chuan. Having raised this daughter, he had endured endless frustration. His son-in-law had fled without a trace, and keeping his daughter at home offered no resolution. Yet if he arranged another marriage and the son-in-law returned, complications would arise. As he and Qu-shi wrestled with their dilemma, word came that Chao-yun had died.

Xiao-chuan said, “We should hold a funeral for Chao-yun as if she were our daughter, keeping it secret from the Lu family.”

Qu-shi asked, “And what of Da-qiao?”

Xiao-chuan replied, “I have a relative named Kong Fang who borrowed three thousand strings of cash from me to open an inn in Ji’an Prefecture. We can send Da-qiao to live with him. Once the situation cools, we can arrange another match—wouldn’t that be tidy?”

Qu-shi sighed, “But she’s been by my side since childhood. How can I bear to part with her?”

Xiao-chuan said, “Circumstances leave us no choice.” He informed Pu Yi and his wife, who saw no better option. They then reported to the Lu family that their eldest daughter had died, and the funeral rites were carried out. Lu Tian-cheng and his wife came to mourn, believing it to be true.

Poor Chao-yun—whether alive or dead, she was made to take the blame. After the forty-nine days of mourning had passed, Xiao-chuan dispatched his steward, Pu Zhong, and his wife to prepare travel funds and luggage. They accompanied Da-qiao to Kong’s household.

Pu Zhong first entered to deliver the letter. Upon reading it, Kong Fang invited his niece inside, where they exchanged formal greetings. He then prepared a chamber for her to reside in. Kong Fang immediately instructed a matchmaker to seek a marriage prospect for her. Yet this "unsellable stock" found no takers anywhere—after more than forty or fifty proposals, not a single one succeeded. Several more years passed with no suitor in sight, and the matchmaker’s enthusiasm waned, just as Da-qiao’s own desire to marry gradually faded. Truly:

*When fate denies a heavenly match,*
*The red phoenix star shines on another’s house.*

Meanwhile, Lu You-sheng had served as a private secretary in Prefect Yan Yue’s yamen for five years, amassing a comfortable sum. He changed his name to Yan Yu and accompanied the prefect to his new post, where he sat for the imperial examination. One day, news arrived that the emperor had summoned Prefect Yan to the capital. Yan wished to bring You-sheng with him, but You-sheng thought, *"I have not returned to take the examinations for many years, and my scholar’s status has long lain fallow. If I go now, won’t I lose both opportunities? Better to wait two more years—if I pass the provincial examination, I can marry a beautiful wife. Then, returning in glory, I will achieve both goals at once. Would that not be ideal?"* He wrote a letter and entrusted it to Prefect Yan to deliver home. Renting a private residence, he settled in to focus on his studies.

It so happened that the seventh day of the seventh month arrived, when households everywhere prayed for skill by threading needles. You-sheng mused, *"Today is Qiao-qiao’s birthday. Were I at home, I would surely raise a toast to celebrate with her. But now, separated by distance, we cannot meet even in haste."* Tears welled in his eyes.

He then composed a poem on the spot:

*"Two hearts apart, each sheds its stream of tears,
Vainly the Herd-boy calls from heaven’s frontier.
The Weaving Maid’s millennial grief won’t fade,
Nor can the fairy’s Qixi sorrow be allayed.
The embroidered bower’s rain-cloud passion burns bright,
The gauze window’s wind-moon longing drifts like night.
Far as Wu Mountain, the Silver River flows—
Heartbroken, autumn’s sorrow Song Yu knows."*

As he finished reciting, the door creaked open. Who might be coming? The next passage will reveal all.

---

**Chapter Three, Third Tale: The Handsome Scholar’s Ghostly Matchmaker**

Now, You-sheng looked up as the door opened and saw a woman of about thirty. He quickly rose, stepped forward, and bowed, asking, *"Madam, to which household do you belong? What brings you here?"*

The woman replied, *"This old one is surnamed Wei. I’ve come, perhaps presumptuously, to propose a match for you, sir."*

You-sheng said, *"I am deeply grateful for your kindness. However, I have resolved to marry only a woman of both talent and beauty."*

Wei replied, *"I’ve arranged countless matches and never once misled a family’s child. This young lady is of age and as lovely as a flower. If you marry her, how will you repay me?"*

You-sheng said, *"If she is as you say, I will certainly reward you handsomely."*

Wei smiled, rose, and took her leave. You-sheng asked where she lived, and she answered, *"Under the third archway east of the main street."*

After parting, Wei went straight to the Kong household to act as matchmaker for Daqiao. Kong’s wife said, *"I’ve turned down dozens of proposals for my daughter, as none suited me. But if Wei speaks of this one, it must be a fine match."*

Wei said, *"This Master Yan is exceptionally talented—a learned scholar of our time."*

Kong, knowing he was the prefect’s guest and thus a man of influence, immediately agreed.

The next day, You-sheng visited Wei and said, *"Regarding yesterday’s discussion, I must see the young lady in person to set my mind at ease."*

Wei replied, *"That can be arranged."* She then accompanied You-sheng to a grand household, where she asked him to wait while she went inside. After the time it takes to drink a cup of tea, two maids emerged, supporting a young woman who glided forward with graceful steps. She approached the hall, bowed to You-sheng, stood briefly, then turned and followed Wei back inside.

You-sheng, his spirits lifted and heart delighted, watched her until she passed through the inner gate before turning his gaze away. Unnoticed, she had dropped a handkerchief, which You-sheng picked up. Fearing someone might see, he hastily tucked it into his sleeve without examining it closely.

Wei emerged, and they set off. Along the way, she asked, *"Does the young lady meet your approval?"*

You-sheng replied joyfully, *"She is truly a woman of the highest refinement. But how much is the betrothal gift?"*

Wei said, *"She doesn’t care about the gift—only that you marry into her family."*

You-sheng said, *"That can be done."* They parted, and he chose an auspicious day to send the betrothal gifts and complete the marriage.

On the wedding day, You-sheng dressed in his finest, and the procession arrived. He boarded the sedan chair and was carried to the Kong household. After the nuptial rites, Wei took her leave.

You-sheng entered the bridal chamber and saw his new wife. Startled, he thought, *"Why does she not resemble the woman I saw before? There must be some mistake."* He pulled her close, scrutinizing her carefully, and suddenly erupted in fury, shouting, *"Where did this monstrosity come from!"*

*"The woman I met the other day was a lovely girl of seventeen or eighteen—you’ve switched her out to deceive me! I’ll take this to court!"*

Hearing the commotion in the bridal chamber, Kong Fang hurried over to inquire. After listening to You-sheng’s account, he said, *"When did anyone come to see my daughter? Where did such a story come from?"*

You-sheng replied, *"That matchmaker, Madam Wei, brought me here. Two maidservants escorted out a woman as beautiful as a flower or jade—how could this be her?"*

Kong scoffed, *"You must have seen a ghost! There was no flower-like beauty for you to meet."*

*"Absurd!"* You-sheng cried. *"On the day we met, the woman even left behind a handkerchief—I kept it here. Look!"* He rushed to his trunk, retrieved the handkerchief, and handed it to Kong. Kong took it and saw fine, fly-head script upon it. When You-sheng took it back to read, he exclaimed in shock, *"How strange! This is the handkerchief I gave to Zhaoyun—why was it with that woman? We only need to ask the matchmaker to get to the truth."* He urged Kong to go with him.

Kong, struck by his strange words, also wished to find the matchmaker and question her. The two men, dazed with frustration, stepped out the gate. When they reached the foot of the third memorial archway, they saw only an expanse of empty ground—where had the house gone? The matchmaker, too, had vanished. They stood dumbfounded, staring at the vacant lot. *"How strange! How strange!"* they muttered. Asking the neighbors, each one said there had never been a matchmaker named Wei; this empty ground had served as an execution ground for autopsies ten years prior, so no one had built a house there. The father and son-in-law gazed at each other in bewilderment, unable to make sense of it, and returned home dejectedly. They told the household what had happened, and all marveled at the strangeness of it.

You-sheng sat in his room, turning the handkerchief over and over, pondering for a long while, but could grasp nothing. He had no choice but to set it aside and put it out of mind. Yet now that he had married this woman, his situation was neither settled nor resolved—he would have to flee again to escape this ordeal. He did not sleep all night, and as soon as the fifth watch arrived, he opened the door and slipped away. Unfortunately, the innkeeper spotted him and reported it to Kong. Kong immediately sent three or four young servants to pursue him. They caught up with him halfway, dragged him back, and brought him before Kong and his wife.

The couple was furious. *"With things as they are,"* they said to You-sheng, *"why did you leave without a word? Are you going to abandon our daughter and leave her to a lifetime of regret? That is no way for a gentleman to act!"* You-sheng hung his head in silence.

Kong knew that Da-qiao’s first husband had already fled, and now seeing this one attempt to leave as well, he feared he would depart and never return—another unresolved matter. Without further argument, he pushed You-sheng into the chamber and locked the door. Every window, pillar, and wall was secured tightly, and meals were passed in through a rotating tray. Such arrangements made it impossible to escape, even with wings. You-sheng sat in the room like a caged ape or a captive crane, with no means of flight. With no other choice, he endured in silence, passing the days in reluctant submission.

Kong thought to himself, *"My son-in-law is no criminal—how can I keep him imprisoned here? Better to let Da-qiao enter his room at dusk and leave at dawn. That way, he won’t have to see her unsightly face, and they may yet share a bed. Perhaps the young man will change his mind."* Yet You-sheng’s resolve was even firmer than that of the steadfast man Liu Xia-hui. No matter how she lay beside him, he remained unmoved, not making the slightest sound. After a few days, even Da-qiao refused to enter. This was the true measure of You-sheng’s devotion to talent and restraint from desire, which made him so unyielding.

Unexpectedly, Kong Fang’s fortunes took a turn for the worse. One night at the third watch, a clamor arose outside the door—robbers, their heads wrapped and faces covered, smashed through the tiles and forced their way in with torches and cudgels. Startled, You-sheng had nowhere to hide. Finding nothing of value after a thorough search, the bandits bound him and scorched his body with burning straw, demanding he reveal where his treasures were hidden. Unable to endure the torment, You-sheng at last said, "The treasure is in the upper floor at the rear." The robbers dragged him along as their guide. Having only just arrived at the Kong residence, You-sheng was unfamiliar with the layout, yet the bandits drove him forward with blows, stick after stick, until they reached the rear tower. There, they ransacked chests and overturned trunks, gorging themselves before departing. Fearing pursuit, they hauled You-sheng two or three *li* away before releasing him. He fled for his life, stumbling and staggering, collapsing in a daze only to scramble up and run again. Then, one of his shoes slipped off. As he groped about in the dark, he failed to find it but instead felt a heavy bundle, likely left behind by the robbers. He tucked it into his sash and hesitated: *"If I return, they will surely lock me in that room again. If I do not, I have no lower garments—what will I do when dawn comes?"* Just as he despaired, the moon began to sink, and the cock crowed at daybreak. Soon, the sky lightened. With no other choice, You-sheng crouched down and sat upon the ground. The locals, seeing this strange sight, gathered around in a circle, demanding his story. Growing weary of their questions, he suddenly spotted a young servant pushing through the crowd. The boy cried out, "Master, put these on!" You-sheng looked up—it was none other than the lute attendant. Hearing that his master had been seized, the boy had guessed he would be released partway, half-dressed. After the robbers left, he had taken a few garments and set out before dawn to search. By chance, he had come upon You-sheng in this very place. Dressed at last, You-sheng conferred with the boy: "Let us not return. We shall find another place to stay." The attendant replied, "But all our belongings are there—how can we abandon them?" You-sheng said, "What are belongings worth? If we go back, they will lock me in that room again. When will I ever see freedom? The imperial examinations are near. Let us go to the provincial capital, find lodging, and study for a time. After the exams, we can decide what to do next." The boy objected, "We have no traveling money—how can you take the exams?" You-sheng told him of the silver he had stumbled upon. Delighted, the attendant followed his master, and along the way, they purchased bedding. By the time they reached the provincial capital, the preliminary exams had already passed, but You-sheng was selected as a *yicai*—a candidate who had missed the main examination—and granted a place. He awaited only the three sessions of the provincial exam. After a few days, the first session arrived. You-sheng prepared himself and entered the examination hall. The sky was still dim, and the examination papers had not yet been distributed. He lowered his head and feigned sleep for a moment. Suddenly, a group of clerks shouted, "The names are being called in the hall—go, go at once!" Without explanation, they seized him and dragged him forward. Above, the names were read one by one. When the eighteenth name, Lu Shishan, was called, You-sheng stepped forward to answer. There, seated in the place of honor, an official declared, "You abandoned your wife without cause. The Celestial Court is displeased and has revoked your future prospects." Before You-sheng could explain, the clerks hustled him out.

You-sheng seized the clerk and demanded, "Why call my name only to reject me?" The clerk replied, "That venerable official oversees which candidates pass or fail." Before You-sheng could press further, the afternoon had already slipped away. He submitted a blank examination paper. By dawn, the list of successful candidates was posted—his name absent once more.

"You-sheng sighed, "This year’s failure stems from that dream’s misfortune. I shall wait another three years; if I still fail next time, I will reconsider." Time passed swiftly, and soon it was autumn examination season again. Heaven’s justice was manifest—once more, he fell beyond the tail of Sun Shan. Turning to Qin Si, he said, "Two failures leave me no face to remain here. I shall cast aside this *xiucai* status, pack my belongings, and return home." That very day, he settled his rent and set out on his journey.

Along the way, he mused, "That dream in the examination hall was indeed strange. This time, upon returning, I shall first reconcile with the Kong family, then bring my wife back with me, and later fetch Lady Pu to return her intact to her family." Just so:

The bitter sea knows no bounds—
Turn your head, and the shore is near.

This very thought of his had already startled the Day-Officer of Merit, who reported it to the Celestial Emperor. Thus, his prospects for official rank held seven or eight parts of promise. But this is a matter for later.

Meanwhile, after the bandits had departed, Kong Fang and his wife crawled out from beneath the bed. Taking stock of their household silver and valuables, they found a full three to five thousand taels missing, and their son-in-law gone as well. In one stroke, they had lost both person and property, and their bitterness knew no bounds. They could not but report the theft to the authorities in hopes of apprehending the culprits. Yet as the saying goes:

Robbed, then hounded by officials—
Sorrow upon sorrow.

They fell into a deep melancholy, which soon turned to illness. Fever and chills racked Kong Fang, and within days, he passed away with a final offering. His wife followed soon after. Da Qiao mourned them more grievously than if they had been her own parents. After observing three years of filial mourning, she performed all rites for their burial.

A once-prosperous household, now bereft of its two central pillars, tottered and collapsed. Though Da Qiao was of age, she had never married, and as a young woman, she could hardly keep the household in order. She could only leave matters to drift. One day, she thought, "I am already of such an age, yet master of none. Twice betrothed, and both husbands turned to empty promises. I no longer hope for any good fortune. I shall pack my things and return to see my parents one last time, then shave off these locks and take up the monastic life." She called upon the Pu couple to discuss the matter. They assented, and Da Qiao made ready. Hiring a carriage, the three set out on their journey homeward. But of this, no more.

Meanwhile, Lu Yousheng made his way toward Ji’an Prefecture. Upon arriving at the Kong residence, he found the courtyard desolate, nothing like its former bustle, and grew deeply perplexed. Hurrying to ask an old man across the way, he said, “How fares the Kong family of late?” The old man replied, “After the bandit raid, the couple both perished, and the house was sold to another.” Yousheng asked, “What of their daughter? Where does she live now?” The old man said, “She moved away three days ago.” Yousheng pressed, “Where did she go?” The old man answered, “No one knows for certain.”

Hearing that the Kong family had been utterly ruined and his wife’s whereabouts were unknown, Yousheng felt a profound sorrow. With Qin Si at his side and nowhere to turn, he could only plan his return journey and press onward. By the time they reached Yushan, the hardships of the road—wind and frost—had taken their toll, and he fell gravely ill. They took lodging at an inn to rest, calling a physician to treat him. Yet his condition worsened day by day, his illness nearly fatal, and his purse empty as a gourd. Qin Si, frantic, approached the innkeeper to negotiate, offering to sell herself to cover the costs of her master’s funeral. The innkeeper said, “If you leave, who will attend to the gentleman?” Qin Si replied, “Let us first draw up the contract. Once my master’s fate is known, I will go without delay.” The innkeeper said, “That will do. Go speak with your master, and I will find a buyer for you.”

Qin Si then told Yousheng of the arrangement. With tears in his eyes, Yousheng said, “Matters have come to this; there is no other way. But I have burdened you with my troubles, and your kindness is too much to bear.” So saying, he wept again.

Qin Si said, “Master, do not grieve too deeply. This is but a temporary measure. If you should recover your silver, you may always redeem me.” As the two spoke, the innkeeper approached the window and called, “Brother Lu, come, I have news for you.” Qin Si stepped outside. The innkeeper said, “I have found a buyer, though they will offer only four taels of silver.” Qin Si replied, “Our need is urgent; we must accept.” The innkeeper went to finalize the agreement, and the sale was set for the following day.

The next day, Qin Si accompanied the innkeeper to the buyer’s home, where the contract was signed and the silver exchanged. Returning to the inn, she arranged for the physician and medicine. Truly:
Medicine cures not the doomed,
Buddhas save only the destined.

After three or five days, Yousheng’s condition began to improve. By the time the full moon arrived, his strength had returned. He said, “My illness has passed. You should go to your new master’s home now.” Qin Si bid him farewell and departed.

Now, Qin Si’s new master was named Chen Yan. His father, Chen Guozhu, served as Educational Commissioner of Shaanxi. As the journey was long, he had not brought his family with him. His mother, née Qian, oversaw her son’s studies. The boy was already fourteen. Upon arriving at the Chen household, Qin Si kowtowed and paid her respects to her mistress and young master, then met the kitchen staff and the master’s brothers. She was smooth and agreeable in her conduct, winning everyone’s favor. Even Master Chen, knowing she had sold herself to save her former master—a loyal servant—treated her with respect and never lorded his authority over her.

One day, a letter arrived from Commissioner Chen. The letter first urged the hiring of a tutor for his son, with great earnestness. Qin Si, having read it, said to the young master, “The master’s letter speaks of hiring a tutor. Why not invite my former master? He would be an excellent choice.” The young master replied, “How can you be certain of his scholarship? You speak too lightly!” Qin Si said, “Though I know little of his learning, I do know that when he was at home, he entered the academy at twelve and became a government student at sixteen. Later, he served as a private secretary in Ji’an Prefecture. Before he could return home for the examinations, he was promoted to government student while in office. From this, I gather he must know how to compose essays.”

The young master smiled and said, “If that is so, I shall write an invitation for you to bring him here to share some wine.” He then penned a note reading “awaiting your instruction this very day” and had Qin Si deliver it.

Qin Si arrived at the inn and, presenting the note to his former master, explained the circumstances. Overjoyed, the scholar tidied his robes and cap, wrote a return card, and went to pay his respects. As soon as he entered the door, Master Chen rushed out to greet him in stockinged feet, showing the utmost courtesy. Once seated as host and guest, they exchanged pleasantries. After tea, they discussed ancient prose and contemporary examination essays, conversing at length with unflagging enthusiasm, every word sharp and incisive. Master Chen listened and said, “Your enlightened discourse has given me much to ponder—my mind, once blocked, now feels suddenly opened.” The scholar replied, “You flatter me.”

That evening, a feast was laid out, and the two raised their cups in toast, drinking until the night grew late before parting. The young master then invited the scholar to stay the night in the study. The next day, he informed his mother of his wish to engage the scholar as a tutor, and she gave her consent. The young master prepared gifts of introduction and, inviting the scholar to take the seat of honor, bowed four times and □□ the contract of employment. Meanwhile, Da Qiao had set out on his journey home. Finding overland travel arduous, he hired a passenger boat and sailed down the Yangtze. Unexpectedly, at the second watch of the night, a band of river pirates swarmed aboard, binding master and servants—three in all—and casting them into the water. The pirates made off with all the chests and belongings, stripping the vessel bare before scattering. Truly:

Without the bone-piercing chill of winter’s frost,
How could plum blossoms fill the air with fragrance?

Had Da Qiao not endured this peril, how could he and his wife have later risen to such honor and prosperity?

This concludes the fourth tale of Scroll Three.

**Fifth Tale of Scroll Three**
*The Plain Maiden Thrice Fulfills Her Marriage*

Now, the waters beneath Mount Dagu were part of the Yangtze’s mighty current—where countless souls had vanished without a trace, who could ever account for them? Yet Da Qiao’s fate was not yet sealed. She drifted until she neared a moored vessel, where the boatman spied her and cried, “A woman is floating downstream! Quick, save her!” The crew rushed to action—some with poles, others into the water—and hauled her aboard. Though she clung to but a few breaths of life, the official in the cabin ordered the boatwoman to cut her bonds, change her clothes, and let her rest awhile before summoning Da Qiao inside to recount her story.

Da Qiao told of her parents’ origins, her betrothals to Zhang and Li, and how she had been waylaid by pirates. The official sighed repeatedly, “Pitiful, pitiful!” Then, eyeing her closely, he saw a face so plain that none would find her pleasing. “Now grown to such an age, still a maiden of a good family, cast adrift here—if I do not lift her up, she will surely become a ghost of the gutters.” Turning to Da Qiao, he said, “Marriage comes sooner or later as fate decrees. Da Qiao rejoiced, “My lord, you have given me life and will secure my future. Even if I repaid you with jade rings and bound grass in the afterlife, it would not suffice for a fraction of your kindness.” She drew a chair forward, “Father, please be seated while your child kowtows in gratitude for your rebirth of me.” The official sat without hesitation, watching her bow before rising to take his proper seat.

The next day, he hired two maids to attend Lady Da Qiao. Who was this official? None other than Chen Guozhu, father of Chen Yan—the same Chen Yan who had engaged Lu Yousheng as his tutor—now serving as Education Commissioner of Shaanxi, en route to assume his post. Da Qiao’s fortune had led her to this lifesaving benefactor, who would later bestow upon her wealth and honor. Upon taking office, Commissioner Chen governed with pristine integrity. Yet his unyielding nature and refusal to curry favor with superiors led to his impeachment by the provincial inspector after three years. Demoted to Prefect of Fuzhou, he set out for Fujian with Da Qiao in tow. Once settled, he sent for his family.

Meanwhile, Chen Yan—though dull-witted—had flourished under his tutor’s guidance. Their days passed in poetry and prose, their bond as close as flesh and blood, until three autumns had slipped by. One day, news arrived of his father’s demotion to Fuzhou Prefect. Though dismayed, Chen Yan took solace in the proximity of the post, where he could bring his aged parents and young siblings to share in his prosperity. Soon after, the messengers arrived, and he prepared to depart. Lu Yousheng sought to resign and return home, but Chen Yan pleaded so earnestly that he relented and accompanied them.

Upon reaching Fuzhou’s borders, porters, sedan chairs, and horses awaited. They entered the yamen, where the young lady paid her respects to her mother. Commissioner Chen recounted Da Qiao’s story to his wife, who exclaimed, “A daughter of such years, and you left her unmarried in Shaanxi for three years?” Chen replied, “She was born and raised in Wu. She must wed a man of her homeland so her parents may one day reunite.” His wife agreed, “That makes sense.”

That evening, a feast was laid, and Commissioner Chen invited his son’s tutor for conversation. Father, son, and teacher drank together. After several rounds, Chen remarked, “My son was once so unruly, but thanks to your guidance, his speech and manners have improved.” Lu Yousheng demurred, “Not at all. Your son is remarkably quick-witted, grasping ten things from one. I, long out of practice, fear I am unworthy to be his teacher. I hope you will not hold me accountable.” They exchanged tales of their journeys, discussed history and literature, and did not part until the night had deepened. The next day, the young master and his tutor resumed their studies in the rear garden.

This occurred in early March, when the peonies were in full bloom. Miss Da Qiao, accompanied by three or four maidservants, entered the rear garden to admire the flowers. As she turned past the study, she unexpectedly came face-to-face with Lu Yousheng. He quickly retreated into the study. The maidservants followed their mistress as she wandered among the blossoms, enjoying herself to the fullest before returning.

Unbeknownst to her, Lu Yousheng had torn a hole in the paper window and secretly observed her, thinking: *"Though this young lady is adorned with pearls and jade, she has not a trace of beauty. No wonder, at her age, she remains unwed—what a pity her youth is thus wasted."* His gaze followed her until she passed through the garden gate, and only then did he turn away. With a sigh, he murmured, *"Miss, your suffering is no different from mine. I, Lu Yousheng, possess both talent and looks, yet today I too am alone. If one were to judge fairly, your solitude in the women’s quarters would not be amiss."*

Indeed:
*Though beauty and plainness differ in form,*
*Two lonely lamps burn in separate chambers.*

This fleeting thought, born of a moment’s whim, should have been dismissed at once—yet unbeknownst to him, his heart became ensnared, and day and night, the young lady lingered in his thoughts, stirring endless melancholy. Reflecting on his past, he reproached himself: *"In my youth, I lacked all resolve. *One misstep undoes the whole,*
*Leaving the board in ruin.*

Qiaoqiao reproached him: *"Sir, how could you be so heartless? Had you heeded my words, you would not be in this state today."*
Yousheng replied: *"I was foolish—twice deceived by others."*
Qiaoqiao said: *"Now, your destined bride is a lady of noble birth. If you repeat your past mistakes, you will never know marital bliss."*
Yousheng answered: *"I understand, I understand."*

Then Chaoyun seized him, saying: *"Master, why did you... [text missing] ...on that matchmaking visit? [text missing] ...from the book chest and handed it to Chaoyun [text missing]."* Qiaoqiao then recounted the tale of their matchmaking efforts to Yousheng. He exclaimed: *"From your words, it seems you two have become ghosts of the Yellow Springs!"* Realizing they were indeed spirits, they fell silent, then vanished like the wind. Yousheng rushed to search for them, but no trace remained. Convinced they were ghosts, he cried out in alarm—only to awaken from the dream.

He searched for the handkerchief, but it too had vanished. Reflecting on past events, he realized it had all been the work of ghosts. Though he had long treasured the handkerchief, harboring a secret dread, he now understood its origin and sighed deeply. But no more of this.

Though fate had decreed this union, it was their intervention that had brought it to pass. Thereafter, their allotted time in the mortal realm ended, and they appeared before King Yama. But this is another matter.

As for Lu Yousheng, upon waking from the dream, he surmised the noble lady must be Master Chen’s daughter. Overjoyed, he thought: *"To wed her would make my twenty years of wandering worthwhile."* From then on, he fixated on the young lady, neglecting his studies and losing his appetite, falling into a languishing lovesickness. He sighed: *"The young lady endures solitude in her secluded chamber, while I, Lu Yousheng, bear the loneliness of a wandering scholar. Heaven! Why not bind our feet with the red thread and let us grow old together? Then we would both have a place in this world. Yet there is a difficulty: Master Chen is a stubborn man—how could he consent to marry his daughter to a drifting stranger like me? Even if he agreed, the lady might not willingly wed a mere tutor. And even if both consented, I have no means to approach them, nor can I ask another to propose on my behalf. To speak for myself would be improper, and if the old man refused, I would only invite humiliation, making things awkward between teacher and student. In truth, she is a lady of high birth, and I am a learned scholar. If I do not scorn her plainness, and she does not scorn my poverty, then marrying me would not be beneath her."*

After endless deliberation, he concluded the matter was impossible—he could only *"quench his thirst by gazing at plums."* Meanwhile, the imperial examination was announced, and Master Chen’s son, wishing his tutor to assume the Chen surname and accompany him to the provincial exam, had Yousheng change his name to Chen Chong. Both entered the examination hall and performed admirably: the tutor ranked first in the preliminary round, while the young master placed third. Both were approved to proceed to the next stage.

When the autumn examination arrived and the three sessions concluded, the master ranked beyond the eightieth place, while Master Chen’s son passed as the [missing characters]... dividing host and guest. First, as a nephew by age; second, as one who had passed the exams alongside his adoptive son; and third, as Master Chen had long harbored the intention to betroth his eldest daughter, Daqiao, to the master—on that day, Daqiao did not appear to greet him. Master Chen and his wife took the seats of honor, the master facing west, the young master facing east, and all drank merrily until thoroughly intoxicated. The following day, they inevitably had to meet with fellow graduates and the chief examiner, remaining occupied for a full month before finding leisure.

One day, Master Chen said to his wife, “I have long wished to betroth Daqiao to the master. Now that he has passed the exams, we must not miss this fine opportunity.” His wife replied, “But our daughter is plain and past her prime. What if the master finds her unsatisfactory?” Master Chen said, “We shall marry them first and deal with matters afterward.” That very day, he visited an acquaintance, one Ke Bing, and asked him to act as matchmaker. Ke Bing agreed and promptly called on Yousheng to propose the marriage of Master Chen’s daughter. How could Yousheng, who had long yearned in vain, refuse when Master Chen now condescended to the match? He readily assented. An auspicious day was chosen, and the betrothal was sealed with a silk thread. The wedding took place at the Chen residence.

On the night of the wedding, after the nuptial rites were completed and they retired to the bridal chamber, Yousheng embraced Daqiao’s fragrant shoulders and, holding a silver mirror, examined her face. He sighed and said, “My fate, my fate!” Daqiao replied, “My sweetheart, my sweetheart!” Yousheng chuckled and stepped away. Daqiao, angered, said, “I only called you that out of affection, not wishing to refuse your sentiment. Why do you mock me?” Yousheng replied, “I was not laughing at you, nor was I addressing you. Yousheng repeatedly pleaded and cajoled, but her sobs only grew louder. As she wept, she cried out, “You clearly find me ugly and mean to flee! If you leave, I’ll have my father submit a memorial against you, strip you of your rank, and take your life!” With that, she wept anew. Flustered, Yousheng feared that Master Chen and his wife might overhear, which would be mortifying. He quickly dropped to his knees and said, “My lady, forgive this first offense—I will never again dare to offend your noble countenance.” He then used his sleeve to cover her gaping mouth, a full foot wide.

Seeing his earnest efforts, Daqiao finally fell silent and asked, “What exactly is this lament of yours about fate? Tell me everything. If you utter a single falsehood, you’ll kneel until dawn.” Yousheng replied, “At eighteen, I resolved to marry a peerless beauty. Unluckily, my father betrothed me to Pu Xiaochuan’s daughter, who was hideously ugly. After the wedding ceremony, I fled. Later, I married Kong Fang’s daughter—equally repulsive—and again left without a word. Now, having wed you, my lady, whose beauty is refined and wholly to my liking, this sigh was only because fate decreed I should marry a lady of noble birth. How could I wed such extraordinarily ugly women? Is that not my fate?”

Hearing this, Daqiao could not suppress a smile. She helped him to his feet and said, “Your fate is my fate.”

“When I first married a man named Lu Shishan, I fled after the wedding ceremony. Later, I married Yan Yu, and again I fled. Now that I’ve wed you, sir, I feared you too would run away—so I only answered you with such hesitation.”

Yousheng replied, “From what you say, that Lu Shishan was me, that Yan Yu was me, and this Chen Chong who has married you today is also me. Could it be, my lady, that you are none other than the daughter of the Pu family and the young lady of the Kong household?”

Daqiao said, “I need not hide it from you: that daughter of Pu Xiaochuan was I, that Kong Fang’s beloved A’ai was I, and this young lady who has married you today is also I.”

Yousheng said, “I thought there could not be two such women in the world—it was always you. Truly, the bonds of predestined affinity are not to be defied.” The two laughed and jested for a while, then undressed and retired to bed.

Their words had only just crossed, and now they must make amends beneath the covers. One was a maiden past her prime yet still blossoming, the other a long-deprived virgin no longer young—what need for modesty, what cause for refusal? Hand in hand, they embraced the clouds and grasped the rain, ascending at once to the heights of Gaotang. By this time, Yousheng cared not for the plainness above, savoring only the delicacies below. Yet his heart still harbored a lingering regret—not that anything was amiss, but that the two of them had squandered twenty years of romance, crawling and scrambling in vain, only to end as husband and wife after all.

That night’s joy need not be told. The next day, when they spoke with Master Chen, all marveled without end.

Meanwhile, before any others could reach the capital, only Prefect Yan managed to send a letter, revealing their whereabouts. Thereafter, all word from them vanished. Fortunately, Yousheng later fathered a daughter, nicknamed Daier—meaning "a daughter in place of a son"—who had now reached sixteen. By Heaven’s grace, the couple at last had someone to fill their home, sparing them the loneliness of old age.

One day, as they sat idly in the hall, a man suddenly approached with joy written across his face. Dropping to his knees, he cried, “Father, your son has narrowly escaped death—today I return!” Tiancheng, his aged eyes blurred, peered closely before seizing him in an embrace. “My child,” he wept, “you abandoned me for twenty years—how I have longed for you!” Grief and joy surged together, and tears streamed unchecked. Inside, Xiaoshi heard the old man’s sobs and, unaware of the cause, hurried out with their daughter. Seeing them, Yousheng knelt and bowed deeply. The three embraced, weeping bitterly—only Daier, confused, slipped away.

Tiancheng turned to her: “This is your elder brother, gone for twenty years and only now returned. Come, greet him.” Daier curtsied twice before them, and the four sat down. After such long separation, words could hardly suffice. Yousheng recounted his success in the imperial examinations and his marriage to the daughter of Pu Xiaochuan. His parents rejoiced, sending servants to fetch his luggage from the boat and escort his bride ashore. Qin Si, who had been given in adoption to Master Chen, returned as well, accompanied by a maidservant for the journey.

Tiancheng then dispatched a messenger to inform the Pu family. Before long, Pu Xiaochuan and his wife arrived. With the bride now present, incense and candles were lit throughout the hall. Yousheng and his wife bowed anew before the ancestral shrine, then paid respects to both sets of parents. A grand reunion feast was laid out, and joy overflowed. Between cups of wine, they took turns recounting the past twenty years—laughter erupting at moments of happiness, tears flowing at tales of hardship.

At this moment, only Pu Xiaochuan and his wife flushed with deep embarrassment—having once claimed their daughter was dead, how could she now be here? Though the Lu family made no mention of it, they felt profound shame in their hearts. That evening, the feast ended in full merriment.

The next day, Yousheng inquired after Qiaoqiao and Chaoyun, only to be told they had died seventeen or eighteen years prior. Overcome with grief, he mourned their loss, reflecting on the love they had shared—now vanished without a trace. Little did he know that Qiaoqiao and Chaoyun had gone to the Pu household to continue the ancestral line! All this was predestined karma, a debt from past lives, where separation and reunion unfolded as if guided by unseen hands.

A year later, Master Chen’s term of office ended, and he traveled to the capital with his son for the imperial examinations. Passing through Suzhou, they paid a visit to Lu Tiancheng. Yousheng promptly prepared a banquet. As they drank, the conversation turned to Master Chen’s son’s marriage. Yousheng offered his sister in place of his own son as a match, and Master Chen agreed, saying to Tiancheng, “The journey was rushed, and I have not prepared betrothal gifts—what is to be done?” Tiancheng replied, “My son has long received your familial kindness; what need is there for formalities?”

The next day, Master Chen sent a messenger bearing a golden *ruyi* scepter and a silver tripod as tokens of betrothal. After lingering for several days, they set off together for the capital to take the examinations. When the spring imperial exams concluded, both passed as *jinshi* of the third rank and were appointed magistrates, awaiting their official seals. Master Chen was reassigned as a maritime commissioner, and upon their return, Yousheng arranged his sister’s marriage. All assumed their posts in honor.

Later, Yousheng’s two sons both passed the highest examinations, and he and his wife lived to the age of ninety. Their descendants flourished for ten thousand generations, proving that the affairs of the world—what man does not strive for yet comes to pass, what he does not seek yet attains—are all the work of Heaven and fate, not within mortal power. Reflect upon this and take heed. *End of the First Tale in Scroll Four.*

The Moon Palace’s Chang’e Suffers Calamity

*Poem:*
Beneath the bright moon, wind still in wild clouds’ span,
Wine in hand, I sing, delighting in nature’s plan.
Worldly affairs are but a game of chess,
Hold fast to the true Dao, and face the heavens’ span.

When the Dao of Heaven is not upright, wind and rain miss their season, and human life meets with disaster and hardship. When the Dao of the Ruler is not upright, governance falls into disrepair, and the people grow cunning and deceitful. When the Dao of Man is not upright, the inner chambers are not kept in order, and the household teems with perversity and falsehood.

In the time of Emperor Yao, there were twenty years of great floods; in the Zhou dynasty, frost fell in the sixth month; in the Han, a white rainbow pierced the sun; and in the reign of Emperor Xuanzong, locusts swarmed across the land—these were all signs of the Dao of Heaven being askew.

As for the Dao of the Ruler being askew, consider the First Emperor of Qin, who destroyed the six states and unified the realm. Had he been diligent and vigilant, cultivating virtue and practicing benevolence, his dynasty might have endured for ten thousand generations. Instead, he heeded the words of alchemists and journeyed beyond the seas in search of immortals.

At that time, a Daoist in a yellow cap, seeing the First Emperor on his eastern progress, prostrated himself by the roadside. Boasting of his immortal arts, he performed wondrous transformations, each more marvelous than the last. The First Emperor, half-believing, half-doubting, said, “As I am on my eastern tour, I have no leisure to receive your teachings. When I return to the capital, I shall send for you to speak with me at length.” The Daoist took his leave, then mounted a wisp of white cloud and drifted away.

Seeing such strangeness, the First Emperor regretted missing the immortal before him and cursed his futile journey beyond the seas. He hastily sealed Mount Tai and returned to the capital. There, the Daoist was already prostrate outside the palace gates. The eunuchs announced his presence, and the emperor summoned him into the palace. Seated in conversation on profound matters, the First Emperor held him in great esteem.

When asked of his whereabouts, the Daoist replied, “This poor Daoist roams from Cangwu to the Northern Sea in an instant—how could I have a fixed abode? The threshold of the Jade Purity Palace in Heaven was once inlaid with sandalwood, catalpa, and nanmu, adorned with the Eight Treasures. But over the years, it has rotted away. I wished to recast it in solid silver to endure forever and enhance its splendor. I wonder if Your Majesty would deign to approve this humble sincerity and generously fulfill this great vow?”

The First Emperor said, “How much could a threshold cost? But I must know its length, width, and height to calculate the amount.” The Daoist replied, “I have already measured it: eleven feet long, two feet wide, and one foot high. It will require thirty-six thousand taels of silver.”

The First Emperor immediately ordered eunuchs to deliver the sum from the inner treasury. He summoned many silversmiths and set a deadline of five days to complete the work. They carved dragons, phoenixes, flowers, birds, water ripples, and cloud patterns into it, crafting it with utmost skill.

The First Emperor asked the Daoist, “How will such a heavy threshold ascend to Heaven?” The Daoist replied, “Do not trouble Your Majesty with such concerns. This poor Daoist will return in five days to collect it.”

Sure enough, on the fifth day, a white crane flew into the palace, took the threshold in its beak as lightly as a reed, and soared into the sky. The First Emperor gazed after it for a long time, watching it vanish into the clouds. All in the palace were astonished, declaring that the Son of Heaven’s great fortune had brought about this wondrous encounter. The First Emperor, too, believed it was his own virtue and power that had wrought this marvel, and all praised him without end.

Who could have known that five years later, the Daoist would disguise himself in commoner’s garb and take a piece of silver to a silversmith’s shop to be melted down? The silversmith recognized the dragon and phoenix carvings as resembling those made in the imperial palace. He exchanged the silver but secretly followed the Daoist and reported him to the county authorities. The magistrate dispatched many constables to arrest him.

When the Daoist saw the crowd approaching, he realized their intent. With a twist of his body, he sank into the earth. The constables searched all around but found no trace of him. Only when they dug beneath a large tree did they see a foot of clothing protruding from the ground. The magistrate, knowing him to be a demonic Daoist, ordered pig and dog blood to be poured from above. As they dug, the Daoist stood stiff in the earth, the silver threshold at his feet.

They seized him, bound him with ropes, and pried open the threshold. A hundred men strained to drag it out, and together they escorted him to the First Emperor. By imperial decree, the Daoist was sentenced to death by slow slicing, and the silver threshold was carried back into the palace and returned to the inner treasury. This was a case of the people’s cunning and deceit.

Now, let us speak of a tale where the Dao of Man is not upright. During the Jiajing era of the Ming dynasty, in the region of Suian County, Yan Prefecture, Zhejiang, there lived a *jinshi* named Guo Lin, styled Xiangong. He had served as prefect of Yanzhou in Shandong but was then observing the mourning period for his parents at home. His wife, née Yuan, was fifty years old and had borne him one son and two daughters. Their son, Guo Zongxian, was nineteen and had already passed the county examinations. Their eldest daughter was sixteen, with the childhood name Zhenzhu, and their younger daughter was twelve, called Zhangzhu.

Miss Zhenzhu was born with a refined and elegant temperament, her joy and anger never showing on her face. She favored plain tea and simple meals, and preferred to wear unadorned white garments. If even a hint of bright color touched her person, she would be restless until she removed it. With such a disposition, one might well imagine her bearing to be naturally extraordinary.

Her mother, seeing her in such attire, would often jestingly call her "Chang'e." One day, during the Mid-Autumn Festival when osmanthus blooms were in full splendor, Master Guo and his wife were in the hall admiring the moon and flowers—moonlight shimmering in their cups, fragrance wafting over their mats. After several rounds of wine, Master Guo sighed, "Today the jade heavens are spotless, the crystal vase radiant and clear. Only the Moon Palace lacks Chang'e to open its gates and dance in rainbow-hued robes."

Hearing the word *Chang'e*, his wife assumed he was calling for their eldest daughter and promptly instructed a maid, "Summon the eldest young lady." The maid entered the embroidered chamber and escorted Miss Zhenzhu to the steps below. Lady Yuan smiled, "Chang'e has arrived." Master Guo fixed his gaze upon his daughter—her plain white garments set off her flower-like countenance, her graceful bearing akin to a jade maiden. Turning to his wife, he remarked, "Though our daughter resembles Chang'e, alas, we have no Guanghan Palace to house her."

Miss Zhenzhu then stepped delicately into the hall. After exchanging courtesies, she sat beside them. The three shared several cups of wine until the moon began its westward descent. The feast was cleared, and they retired to their chambers.

That night, Master Guo mused, "Our daughter possesses such beauty, so like Chang'e—why not build a Moon Palace in the rear garden to keep her there? Then we might seek a zhuangyuan son-in-law to marry her, and our family’s prestige would shine even brighter." Indeed:
*Plucking osmanthus in the moon to welcome immortal guests,*
*The world gazes in awe at the zhuangyuan’s cloud-borne glory.*

Master Guo pondered this all night. The next morning, after washing and dressing, he strolled to the rear garden, surveying the grounds. Finding the space too cramped for his vision, he muttered, "We’ll need ten acres of open land to do this properly. Best to choose a site outside the city." He then took two servants, boarded a small sedan chair, and traveled several *li* beyond the city walls to a secluded spot. There lay a vast, level expanse, surrounded by mountains on all sides—a most refined setting. Master Guo sent men to inquire about the landowner and purchased the plot at a fair price.

Construction began without delay. After spending five or six thousand taels and a full year of labor, the palace stood complete—truly magnificent. It was just before Mid-Autumn when one beheld:
*A pristine edifice spanning the sky, the Silver River gleaming bright.*
*Eaves carved high, needing no painted adornment;*
*The winding terrain, graced by celestial blossoms.*
*Music and pipes resounded, invoking the spirit of the Moon Goddess;*
*Laughter and chatter mingled, half-echoing the zither of the Xiang Consorts.*
*Bright stars glowed like mirrors arrayed;*
*Cool sleeves fluttered as morning tresses were dressed.*
*Perfumed waters flowed free of grease;*
*Orchids exhaled their icy, fragrant breath.*
*White clouds drifted from the bridal chamber,*
*Layered snow adorned the pale walls.*
*Osmanthus petals scattered golden grains,*
*Toad-light exhaled jade-like mist.*
*Though likened to jasper towers and jade halls,*
*It was fit only for moon maidens and fairy consorts.*

When the Moon Palace was finished, Master Guo had a plaque mounted above the gate inscribed: *The Hall of Vast Cold and Emptiness*. Miss Zhenzhu, with her simple and elegant adornments, lent the place a sparse charm. He assigned several households of servants and a dozen maidservants to attend her, then sent her to reside in the palace. There, she spent her days climbing hills, gazing upon waters, admiring the moon, and enjoying the flowers.

One evening, as dusk fell with a bright moon and sparse stars, the wind still and clouds at rest, Miss Zhenzhu ascended the Tower of Soaring Skies to admire the moon. By the second watch, a foul wind suddenly arose outside the window, shaking the grass and trees. Soon, crows scattered and cuckoos cried in disarray, while foxes howled and gibbons shrieked—all manner of malevolent spirits converging in chaos. Before Miss Zhenzhu could retreat to her chamber, a white-browed tiger leapt onto the terrace, pounced upon her, and carried her off in its jaws. The maidservants nearby were struck with terror, their souls scattering in fright. They hurriedly alerted the steward, and the household rushed to the scene—only to find their young mistress gone.

In a panic, they lit torches and scoured the mountains, but found no trace. That very night, they hastened back to the city to inform Master Guo and his wife. Overcome with regret, Master Guo reproached his wife, "Our fine daughter—we compared her to Chang'e, yet now she has vanished from the Moon Palace, gone who knows where." His wife, in turn, blamed him: "Such a grown girl should have stayed by our side! Who asked you to build this soul-snatching Moon Palace, sending her to her doom?" The two lamented bitterly, then followed their servants to the palace outside the city, where they wept in sorrow. They sent men to search the mountains for her remains, intending to bury them, but after days of fruitless searching, they had no choice but to abandon the effort. Master Guo and his wife offered a skyward lament before gathering their servants and maids to return home. Truly:
*In the Moon Palace, none to keep her company—*
*Chang'e weeps, carried off by a tiger’s jaws.*

Beyond the mountain lay the Lan□ region, where a woodcutter named Jin lived. He and his wife, both elderly, had no children. One day, while selling firewood in the market, they encountered a boy of about six, dressed in fine, resplendent clothes. His bearing was dignified, yet his eyes darted about in confusion, tears streaming as he wandered lost. Old Jin took him home, treating him as an adopted son, and named him Jin Yu.

Fearing the boy might learn of his parents' origins and one day return home, Old Jin moved his family deep into the mountains, over a hundred *li* from the market town. He also forbade the boy from speaking freely before others, so that none in the mountains knew his true background, and all took him for their own son. Later, when Old Jin and his wife passed away, Jin Yu continued the firewood trade, and by then he was nearly ten years old.

One morning, he rose early to gather firewood. A gloomy wind moaned, and a thick white mist clung to the ground. As he rounded a bend in the mountain path, he heard faint sobbing from a tiger pit—a woman’s voice. Jin Yu stepped forward to look and saw a woman of breathtaking beauty, her hair adorned with pearls and jade, wailing to the heavens. "Save me! Save me!" she cried. Jin Yu thought, *"If I rescue such a woman, she might marry me—or at the very least, those pearls and jewels on her head would be my reward."* Quickly, he removed the wooden cover from the pit and untied the ropes, but the pit was several *zhang* deep, making it difficult to devise a way out. After a moment’s thought, he took the rope from his carrying pole, untied it, and lowered it down. The woman grasped the end and climbed up with ease. Once out, she bowed deeply to Jin Yu four times. Just as he was about to ask her story, the woman leapt into the air with a sudden bound and transformed into an old tiger, roaring away. Jin Yu was so startled he tumbled to the ground in a heap. When he looked again, the tiger had vanished without a trace. Puzzled, he returned to his firewood gathering.

But let us set aside Jin Yu’s musings for now and explain the tiger’s origins. In the mountains of Lan□, at the precipice of □ Mouth Cliff, there lived a Daoist named Xiao Daoyan. He had resided there for years, nourishing himself on pine needles and cypress berries, cultivating his *qi* and refining his primordial essence, his practice nearly perfected. One day, a demonic impulse seized him, craving the taste of human brains. Sitting in meditation on the cliff, he thought, *"I must transform into a tiger to obtain such fare."* By chance, he came upon a temple where a tiger pelt lay hidden beneath the Buddha’s altar. He took it and donned it, then recalled the *Three Transformations of the Yellow Weasel* incantation from the *Seven Lots from the Bookcase of the Clouds*. With a rustle, he became a ferocious tiger, his heart swelling with savagery. He prowled the mountain valleys, devouring anyone he encountered. The terror spread through the region, and the people lived in dread. The local authorities dispatched hunters to dig pits and set traps across the mountains.

That day, the tiger emerged from the mountains only to fall into a pit. There, he transformed into a woman. Just then, he encountered a woodcutter, who rescued her from the snare. The Daoist, ever mindful of the life-saving kindness like gold and jade, took pity on the woodcutter’s solitary existence and sought to find him a fine match. Coincidentally, Master Guo the Immortal was building a Moon Palace for his daughter to reside in, and the Daoist, moved by this impulse to repay virtue, carried the Pearl Maiden away in his jaws, intending to make her the woodcutter’s wife. Yet, unaware of the woodcutter’s dwelling, he first placed the maiden in his cave. Then, reciting the skin-shedding incantation, he reverted to his Daoist form to seek out the woodcutter’s home—this need not be recounted here.

Meanwhile, the maiden, dragged over five or six mountain ridges by the tiger, was so terrified her limbs turned limp, her chest barely holding a thread of breath. The Daoist boiled water, took a calming elixir, and poured it into her mouth. Gradually, she revived and regained her senses. Realizing she had been carried off by a tiger, she was fortunate not to have been devoured. Slowly rising, she looked around and saw a stone bed, stone stool, stone table, and stone hearth within a stone chamber—all seven necessities of a household were present, as if it were a small home. The maiden thought, *"Why has this tiger brought me here? I should leave this cave and find my way back to my Moon Palace."* But outside the cave, ancient trees stood with cawing crows, a desolate wind howled through the ravine, and no human trace could be found—only wolves and jackals roamed. The maiden hesitated, unable to endure the hardship, and returned to the cave, weeping bitterly. Soon, hunger gnawed at her. Noticing a faint gleam in a basin, she went to the hearth, lit a fire, and cooked rice. Choking back sobs, she ate a bowl and sat there.

Just then, the Daoist returned, carrying meat from a river deer and other game. Entering the cave, he set down his burden and saw the maiden. Only then did she realize this was the abode of a Daoist cultivating the Way. Stepping forward, she bowed and said, *"I am the daughter of Prefect Guo. A tiger carried me here—I beg you, Master, to send me back, and I will reward you with gold and silk."* The Daoist replied, *"That can be arranged. Let this poor Daoist first inquire about your residence, and then I shall escort you home."*

The Daoist said, *"Pray allow the young lady to stay a few more days. Only, this deep mountain offers neither food nor bedding fit for a lady’s use—pray forgive this poor Daoist’s inadequacies."* The maiden replied, *"There is a reason. An unmarried man and woman dwelling alone in these secluded hills may invite suspicion, like the proverbial melon patch or plum tree beneath which one dares not adjust one’s hat."* The Daoist said, *"The young lady is mistaken. This poor Daoist has cultivated in bitter austerity for over thirty years, on the verge of attainment—how could I harbor such impure thoughts and ruin a lifetime’s work? The young lady need not worry."*

The Daoist then turned and left. The maiden thought, *"This Daoist treats me with such courtesy and respect—he likely harbors no designs. I shall observe his behavior tonight to set my mind at ease."* The Daoist went outside the mountain and fetched a reed screen, dividing the stone cave into two courtyards: the maiden within, the Daoist without. When evening came, they took their supper, and the maiden lay down fully clothed. Beyond the screen, the Daoist sat beneath the lamplight, gnawing and crunching with such vigor that the sounds of swallowing and chewing grated on the ear.

The maiden quietly stepped down from her stone bed and peered through a gap in the reed screen. There, the Daoist was gnawing on a human head. Terrified, her heart pounded like a startled deer, her soul nearly fled her body. She knew her own flesh would soon be devoured, yet the situation left no choice—summoning her courage, she watched for some time. She saw... (text missing) ...eating... pounding the skull with his fist...

**Chapter Four, Second Tale: "The Divine Incantation Turns Illusion to Reality"**

Pearl Maiden, seeing the Daoist’s savagery, trembled with fear and lay back down. She thought, *"If this Daoist does not violate me tonight, there may yet be hope of returning home."* Then she reconsidered: *"If he is truly a tiger, I am but prey in his jaws—how could he ever let me go?"* She tossed and turned, sleepless through the night: *"I shall see what tomorrow brings to know my fate."*

At dawn, the Daoist entered to greet the maiden and saw that the wild game offered the day before remained untouched. He took it away. Soon after, he returned with a basket of melons and fruits, placing them in the kitchen before departing again. The maiden, seeing the produce, forced herself to eat a few pieces. That evening, she watched once more, though with less apprehension.

For half a month the maiden pleaded with the Daoist, saying, *"I have been away from home these fifteen days, and my longing for my family is unbearable. I beg you, Master, send me home. The reward I promised shall not be withheld."* The Daoist replied, *"This poor Daoist has already inquired beyond the mountains—Master Guo’s estate lies a month’s journey from here. Lacking travel funds, I have delayed your return."*

The maiden thought, *"I arrived but a single night ago—how could it now be a month? This is clearly the Daoist’s trickery."* She entreated him again and again to send her back. At last, the Daoist recounted the full tale: how he had fallen into a trap, how the woodcutter had saved him, and how he now sought the maiden’s hand in marriage.

The maiden said, *"If that is so, why not send me home to speak with my parents? A proper match through a formal proposal—what could be better?"* The Daoist shook his head: *"Impossible! How could your father ever consent to wed his blossom-like daughter to a woodcutter?"* He urged her to be patient, promising that once he had found the man, all would be well.

The maiden wept bitterly, pleading with tears and snot, but the Daoist remained unmoved. With no other recourse, she returned to her chamber, wondering how he would proceed. Before she knew it, another month had passed.

She thought, *"This Daoist is so strange—why does he don a tiger’s pelt and chant a spell to transform? I’ve grown familiar with the incantation, but he hides the pelt each day, and I’ve never been able to seize it."* One morning, the Daoist rose early and left. The maiden went to the cave’s entrance and searched all around until she spotted the tiger pelt in a stone chamber above. She dragged over a stool, climbed up, and pulled it down, overjoyed.

She donned the pelt, recited the spell, and with a leap, her body surged with strength. Flourishing her might, she let out a roar—mountains trembled, trees shook, and with a flick of her tail and a toss of her head, she bounded out of the cave.

She thought, *"If I return home now, my parents won’t recognize me. Besides, the city offers no place for me. Better to visit the Moon Palace first and decide later."* Crossing several ridges, she saw towering pavilions and lofty terraces and thought, *"This must be my homeland."*

With a single tiger’s bound, she leapt to the gate. There she saw the courtyard desolate, the plants and trees forlorn—nothing like the palace of old. The maiden butted her head against the door, and it swung open at once. □□□ she slunk inside, gazing all around in sorrow, overcome with grief.

After a while, she thought, *"Why not shed this pelt now, return to my human form, and send word to my parents to fetch me home? What could be better?"* She shook herself vigorously, but the fur clung fast. Enraged, she cried, *"If I cannot cast off this tiger’s hide, I’ll remain a beast for life, abandoning my flower-like beauty to drift away like the eastern current—what am I to do?"* She let out a deafening roar, claws slashing, fangs bared, charging wildly about until the Moon Palace was torn askew in an instant. With head hung low and spirits broken, she returned to the mountains. No more of this shall be told.

Meanwhile, word spread among the households at the foot of the mountain that the Moon Palace of Immortal Guo had collapsed, and all came to see the spectacle. The broken rafters and shattered balustrades were casually gathered by the crowd, who carried them away. Unbeknownst to them, Immortal Guo had already learned of the matter and dispatched his servants to retrieve the debris. Seeing the people hauling and tugging at the remnants, the servants seized several and detained them at the home of Village Head Huang to be sent to the authorities. There, they were first subjected to private flogging, their cries of agony filling the air as they pleaded for mercy.

Just then, a Daoist priest passed by the door and, hearing the mournful wails, entered to investigate. Among the captives was the very woodcutter who had once rescued him from a pit—someone he had sought for over a month without success, only to encounter him here by chance. Stepping forward, the priest addressed the steward: *"Esteemed patrons, though I may not know the proper decorum, I humbly beg a word with you."* The crowd replied, *"Master, you are a venerable elder of this place. Speak freely. Tomorrow, we may call upon you to bear witness."* The priest said, *"I care not for the others, but this young man is my nephew, who chops wood for a living to support my old age. Today, in a moment of folly, he has offended you. I offer this modest gift in hopes of your forgiveness."* With that, he presented a five-tael ingot of gleaming silver. The crowd accepted it gladly.

The priest thanked them and turned to lead Jin Yu away, but the others held him back: *"We appreciate your generosity, but we’ll spare him the flogging. Tomorrow, he must still be sent to the magistrate."* The priest pleaded repeatedly, but they refused. Jin Yu pulled the priest aside to a secluded spot and asked, *"Master, what connection do we share that you would spend five taels of silver to save me?"* The priest replied, *"Never mind that now. I’ll explain later. But if they won’t release you today, what can be done?"* Jin Yu said, *"If you can secure my freedom, I will be indebted to you for life and death."* The priest pondered for a moment and then said, *"Very well. Tomorrow morning, when you see a tiger approaching, the crowd will surely scatter in fear—but you must not move. I will handle the rest."* Jin Yu agreed, and the two parted ways. Truly:

One bestows kindness, yet the recipient knows not gratitude;
One bears resentment, and the heart never forgets.
Behold how fortune and misfortune descend—
For kindness and grudges alike have their destined reckoning.

This aside, let us return to Miss Pearl. Upon returning to the mountains, she thought: *"That wretched Daoist’s skin I now wear—who knows how frantic he must be? I’ll go to the cave’s edge and listen to what he says."* She made her way to the entrance and saw the Daoist inside, devouring flesh and gnawing bones. With each bite, he sighed repeatedly: *"How strange! How strange! That young lady has vanished without a trace!"* Miss Pearl stifled her laughter.

After finishing his meal, he went to the stone chamber to retrieve the tiger pelt—only to find it gone. He stomped his feet, beat his chest, and wailed without end: *"This was my lifeline! Now that it’s lost, how shall I not starve?"* Then, muttering to himself, he said: *"Even if I perish, it’s no matter—but what of that woodcutter? I promised to go to Squire Huang’s home tomorrow morning to save him. Without this pelt, how can I keep my word to my benefactor?"* With that, he wept again.

Miss Pearl, having heard all clearly, made her way directly to Squire Huang’s gate to wait.

Just then, the household was gathered inside for breakfast. Miss Pearl leapt into the main hall—before the crowd could scatter, they tumbled into a heap. Only Jin Yu remained still, his heart as clear as a mirror. She seized him in her jaws, bounded twice in tiger-leaps, and sprang to the cave’s edge. The cave door was still shut, the Daoist inside sighing without cease. Miss Pearl set Jin Yu down, then rammed her head against the door several times before withdrawing to the side.

Hearing the commotion, the Daoist threw on his robe and opened the door—only to find a corpse stretched stiff before him. Steadying his gaze, he recognized the woodcutter he had vowed to save the day before. Overjoyed, he hurriedly boiled water, ground a *dingxin* pellet into powder, and mixed it into the brew. Jin Yu gradually revived. The Daoist helped him inside, seated him in the cave, and asked how he had come to be there. Jin Yu recounted all, leaving the Daoist deeply astonished; the account aligned with his own words, though he said nothing of it.

The Daoist then revealed how he had fallen into the trap, transformed into a woman, and been rescued by Jin Yu—how he had intended to give Miss Pearl to him in marriage—and told him everything. Only then did Jin Yu understand the strange events of the past, now made clear at last. After sharing a midday meal, he bid farewell and returned home, but no more of that need be told.

As for the servants and local constables who had witnessed Jin Yu being devoured by the tiger, they gathered their companions and entered the city to report the matter to the authorities. The magistrate, having heard their account, ordered twenty strokes of the rod and dismissed them. But this, too, need not be recounted.

Meanwhile, upon hearing the Daoist’s words, Miss Pearl thought to herself: *"If what the Daoist says is true, then this man is my husband. Just now, when I looked at him closely, his bearing was imposing, his features broad and open—truly the son of a noble house. Though he gathers firewood now, he is certain to rise in the world. If I marry him, so be it. But there is one matter: this pelt I wear is difficult to shed, and my belly aches with hunger, with nothing to eat.
