Why not go and sit in the woodcutter’s home, display a bit of divine power, fill my stomach for the moment, and secure a future for myself? Then we may become a fine couple—would that not be splendid!"*

She went straight to his door, flung it open, and sat inside. When Jin Yu arrived at the threshold and saw the door wide open, he assumed thieves had broken in. He checked all around but found nothing missing. Turning to the room, he saw *that thing*—his eyes bulged like marbles, his mouth gaped like a winnowing basket, and he bolted outside.

He thought: *"I recognize this old creature—it was the one who rescued me this morning and took me to the Daoist’s home. Has it returned now to demand thanks? Or did it not devour me earlier and has come to claim its reward? This is most perplexing. Let me take another look."*

The young lady, seeing Jin Yu, nodded her head repeatedly. Jin Yu leapt in fright and bolted out again. Just then, a neighbor’s dog happened to pass by. He seized it and tossed it before the tiger, saying, “Brother, here’s a modest offering—may it fill your belly. Now go your way elsewhere.”

The dog, terrified, rolled onto its back, yelping incessantly. The young lady sniffed at its body, then turned her head away. Jin Yu rejoiced, “Good, good! This tiger is a vegetarian—it won’t eat dog meat, let alone human flesh!” Emboldened, he stepped closer, reaching out to scratch her head and gauge her reaction. But he quickly withdrew his hand, thinking, *“Hold on! This is no time for recklessness. As the saying goes, ‘Who dares scratch an itch on a tiger’s head?’ With no plan in sight, I suppose I must leave her be.”*

He went to the kitchen to boil water and prepare a meal. The tiger followed to the stove, smacking her lips and wagging her tongue, as if begging for food. Jin Yu filled a bowl with rice and set it on the ground. The tiger licked it clean in an instant. He served her more, and after she finished, she sat there as before. Jin Yu ate his supper, lit a lamp, and retired to bed. The tiger walked to the bedside, lowered her head, closed her eyes, and settled down to sleep as well.

In his dreams, Jin Yu saw a woman as lovely as a flower or jade approach his bed. He asked her who she was. She replied, “I am the daughter of Prefect Guo. Fate has bound us together, and I have come to share your pillow in secret.” Recalling the Daoist’s words from earlier that day, Jin Yu embraced her warmly, undressed, and lay down with her. The two indulged in utmost delight, entwined like *mandarin ducks*, holding each other close, and drifted into deep slumber.

When he awoke, the woman was gone—only the tiger’s head lay beside his pillow. A cold sweat broke out all over his body, and he hurried to the inner side of the bed to sleep. The next day, he was utterly bewildered. That night, the woman returned in his sleep, exhausting every pleasure of the pillow, and made Jin Yu vow that neither would marry another. At that moment, he would have agreed to anything—even surrendering his life—so he readily consented, swearing a thousand oaths by her side.

When he rose the next morning, Jin Yu thought, *“This is clearly the tiger’s doing, bewitching my heart. I must steel my resolve and keep my distance.”* As soon as the tiger left the house, he hastily gathered his bedding and clothes and fled in haste.

*Truly:*

Falling blossoms long to follow the flowing stream,
Yet the flowing stream, heartless, clings not to the flowers.
Who knows where the tiger went in pursuit—what follows shall naturally unfold in detail.

**Chapter Four, Third Tale**
*The Daoist’s Bloodstains Restore True Nature*

Now, the maiden Pearl, having become Jin Yu’s dream-wedded wife for two nights, was deeply enamored. When the woodcutter failed to return by evening, she set out the next day in search of him. Little did she know that Jin Yu was staying at a friend’s house; as he stepped out the door, they came face to face. Overjoyed, the maiden wagged her head and tail, following him inside. The household, seeing the tiger approach, panicked and raised a clamor. Jin Yu said, “Do not be alarmed—this tiger is my domesticated one, and she eats only the purest vegetarian fare.” The crowd found this strange and gathered to watch. Indeed, she was as gentle as a human. When they offered her meat or fish, she refused, but if tofu or wheat gluten were placed before her, she devoured them as if they were butterflies. Soon, word spread through the village, and people brought vegetarian dishes to see the tiger. Eventually, the tiger grew weary of eating.

After a month or so, the villagers grew accustomed to her presence, and the tiger found little left to eat. Jin Yu thought, *“This place is too sparsely populated to sustain us both. Better to travel elsewhere and seek our fortune.”* They journeyed to Jinhua, where he hid the tiger in a mountain valley. Disguising himself as an immortal, he boasted, *“I can subdue tigers to bring peace to the land. All I require is a donation of a hundred taels of silver to build a thatched hut. If patrons are willing to contribute, I shall ride the tiger here for all to see.”* The crowd replied, *“If you truly ride the tiger here, we will gather the silver for you—and we ask that you teach disciples to guard against future tiger threats.”*

Before long, Jin Yu returned, riding the tiger. At first, the people were terrified, but seeing the tiger so docile, they collected the silver and presented it to him. Jin Yu then rode the tiger back into the mountains. Along the way, he mused, *“This trade is far better than chopping wood. It seems this tiger owed me a debt in a past life—by day, she earns me silver, and by night, she is my wife. Now that this place has grown accustomed to the sight, I shall travel to other provinces to amass more wealth and become a rich man.”* Gathering his belongings, he led the tiger onward, earning money along the way.

After a year of wandering, they reached Chuzhou. With several hundred taels of silver and heavy luggage, he found long travel inconvenient and rented a house there to settle. But of this, no more need be said.

The Daoist, now bereft of his tiger skin, had no choice but to remain in the cave, subsisting on meager fare, his endurance nearly spent. Venturing beyond the mountains, he found nothing to eat, and hunger left him weak and emaciated, his waist limp and his belly hollow. He thought, *“Last year, I wished to save that woodcutter, but without my tiger skin, I could not go to his aid. Then another tiger dragged him away, preserving my reputation for keeping my word—surely that young lady had donned my skin and transformed. Now I must search these mountains until I find her, and beg her to return it to me, lest I starve to death.”*

Staff in hand, he wandered from peak to peak, asking everyone he met about such a strange affair. Those who heard his tale kept it close to heart, and when they saw the Daoist inquiring after the tiger’s whereabouts, they knew at once where it might be found—three mouths agape, each a foot wide. His search led him at last to Chuzhou, where, by chance, he came upon the tiger sitting before a household’s gate with Jin Yu.

The Daoist said, *“Miss Guo, why are you here? You’ve left me in dire straits.”* Seeing him, the tiger trotted to his side and sat, as if in affection. Jin Yu, recognizing the Daoist, stepped forward to bow and thank him for his past rescue. The neighbors, unaware of the full story, gathered to question them, and the Daoist answered as he went along. Jin Yu then invited him to a tavern for wine. The two sat down, and the server brought them cups. They drank several rounds.

The Daoist turned to the tiger and said, *“Miss Guo, I kept you well in my grotto, intending to find this gentleman Jin to arrange your marriage—why did you don this tiger’s pelt and behave so recklessly? A young lady of your standing, transformed into such a beast—what becomes of your dignity?”* The tiger gazed at him with brimming tears, its body trembling violently. The Daoist understood it could not shed the pelt and was thus feigning distress.

Jin Yu addressed the Daoist, *“Master, I do not comprehend a word of what you say. Pray, enlighten me.”* The Daoist recounted the young lady’s history and the matter of the tiger’s skin in full. Jin Yu exclaimed, *“No wonder, when I shared my dwelling with this tiger, a woman of exquisite beauty came to my bed each night. Now, if you would but help her shed this fur, my gratitude would know no bounds.”*

The Daoist replied, *“I could remove it from my own body, but how am I to strip it from hers?”* After pondering a moment, he asked, *“Does the woman still come at night?”* Jin Yu answered, *“Not a night passes without her.”* The Daoist said, *“Then we must proceed thus.”* Jin Yu pressed, *“What is your plan, Master?”* The Daoist replied, *“Let us finish our wine and discuss it at your home.”*

The two drank several more cups before the Daoist rose. Jin Yu settled the bill, and they departed. Once home, the Daoist told Jin Yu, *“I shall teach you the incantation for shedding the pelt. When she arrives tonight, you must instruct her in it.”* That night, Jin Yu taught the young lady the incantation.

The next morning, a rattling sound arose from the tiger’s throat. With a roll upon the ground, the tiger pelt fell away. The young lady rose, straightened her robes and sash, and stood as a woman of beauty surpassing even Chang’e. Overcome with joy, Jin Yu smiled at her and said, *“Now you shall come every night—”*

She blushed but made no reply. The Daoist then urged Jin Yu to act as matchmaker for the couple, and they renewed their vows with fresh wedding rites. The Daoist, having secured the tiger pelt upon himself, recited the divine incantation, leapt through the gate, and vanished into the depths of the mountains.

Little did they know that misfortune was fated for those mountains. With this creature now among them, none—man, woman, young, or old—who crossed its path escaped being devoured. Within half a year, the mountain’s beasts and the village’s people were all consumed. As its hunger grew, it took on human and demonic guises, luring prey into its jaws with ever greater cunning. Truly:

*A tiger in the marketplace is no true tiger,
A man in the mountains is no true man.
The world’s upended fortunes arise
From the collapse of rightful judgment in the home.*

This thread shall be set aside for now.

Meanwhile, Master Guo the Immortal, still grieving the loss of his daughter to the tiger and the strange events in the Moon Palace, felt deep melancholy. Some days later, a letter arrived from the capital. He opened it to find that his former classmate, Zhang Cunshu, had been newly appointed Minister of Personnel. Knowing Guo’s mourning period had ended, Zhang had sent the letter to cordially invite him to the capital to assume a new post. Overjoyed, Guo wrote a reply, dispatched the messenger, and began preparing his luggage for the journey. Within a month, he arrived in the capital and called upon Minister Zhang.

After the formalities, Zhang said, *“My elder brother’s lofty retreat and joy in the clouds mark you as a dragon among men. I, in my humble role as Minister of Personnel, pale in comparison to the likes of Du and Zheng—truly, I am ashamed.”*

Guo the Immortal replied, *“Your Excellency’s rank is as high as the Northern Dipper, your talents as towering as the Central Terrace. In this era of peace and order, you are well-placed to record worthy names in the imperial archives. Your Excellency’s wisdom and magnanimity mirror the heavens, and your promotion of the able without regard to seniority—”*

Hearing these words, Zhang sensed Guo’s willingness to return to office and said, *“Your esteemed name has long rested in my records. That is why I sent for you—”*

Guo feigned modesty before taking his leave. The next day, he returned the visit, and they discussed his appointment. The imperial decree soon arrived, and the Ministry of Personnel confirmed his post as Prefect of Fuzhou. Guo bade farewell to Minister Zhang and departed the capital. His journey home was uneventful, and upon arrival, he made preparations for his new office. Choosing an auspicious day, he set out for his post and arrived within a month.

After offering incense and opening the yamen to receive petitions, we shall set aside the account of Guo the Immortal’s governance—pure as flowing water—and turn instead to his son, Guo Zongxian. After a year in office, Guo had sent his son home to prepare for the imperial examinations. The young master returned to the prefecture after passing the preliminary trials and was en route back when, passing through Chuzhou, he encountered dark clouds gathering and thunder crashing. Unable to proceed, he said to his steward, *“The wind and rain rage together—let us take shelter in this temple.”*

Entering the temple gates, he looked up to see it was dedicated to the Great Exorcist Emperor. Guo bowed four times and sat upon the prayer mat, waiting for the rain to cease. But the storm only worsened, continuing unabated until dusk. He asked his steward, *“How far is the nearest inn?”*

*“Over ten li,”* the steward replied.

*“We shall have to stay here for the night,”* Guo said. He instructed the temple keeper to prepare the evening meal. After eating, they settled in for the night.

By the second watch of the night, Guo saw before the hall a glimmer of golden blades and the glint of iron armor. A majestic deity stood beside him and said, *“Guo Zongxian, heed my words:*
*At the filial widow’s weeping grave,*
*Three thousand arrows must be smeared with dog and boar blood at Xu and Hai.*
*To learn the cause of the luminous pearl’s fate,*
*Watch for the message where water meets the flying fowl.”*

With that, the young master awoke with a start, exclaiming, *“How strange, how strange!”* His steward, now awake as well, said, *“Just now I clearly heard Lord Guan recite a quatrain to you, though its meaning is far from clear.”* The steward replied, *“I too heard something in my sleep, but not a single word remains in my memory.”* Guo then recited the lines one by one. *“Exactly so, exactly so,”* the steward confirmed.

Guo pondered the verses for some time, unaware that dawn had already broken. After eating breakfast and thanking the temple keeper, they set out. Along the way, Guo mused, *“‘Arrows smeared with Xu and Hai’—surely that means coating them in the blood of pigs and dogs. But ‘the filial widow’s weeping grave’—could it mean shooting arrows at a dutiful woman?”* He then thought, *“‘To learn the cause of the luminous pearl’s fate’—‘luminous pearl’ must refer to a jewel. Ah! How strange—my younger sister’s name is Pearl, and she was devoured by a tiger. Could this place hold the key to her fate?”* The last line, however, remained beyond his understanding.

Still lost in thought, he realized they had already arrived at the inn’s gate.

The party dismounted. At midday, a group of hunters rushed past the inn’s gate. Guo asked the innkeeper, *“Who are these people, and why are they in such a hurry?”* The innkeeper replied, *“They’re all hunters. That tiger must have appeared again up ahead—they’ve gone to drive it off.”* Guo asked, *“Why would a tiger venture into a town?”* The innkeeper said, *“Sir, it’s a long story. This tiger is fearsome—it can take the form of man or ghost, and it’s devoured everyone in the mountains. Now it’s starting to prey on those in the town. The other day, our neighbor Wang Xiao’er was gathering firewood at the foot of the mountain when he came upon a child weeping. Thinking the boy had lost his way, he tried to lead him home. But after no more than a few steps, the child spun around, leapt, and transformed into a tiger, dragging Xiao’er off to eat him. The villagers gave chase, but it vanished without a trace. Later, a woman came running in terror, wailing, ‘My son Xiao’er was carried off by a tiger!’ She wept and wailed, searching for his bones and asking after him. Before anyone could answer, the woman herself turned into a tiger and seized two men in its jaws. The crowd scattered in panic. Now every household is on edge, and no one dares let down their guard. Even as you sit here speaking with me, sir—who’s to say you’re not the tiger in disguise? These days, we’re all wary of strangers.”*

Guo listened and thought to himself, *“The verses from the deity in my dream were clearly instructing me to rid this place of this ancient scourge.”* He said nothing of this but told his steward, *“We’ll stay here for a day or two before moving on.”* He then sent the steward into town to purchase bows and arrows, while he asked the innkeeper to procure pig and dog blood to coat the arrows. He fashioned thousands of blowpipes, filling them with the blood, and strapped a waist knife to himself. His servants carried the blowpipes and bows as they entered the mountains.

There, they came upon an old grave overgrown with ancient trees and creeping moss. On the offering stone lay three or five bowls of food, and beside the grave sat a woman of about twenty, dressed in mourning, weeping bitterly to heaven and earth. Guo thought, *“This woman is tending a grave, yet there are no incense sticks or paper money.”* As he drew nearer, he saw that the bowls contained dried venison and gibbon stew. Recalling the innkeeper’s words from the day before, he signaled his servants to make ready.

The woman, seeing Guo approach, rose and bowed to him. He returned her greeting.

The woman said, “I am most unfortunate, having lost my husband early. Before his death, he left me these words: *‘After I am gone, if on the day you sweep my grave you should meet a young man, offer yourself to him in marriage.’* Today, I am fortunate to have met you, a noble gentleman, and your presence matches my late husband’s words. I invite you to my humble home, that we may be joined as husband and wife.”

Guo replied, “This is preposterous! How can we arrange such a matter here in these wild mountains?” The woman stepped closer, her lips moving and tongue flicking, her form beginning to twist into that of a tiger. Guo hastily ordered his servants to loose their arrows. They fired the blood-tipped blowpipes in a flurry, and the woman was struck by seven arrows, her body streaming with foul blood as she leapt wildly into the air. The tiger’s pelt slipped from her, but she could not fully shed her human guise. Guo commanded his steward to bind her with ropes, then took the tiger skin and carried it to the market. The crowd gathered like ants, and the townsfolk pressed their hands to their foreheads in gratitude, thanking Guo for ridding them of this evil beast.

Guo said, “This demon cannot be left for even a moment. Quickly, take her into the city and deliver her to the authorities for punishment.” The men, weary and hungry, said, “Let us first stop at the inn to eat and drink before we go.” Guo entered the inn and took the seat of honor. The waiter set out dishes, and after the meal, the men settled the bill. Just then, a woman inside the inn, hearing the commotion outside, lifted the curtain and poked her head out to look. She and Guo locked eyes, and she quickly withdrew. A servant exclaimed, “Sir, that is the young lady—how has she come to be here?”

Guo said, “She does resemble her, but it may only be a coincidence.” The woman then stepped forward and cried, “Oh, brother! Why are you here?” Guo looked closely and saw that it was indeed—

*[Text ends here]*

**Book Four, Case Four: The Woodcutter’s Encounter Leads to Reunion**

Guo, accompanied by his retinue, wrote a formal report and sent a servant to present it to the prefect. The prefect ascended the hall, subjected the woman to severe torture, and extracted a full confession. Without delay, she was taken to the crossroads and beheaded as a public warning. The tiger skin was awarded to Guo as a token of honor. He then dispatched a servant to the inn to settle the bill and gather their belongings, before setting off with Miss Pearl toward his post in Fuzhou. *[The rest is omitted.]*

Meanwhile, Xiao Daoyan sat upon Iron-Beak Crag when suddenly his body was wracked with excruciating pain, as though scalding oil poured upon his crown. With a great cry, he opened his eyes to find himself surrounded by grass grown three feet deep. Xiao Daoyan thought, “A moment’s wayward thought summoned the demonic, and unknowing, I sat with eyes closed, committing two years of transgressions. Reflecting on all that came before and after, I am struck with dread. Could this have been but a dream of my soul—did I truly bring harm to the living?” He descended to villages and towns, questioning every passerby, tracing the path of his visions, and found all to match his dream in every detail. Returning to the mountain, remorse weighed heavily upon his heart: “Having harmed thousands of living beings, how can I attain true fruition? Below this Iron-Beak Crag lies an abyss of ten thousand fathoms—let me cast myself into it, shattering body and bone to atone before Heaven.” With that, he leapt. Yet midair, a wisp of white cloud bore him aloft, and he ascended in broad daylight. Only then did Xiao Daoyan realize that those mauled by the tiger had met their destined end: “Heaven merely borrowed my form to bring their fates to pass—it had naught to do with me.” Free and at ease, he departed.

Later, that tiger skin would bring about the reunion of a golden couple, but that is another tale.

As for Miss Pearl, thanks to the Daoist who had stripped the tiger skin from her, she and Jin Yu were wed. Though Jin Yu had savings, they earned no interest, and day by day their wealth dwindled. Thus, they opened a tavern before their home. One day, Jin Yu went to collect debts outside the city and returned at dusk to find Miss Pearl gone. Questioning the neighbors, he learned that her elder brother had taken her away. Jin Yu thought, “She once told me her father was a prefect and her brother a scholar. If only I knew where they had taken her, where could I even begin to search? We were wed without matchmaker or betrothal gifts—even if I found them, what could they return to me? Perhaps Miss Pearl will not forget my kindness, and we may meet again someday.” He wept day and night, but of this, no more need be said.

Meanwhile, Master Guo Zongxian, having captured the tiger demon, recovered his sister, and obtained the tiger skin—three strokes of unexpected fortune—set off for home with his retinue. Along the way, he pondered the depth of Lord Guan’s verse, its meaning only revealed in hindsight. The final line, *water’s edge, a chicken flies*, hinted at the character for “wine,” and indeed, his sister had been found in a tavern. The prophecy’s precision filled him with joy. Only Miss Pearl grew dismayed, for she had assumed her parents lived nearby and that she would reunite with them briefly before returning home. Yet after ten days of travel, they still had not dismounted. “Had I known the parting would be so distant,” she lamented, “I would have at least bid my husband farewell and secured our trunks.” Lost in hesitation, she scarcely noticed their arrival at the prefectural gate. Guo entered the yamen with his sister, and their parents, overcome with grief and joy, embraced their daughter. Miss Pearl recounted her encounter with the tiger in the Moon Palace, while Guo described the scheme by which he had captured the beast. Their parents marveled at the tale.

Now, there was a censor of the Ministry of Justice named Zhu Jinchen, whose wife, née Tao, had passed her fiftieth year. They had two sons and a daughter: the elder son, Zhu Yu; the younger, Zhu Jue. When Zhu Jinchen had first been appointed, he was assigned to serve as a judicial commissioner in Qingzhou. En route with his family, they were scattered by bandits, and Zhu Yu’s whereabouts became unknown. At the time, Zhu Jue was of marriageable age, and Magistrate Guo had betrothed Miss Pearl to him. The six rites were complete, the three matchmakers had done their work, and only the wedding date remained to be set. Then, a man and his wife approached, saying, “If... then how could I...?” Miss Pearl had pleaded with her parents repeatedly... and at last devised a plan to extricate herself from the predicament.

---

One evening, Miss Pearl feigned a sharp pain in her heart, crying out incessantly. Her mother, alarmed, asked what ailed her. She replied, “This is the old affliction from my time as a tiger—it will only cease if I cover myself with the tiger skin.” Her mother immediately draped the skin over her, and Miss Pearl’s cries of pain subsided. From then on, she kept the skin with her at all times.

When the wedding day arrived and the bridal sedan had come, Miss Pearl dressed herself in full finery. Her mother placed the tiger skin inside the sedan as a cushion. Miss Pearl stepped into the sedan, and Magistrate Guo saw her off as she was carried to the Zhu residence. Once there, she donned the tiger skin and recited the divine incantation. Just as the master of ceremonies began the rites and the guests lifted the sedan curtain, Miss Pearl leapt out in a bound, transforming into a tiger with several great strides before vanishing through the main gate. The guests scattered in terror, exclaiming in astonishment. Magistrate Guo, beside himself with rage, could only stare blankly at the others. Unwilling to reveal the truth, he followed their lead in feigning bewilderment, calling off the feast and ordering his sedan to return to the yamen. The guests dared not press him to stay and took their leave.

Zhu Jinchen fumed, “This is clearly Magistrate Guo deceiving me! I must draft a memorial to impeach him and vent my anger.” The guests replied, “One can feign many things, but how could one feign a tiger?” Zhu pondered this and, finding no recourse, let the matter drop.

Meanwhile, Miss Pearl, having escaped the Zhu residence, leapt over the city wall and fled with the speed of the wind. Within days, she arrived in Chuzhou. There, she shed the tiger skin and returned to her own doorstep. Jin Yu, seeing her from the shop, rushed out to greet her with unbounded joy. Once inside, Miss Pearl recounted all that had transpired. Jin Yu said, “Your devotion is most rare, my lady. But I am a man of humble station—how can I be worthy of the daughter of a prefectural governor?” Miss Pearl replied, “Since we pledged our lives to each other, what matter high or low?” Truly, there is no joy like returning home after a long absence. That night, their happiness need not be described.

As for Magistrate Guo, upon returning from the ill-fated wedding, he was nearly driven to his death by fury. His wife, seeing their daughter once more transformed into a tiger and gone, wept inconsolably. Their son said, “Do not grieve, my parents. It would be best to send the whole household to Chuzhou to inquire at the wine shop. Perhaps she, unwilling to remarry, has returned to her original husband—who can say?” They immediately dispatched a servant, who traveled without incident until he reached the wine shop. There, he asked the owner about Miss Pearl. Hearing this, she emerged from within and summoned the servant inside. She inquired after her parents’ well-being and all that had occurred since their parting, and the servant dutifully recounted everything. Miss Pearl then ordered the kitchen to prepare a meal for him, and the next day, she sent him home.

Upon his return, the servant reported all that had transpired. Magistrate Guo, left with no other choice, conferred with his wife and decided to send their son with servants to bring their daughter home, that their family might be reunited and she might be spared the hardships of poverty. His wife was overjoyed, and they summoned Guo Zongxian to inform him of the plan. The young master set out at once. Upon arriving at Jin Yu’s home, he was received by his sister, and Jin Yu came to greet his brother-in-law with every courtesy—needless to say.

The next day, Guo Zongxian relayed his parents’ wishes to the couple. Jin Yu promptly settled the affairs of the wine shop, forgoing all debts, packed their belongings, and hired porters and horses for the journey. Their departure need not be recounted here.

Meanwhile, Zhu Jinchen, having learned of Miss Pearl’s origins, prepared to welcome her home within days. He dispatched many servants and attendants to intercept her along the way. Sure enough, as Guo Zongxian’s procession returned with their carriages and horses, Zhu’s steward blocked their path and seized Jin Yu and Miss Pearl, carrying them away. The young master and his retinue gave chase, following them all the way to Zhu Jinchen’s gate, where they saw the two being taken inside. Guo Zongxian, at a loss, hurried home to report what had happened.

Magistrate Guo said, “Do not panic. If your sister submits to him, then so be it.”

Should she refuse, he will revert to his tiger form and flee—then we may demand our people back from him and see how he answers!" With their plan settled, no more was said of the matter.

Meanwhile, the servants had already concealed Miss Pearl in a bedchamber and written a calling card, sending Jin Yu to the county yamen with orders for the magistrate to execute him at once. The servants brought Jin Yu before the magistrate, who ascended the bench and received the card. After hearing the account, the magistrate summoned Jin Yu and asked, "Are you called Jin Yu?"

Jin Yu replied, "This humble one was originally named Zhu Yu. I recall my father’s name was Zhu Jinchen. He was once appointed judicial commissioner of Qingzhou Prefecture. When my family traveled to assume his post, we were set upon by bandits. It was night, and everyone fled in panic. I became lost in the region of Yanzhou Prefecture, where a family named Jin took me in and raised me—hence my name, Jin Yu."

The magistrate asked, "How old were you then?"

"Six years old. I am now twenty-three."

The magistrate found his story perplexing and thought, *"This old Zhu is causing trouble again—demanding I take the life of his own son!"* He summoned the steward and inquired further. To the steward, he said, "Seventeen years ago, did your master encounter bandits?"

The steward pondered a moment before replying, "Yes. Seventeen years ago, my master was appointed judicial commissioner of Qingzhou. While traveling with his family to Zhejiang’s Yanzhou Prefecture, our eldest young master disappeared. We assumed he had fallen into the river and drowned."

The magistrate pointed to Jin Yu. "Do you recognize this man?"

The steward rubbed his eyes and studied him closely. The face bore a resemblance. He cried out, "Could this be our young master Zhu?"

Jin Yu also recognized the steward as Zhu En and exclaimed in surprise. Zhu En rushed forward and embraced him. The magistrate then ordered the steward to take Jin Yu home to his father.

Zhu En returned with Jin Yu—*(text missing)*—long-lost kin, separated by fate, for which none could be blamed. Only the sacred verses of the Demon-Quelling Emperor had foretold all that came to pass.

Before the words were finished, the moon had crossed the western gallery, and dawn broke in the east. The feast dispersed. Truly:

*What once was a tale of demonic woe,*
*Now blooms as a bond of joyful matrimony.*

Thereafter, Zhu Yu and his two brothers engaged a tutor and studied diligently, ultimately becoming men of renown. They passed the imperial examinations and ascended to official ranks, serving in the Bureau of Appointments. Pearl was ennobled as a First-Rank Lady, while Guo Zongxian and Zhu Juan also passed the provincial examinations and entered public service. Both families were blessed with descendants for generations, their official stars shining brightly.

As for the tiger pelt, the young lady cherished it like Pearl herself, regarding it as a treasure for protection. Yet after being stored away for three years, when retrieved, it resembled a mangy dog—its hide and fur split apart. Truly a priceless gem turned worthless, not even a single coin’s value, becoming a laughingstock for later generations. Indeed:

*To see the strange and not be strange,*
*The strange will of itself decay.*

Earlier, a tale was told of the unrighteousness of Heaven’s Dao; later, another of the unrighteousness of the ruler’s Dao. This chronicle, however, recounts a story of the unrighteousness of human Dao giving rise to strange occurrences within a household.

Had Pearl’s parents regarded their daughter with ordinary affection, she might have lived in obscurity. Why, then, was she likened to Chang’e, building a vast Moon Palace deep in the mountains, only to encounter a sorcerous rogue, ensnared in his web? Fortunately, after years of hardship, she did not fall into the hands of wicked men. This, too, was predestined by the threads of fate, destined to reunite in a most wondrous way.

The union came about by chance, yet was wondrously preordained. This telling may seem too far-fetched—Su Dongpo once said: *"Let it be spoken idly, let it be heard idly."* So be it.

**Chapter One, Volume Five: The Fisherman Dwelling by the River**

*Verse:*
A bee’s sting may yet be cured with medicine,
But a woman’s jealousy knows no remedy.
Since ancient times, how many bearded men
Have bowed low before the curtains, humbled by silken sashes?

Among the mindless creatures of heaven and earth, even those harboring venom strike only when provoked, relying on claws and fangs to defend themselves—this is their nature, not malice. Yet a woman’s heart is a realm of divine transformation, ever more cunning, concealing filth where none would think to look, inflicting the cruelest harm. This is deliberate malice—how could its venom not surpass that of vipers and scorpions?

These words come from one who has suffered great injustice at a woman’s hands, venting the grievance of a wrong unredressed. For women are by nature yin and yielding: yin restrains yang, softness overcomes hardness. Thus even the most unyielding of men find their edge dulled before a woman, their brows meekly lowered. A wise woman, encountering such a man, responds with humility and courtesy, exceeding all caution. When both adjust like water to vessel, their harmony is perfect—this is a woman of virtue.

But an unworthy woman feigns airs, plays the coquette, and indulges her whims. The slightest dissatisfaction sends her into fits—refusing food and drink, raging day and night. She must have the last word, the final logic, and even then, she seeks parting verses, compares him to some distant fool, only then falling silent.

There was once a woman who, disdaining her husband’s poverty, turned her heart elsewhere and sang a different tune. The phoenix crown inlaid with eight treasures, the cloud-patterned robe woven in five colors—finery she wore with ease—she cast aside without a thought. What a pity!

This was none other than Cui, wife of Zhu Maichen of Burnt Axe Mountain, who despised her husband’s poverty and his livelihood of selling firewood. At forty-nine, her patience worn thin, she took up another’s lute, seeking mere warmth and fullness. Such is the fickleness of women, their hearts as shifting as willow catkins, lacking steadfastness. Yet it was also the fault of a household without discipline, allowing a meddling nun to sow discord and breed this calamity.

Some say: *"This woman was born under the Iron Broomstar—had she not left, Zhu Maichen would have remained impoverished forever, with no hope of prosperity."* Though such is the talk of men, the true principle is to endure hardship with one’s husband.

These old tales need not be retold.

Now let us speak of a woman most venomous—one who deceived the eyes of all, secretly conspired with monks, and brought about her husband’s death, only to meet a fate far more wretched than that of Cui. Her wickedness was twice as great.

This tale unfolds in the Zhide era of the Yuan dynasty, in Fushun County, Sichuan. There lived a scholar named Zhang Yong. His father, Zhang Lü, had been a man of considerable wealth, but both parents passed early, and the young man neglected all livelihood. For years he lived idly off his inheritance until his fortune was squandered. His wife, née Liu, styled Chunniang, was a woman of humble birth—fiercely cruel, diligent only in eating and sloth. Zhang Yong, lured by her modest dowry, and her father, drawn by his scholar’s status, sealed the match. Yet within a month of marriage, discord arose—though we need not dwell on such trifles.

At the time, the land had only just begun to recover from the chaos of the *jie ding* uprisings, when suddenly famine struck. What a dire season it was!

Silkworms reared, fields must still be sown—
No rest for young or old, the whole household worn.
Then came the plum rains, day after day,
And all the level plains stretched bleak and gray.

The deluge was fiercer than the floods of primordial times. The Dragon Gate’s waterfall became a plain; hills and mounds turned to yawning chasms. For two full months the waters raged before the skies cleared. Yet even then, the millet was lost, the floods unyielding—farmers craned their necks in despair, helpless to act. Only by early autumn did the waters recede.

Fearing tax shortages, the county magistrate toured the countryside to urge the people to till the land. Households toiled with all their might, reclaiming eight or nine parts of the drowned fields. As the shoots lengthened and greened, the farmers rejoiced, their hopes rising. But Heaven, it seemed, was bent on disaster, and the people’s fate was sealed. When they needed rain, the skies poured; when they needed sun, the heavens withheld it. So it went at summer’s end and autumn’s dawn—jewels and pearls of rain, they called it. The ditches and gullies might have drawn moisture from the rivers, but instead, the land grew parched. Bamboo leaves and banana fronds turned ashen; fish scales in the streams exhaled a ghostly mist. By then, there was no water to draw, and the fields cracked under the sun. Dragonflies swarmed, and all hope of harvest faded.

In such times, the rich hoarded grain, while the poor wailed in despair. Truly:

At home, the cauldrons gathered dust, and the hearths stood cold, their smoke long since vanished. Cries of despair filled the roads, sighs echoing through every lane. This was the work of a malevolent sun, the blight of the drought demon—half the fields drowned in floods, the rest withered by drought. Grass roots and tree bark became treasures, while a single drop of water from the ditches was as precious as nectar. The people starved until smoke seemed to rise from their mouths, their faces sallow as withered greens.

The local officials submitted reports of the famine, and the emperor, well aware of the people’s plight, read the memorial with a heavy heart. He ordered grain distributed to relieve the starving. All officials, whether in office or retired, were ranked by grade and required to donate a portion of their salaries to the relief effort.

But let us turn from the emperor’s benevolence to Zhang Yong and his wife, who faced this famine in dire straits. Liu Chunniang spent her days in a frenzy, demanding wine and food regardless of whether there was any to be had. If her wants went unmet, she would wail and weep, her tantrums unending. One day, Chunniang was quarreling with her husband, insisting he find some profitable trade. Zhang Yong was a scholar—unable to bear even light burdens, let alone heavy ones—what business could he possibly manage? Their argument escalated until blows were exchanged.

Just then, an old man passed by their door. Seeing the couple fighting, he stepped inside to mediate. This old man was none other than their former neighbor from three years past, who had since moved to the riverside after his business failed, now making a living as a fisherman. He had only one child, a daughter of twelve or thirteen. Honest and sincere, he was known to all as Yang Laoshi. Seeing the couple’s bitter quarrel, he entered out of lingering affection for their past friendship and tried to calm them.

This intervention would set in motion a chain of events:
The monkey’s death in Chu doomed the forest,
The city gate’s fire scorched the pond’s fish.
A disaster would unfold, nearly sending one soul to the Yellow Springs, leaving the west wind to bear its regret.

But that is a tale for later.

Now, Yang Laoshi stepped inside to find the couple no longer locked in blows but seated, tallying grievances one by one, their sobs unceasing. At the sight of him, they turned like plaintiff and defendant before the magistrate—each hurling accusations, pouring out grievances—until Yang Laoshi’s ears could bear no more. Breaking in, he counseled, “Good wife, in these lean years when livelihoods are hard-won, you and your husband ought not quarrel but discuss matters calmly and seek some trade. Even a pint or half-pint of rice in the pot will see you through. As the old saying goes, ‘After famine comes plenty.’ These days, even scholars turn their hands to business—nothing strange in that.”

Yang Laoshi’s advice to seek work struck precisely the mark with Liu Chuniang, who brightened at once. “Uncle Yang, Auntie Yang—you elders speak sense! As the saying goes, ‘A thousand strings at home are not so good as a daily penny earned.’ Better to bring in a little to feed the family than sit idle at home, staring at each other’s faces like this. What sort of life is that?” Zhang Yong, hearing Yang Laoshi also urge him toward trade, began to entertain the notion, though as a man of letters, he hesitated over what sort of work would suit him. Instead of voicing his own doubts, he turned the question to Yang Laoshi: “How has business been for you lately?”

“Fairly good,” Yang replied, “but with no one to help, an old man like me feels lonely by the river.” Chuniang seized the opening: “If you’re alone, why not let my husband assist you? Would you agree, Uncle?” Yang demurred, “That would be fine, but can your husband bear such hardship?” Chuniang sighed, “What choice do we have? The dawn’s first light brings only the clatter of an empty basket—where is the coin to be found? If we could catch a few fish to sell, it might ease these bitter days.” Yang hesitated, “Though you speak so, I cannot answer without knowing your husband’s thoughts.”

Zhang Yong thought to himself, *"If I refuse my wife’s earnest plea, she will surely unleash her thunderous wrath. Better to agree for now and find another solution later."* Turning to Yang Laoshi, he said, “That will do.”

Seeing her husband consent, Liu Chuniang’s face lit up with joy. She bustled inside to brew tea for Yang Laoshi. Zhang Yong and Laoshi exchanged pleasantries and caught up on recent news. Soon, the tea arrived, and the two men shared a cup before agreeing to choose an auspicious day to start their work by the river. All three parted in high spirits, bidding each other farewell with cheerful words.

Now, as for Liu Chuniang—when she was young and still in her parents’ home, her father, Old Liu, was already past fifty and had struggled to have a son. His only child was this daughter. By the time she reached ten, her parents’ love for her was extraordinary. Their family was quite wealthy, and they cherished her as if she were a luminous pearl or a jade of priceless worth. They never scolded her, not even a word, nor did they ever lay a hand on her. Whatever she desired—wind or rain, fine food or fine clothes—was hers. Even the daughters of humble families could not compare to her, let alone the sons of nobles.

One day, as Old Liu held her on his lap, stroking her affectionately, he sighed and said, *"What a pity she is a girl. If she were a son, our family line would continue, and in the future, there would be someone to stand by my coffin and weep, or to make a show of mourning at my grave. But a daughter belongs to another family—raising her is ultimately in vain."* As he spoke, a few tears of sorrow fell.

Just then, a vegetable vendor from across the street entered. That morning, he had weighed out his greens for Old Liu but had not yet been paid. Now, in the afternoon, he returned with his thirteen-year-old son to collect the money. As they stepped inside, they saw Old Liu cradling his daughter, tears in his eyes. Unsure of the reason, father and son stood silently at the door, watching.

Old Liu was the first to speak. “What do you need?”

The vendor replied, “Master Liu, we’ve come for the money from this morning’s vegetables.”

Old Liu quickly called his daughter inside and asked her mother for some copper coins to pay the man. Chuniang hurried in, but in her haste, a golden earpick fell from her hair. Old Liu did not notice, but the young boy was quick-witted. He promptly picked it up and handed it to Old Liu.

Old Liu was startled. “This earpick belongs to my daughter—how did it end up in your hand?”

The boy answered, “It fell from her head just now as she went inside.”

Old Liu took the earpick and studied the boy’s face closely. His features were refined—clear brows, bright eyes, white teeth, and rosy lips. The only flaw was his tattered clothing; if he were dressed in finer garments, no one would have guessed he was the son of a vegetable vendor.

Old Liu asked the vendor, “Is this your son?”

“Yes,” the man replied.

Old Liu asked, “How old is he this year? What is his name?”

The vegetable vendor replied, “He is thirteen this year, and his name is Wunan.”

Old Liu asked, “Why was he given such a name?”

The vendor answered, “When he was small, a fortune-teller said he would face many hardships, so we named him thus. If he were adopted by another family, he might avoid them.”

Old Liu, seeing the boy’s refined features and having just returned the golden earpick, felt nine parts out of ten of fondness for him. He asked, “If you were to have him adopted, what kind of family would you prefer?”

The vendor said, “Adoption is best with a childless family. If they already have a son, the adopted child would be treated half as a son and half as a servant—carrying books, holding umbrellas, enduring scoldings and beatings, and never valued. But if the family has no son, adopting him to continue the ancestral line, they would naturally cherish and care for him. They would send him to school in his youth, arrange his marriage when he grows up, and ensure he learns a trade to secure his future.”

Old Liu said, “For example, a family like ours—would you trust us?”

The vendor exclaimed, “Oh! How could we ever aspire to the honor of your esteemed household, Master Liu?”

Old Liu replied, “That is not what I mean. When arranging marriages, one considers whether families are well-matched in status, but for adoption, all that matters is whether the child appears capable of growth, and whether the adoptive father is honest and dependable. Wealth or poverty does not matter—it can still be settled.”

The vendor said, “Your household is certainly suitable, Master Liu. I only fear my son is not fortunate enough.”

Old Liu said, “You need not be so modest. If you are truly willing, tomorrow is the fourteenth, and the day after, I will visit Blind Li at the east end to divine a reading. We can finalize it then.”

Overjoyed at Old Liu’s words, the vendor dared not refuse and immediately said, “Master Liu, it is settled.”

Both families had made up their minds, awaiting the judgment of the gods to confirm the outcome. Chunniang, who had been standing nearby with the copper coins for some time, only handed them over once their conversation ended. The vendor took the coins, expressed his thanks, and left.

Old Liu placed the earpick back into Chunniang’s hair, then went inside with her to tell their mother about the matter. Old Mrs. Liu was overjoyed upon hearing the news, but no more of that need be said.

As for the vegetable vendor, he was none other than the younger brother of Blind Li the diviner—Li San. Li San was eager to have his son adopted by the Liu family but feared an unfavorable divination might ruin such a fine opportunity, which was hard to come by. The next morning, he hurried to inform Blind Li, explaining in detail Old Liu’s intention to adopt a son. He instructed, “If he comes to ask for a divination, do everything you can to ensure it goes well. Once my son is adopted, I will repay you generously in time.”

Blind Li replied, “That will be no trouble at all.”

Now, on the fifteenth day, Old Liu fasted, bathed, and took his divination fee to Blind Li’s divination shop to seek a reading. Once the formalities were complete, the blind man took up the divination tube, shook it several times, and drew out the hexagram—*Shi He* (䷫), a single yin line meeting five yang lines. According to the *Book of Changes*, this signified: “*Shi* means encounter; one yin meeting five yang suggests a woman’s virtue is not chaste.” Such was its omen, generally inauspicious for the matter at hand.

Yet Blind Li, having received his brother’s earlier entreaty, told Old Liu: “*Shi* means encounter. The character *shi* (䷫) combines *nü* (女, woman) with *hou* (后, behind), foretelling great fortune ahead—an encounter with good people.” Old Liu, now convinced, paid the divination fee, bowed in thanks, and returned home. There, he discussed the matter with Old Mrs. Liu, and after settling on an auspicious date, they proceeded to adopt a son.

Li San made all the necessary preparations, enlisting an elderly neighbor as a witness, and brought his son to the Liu household. Upon entering, the boy first paid respects at the family altar and ancestral shrine, then bowed to his adoptive parents. Even Chunniang, as his sister, exchanged formal greetings with him. A feast was laid out, and all parted in high spirits.

From then on, the family had new clothes made for him. On a day deemed joyful, they sent him to school to study, giving him the name Liu Zhangtai. Having known hardship before, he now embraced his good fortune, devoting himself wholeheartedly to his new life. He treated his parents and sister with utmost respect, and all were pleased. The bond between brother and sister grew especially close. His parents cherished him as if he were their own flesh and blood, seating him at the same table, walking beside him, and showing no distinction in their affection.

In the *Nei Ze* chapter, it is written: when a boy reaches seven, he must no longer share a seat or meals with girls; after eight or nine, upon turning ten, he is to leave home for his tutor and reside outside. Know that the words in books always hold profound reason. Yet how many households today understand this principle? Carelessly and without discernment, they conceal countless transgressions and let many slip through unnoticed. Even when parents become aware, they dismiss it as a family disgrace not to be aired, and so they cover it up.

From the moment one is born, is there anything not first seen with one’s own eyes before it is understood? Is there any matter not first spoken of by others before it is grasped? Yet the stirrings of youthful desire are different. Young imps, though untaught, somehow grasp its subtle intricacies. Chunniang was now ten—an age of knowing and yet not knowing. Unavoidably, she would listen at the bedside to her parents’ intimacies, finding them intriguing, assuming such things were common knowledge and permissible for all. Within less than a year, she and Zhangtai began exchanging sly glances, their eyes speaking volumes. At first, they remained close in their parents’ presence, but gradually, their boldness grew. With mutual understanding, they sought out secluded spots, where their trysts became as effortless as reaching into a pocket for a trinket.

Their parents, noticing their absence, would merely call them back without suspicion. Unaware, they allowed the two to carry on, until at last, the pair began engaging in acts as intimate as grinding navels to share breath.

One day, Mother Liu sewed a white silk skirt for Chunniang, and no sooner had she put it on than she and Zhangtai slipped away to the rear garden to amuse themselves. They did not return until two full watches had passed. Their mother scolded them a few times, then let the matter drop. After the evening meal, the family retired to their rooms. As Chunniang approached the bed and began to remove her skirt, Mother Liu took it from her to fold. But in the lamplight, she was truly startled by what she saw:

Dots like rouge freshly dyed,
Scattered as peach and apricot blossoms adorned.
The young scholar’s greedy heart,
The fair maiden’s tender shyness—
In one morning’s chaos,
Powder faded, fragrance vanished.
Clearly, the fragrant bud had been crushed,
Its jade-like petals bruised by dew.

Mother Liu, bewildered by the stains on the skirt, grew flustered. The truth of the matter would soon be revealed.

**Book Five, Second Tale: The Alluring Seductress Embraces the Monk**

Mother Liu questioned Chunniang, “Daughter, have you developed sores or boils down there? Why didn’t you tell your mother?”

Chunniang replied, “No, I haven’t.”

Mother Liu called her daughter to the lamplight, pulled open the skirt, and demanded, “Then what is *this*?”

Chunniang looked and saw:

Peach blossoms on the verge of fading,
Seeming to drift onto her cheeks;
Fresh buds just unfurling,
Gradually blooming upon her face.
Her moth-like brows knit in distress,
Her whole body as if seated on pins and needles;
Her phoenix eyes dazed and lost,
Her heart fluttering like a startled fawn.
Her complexion unsettled,
Her words hesitant and vague.
Her face resembled a fruit vendor’s stall—
Patches of green, clusters of purple—
Yet she could not utter a single word in reply.

Mother Liu, at that moment, felt like an earthworm in the field, her belly filled with mud. She thought, *“Has my daughter’s maidenhead been taken? If not, where did this bloody stain on the skirt come from?”*

By then, Zhangtai had heard every word clearly but feigned sleep, remaining silent. Mother and daughter fussed and chattered, then finally went to bed.

That night, Mother Liu pondered the matter carefully, never suspecting Zhangtai. The next morning, after Zhangtai had left for school, she barred the door, took up a thick piece of firewood, and made Chunniang kneel before her for questioning. Chunniang, believing such matters were permissible, saw no harm in confessing and recounted everything without hesitation.

Upon hearing this, Mother Liu was so enraged she nearly died. Instead of beating her daughter, she collapsed to the ground, wailing and weeping uncontrollably. Just then, Old Man Liu returned, only to find the door shut and his wife sobbing inside. He hurriedly called for it to be opened and asked what had happened. Mother Liu told him of their daughter’s scandalous affair.

Old Man Liu, upon hearing this, stormed to the school, dragged Zhangtai back, and was about to beat the wretched boy to death. Mother Liu intervened, “Wait! Spare him this once.” She pulled her husband aside and whispered, *“Don’t beat him too harshly. If he flees in fear, we’ll only suffer the stench of the Li family’s disgrace. If the neighbors find out, the truth will spread—what face will we have left? Remember: household shame must not be aired.”*

"All this stems from our own lack of vigilance—we cannot blame him alone. Let us wait a few more days, find some pretext, and send him back." Old Man Liu followed her advice and allowed Zhangtai to return to his studies as before.

Now, Zhangtai knew the affair had been discovered, but after the storm of fury passed, he dismissed it from his mind. Old Man Liu, however, sought a way to provoke him. Yet Zhangtai was dutiful and respectful to his mother, leaving no fault to exploit. Thus, Old Man Liu devised a plan and consulted Mother Liu, saying, *"Do this and this."* She replied, *"That makes sense."*

Old Man Liu hurried out and summoned a fortune-teller, secretly giving him several coins of silver to follow the plan. As soon as the man entered, Old Man Liu deliberately had Zhangtai stand before him to listen. The fortune-teller first arranged Old Man Liu’s four pillars of destiny and read his fate. Then he calculated Mother Liu’s eight characters. Finally, he asked for Zhangtai’s year, month, and day of birth.

After casting Zhangtai’s fate, the fortune-teller thought, *"These few coins are easily earned. This destiny is one of utter ruin—doomed to punishment and crime."* He slapped the table and sighed, *"What a wretched fate! What a wretched fate!"*

Old Man Liu feigned alarm, though his heart secretly rejoiced. He asked, *"Why do you sigh, Master?"* The fortune-teller replied, *"Who is this young man?"* Old Man Liu said, *"My own son."* The fortune-teller said, *"Forgive my bluntness—I speak only what the calculations reveal, without concealment."* Old Man Liu said, *"A gentleman asks about misfortune, not fortune. Who needs flattery?"* The fortune-teller said, *"This young master’s fate is called 'Tiger Seated in the Hall,' scattering his family’s bones. He should not remain at home. After another year, when his败运 arrives, not a single relative will survive, and his family’s wealth will be reduced to nothing."*

Old Man Liu asked, *"What if he were adopted out?"* The fortune-teller said, *"Adoption would make no difference. His fate is burdened by two layers of the 'Flowery Canopy.' If he were to leave home and become a monk, he would spare his kin harm and might even rise in the future."* These few words sent a chill down Zhangtai’s spine, unaware of the scheme.

When the fortune-telling was done, Old Man Liu paid the fee, and the fortune-teller departed. Without delay, Old Man Liu went to see the vegetable vendor Li San. He embellished the fortune-teller’s words about his son, recounting them in full, and insisted on returning the boy. Seeing Old Man Liu’s earnestness—appearing beyond reconciliation—Li San reluctantly agreed.

Old Man Liu returned home, called Zhangtai aside, and explained the situation. He gave him his usual clothes and belongings, then personally escorted him back to Li San, restoring him like a flawless jade returned. This matter, though seemingly without plan, was executed with precision—clean and leaving no trace.

Now, Old Man Liu’s household was rid of this burden. As for Zhangtai, since his first taste of intimacy with Chunniang, though his outward appearance had suffered, he had not yet reached the true realm of bliss. Yet his heart was deeply attached. Unexpectedly, after returning home for four or five days, he fell gravely ill with lovesickness. The sickness was severe—his form withered, his complexion wan, medicine ineffective, prayers unanswered.

Seeing his son in such a state, Li San went before the gods and vowed: *"If this child’s life is spared, I will offer him to the Buddha’s gate as a monastic disciple."* This was not Li San’s own vow but one prompted by Old Man Liu’s earlier recounting of the fortune-teller’s words.

After two or three months, the illness indeed abated, and Zhangtai narrowly escaped death. Once he had regained his strength, Li San sent him to Pipaji Temple to become a monk, giving him the dharma name Jingkong.

Later, Chunniang married Zhang Yong, and both her parents passed away. The vegetable vendor Li San also died. After leaving home, Zhangtai studied scriptures under his master and lived in peace. When his master entered nirvana, Zhangtai succeeded him as abbot, managing affairs with ease.

Yet he had one flaw: the sight of wine and meat was as vital to him as life itself, and the sight of women made him forget his own life. The temple’s young monks took turns keeping him company, while the alluring courtesans outside the small gate lingered in succession. Truly:

*Within the empty gate, he cultivated the Dao,*
*Yet in the realm of wind and moon, he idled away.*

As for Zhang Yong, he had initially met Jingkong because his wife’s family was acquainted with him, and he often invited the monk to recite scriptures. When they spoke of their childhood, they addressed each other as brother and sister. Jingkong would visit often, sharing tea and idle conversation before leaving with refined decorum.

One day, Zhang Yong was not at home when Jingkong arrived. Chunniang sat with him for a while. This monk was a ravenous ghost in matters of desire, a worm gnawing at the bottom of wine cups. Seeing no one around—and recalling their past intimacy—he boldly began to press close, rubbing against her.

*"Sister,"* he asked, *"do you remember what we did in the back garden?"* Chunniang smiled faintly, lowering her head in silence. Generally, a virtuous woman, when faced with a reckless man, would rebuke him sharply at the slightest impropriety, making it clear she was untouchable. But Chunniang’s smile, though wordless, had already written her consent.

Jingkong embraced her, making countless shameless advances. Chunniang feigned resistance: *"Stop this. If someone comes, it won’t be proper."* Jingkong quickly scanned the surroundings—no one was in sight. Turning back, he knelt on both knees, begging his "sister" for favor.

*"Your brother-in-law has been gone a while,"* Chunniang said. *"He’ll likely return soon. Better come another day."* Before she could finish, Zhang Yong appeared at the door. Chunniang, sharp-eyed and quick, gave Jingkong a push. *"Your brother-in-law is here."*

Jingkong hastily sat down. Zhang Yong entered, exchanged a bow, and sat. After some dull pleasantries, he took his leave.

Chunniang had set her heart on the monk, but with her husband always at home, she found no opportunity to arrange matters. Thus, she nagged and quarreled, insisting he go out to do business. Unluckily, this year of famine left them short of food and clothing, making her demands all the more pressing. When Yang Laoshi’s words aligned with her wishes, she chose the next day to send her husband fishing by the river.

Zhang Yong went to Yang Laoshi’s home, fetched his casting net, and set off together. As fate would have it, his luck ran ill with Zhang Yong—business was poor, and the fish he caught barely covered their daily meals. His distress need not be told.

Meanwhile, the county magistrate, following an official decree from his superiors, distributed ten thousand *hu* of grain to relieve the people of the county. The proclamation spread through the city. Zhang Yong saw it and returned home to tell his wife, *"The government is aiding the poor. Tomorrow, I must go to the city to claim grain."*

*"You should go,"* Chunniang replied.

The next day, □□□□□□□□□, he arrived at the county office, where crowds surged forward, each vying to be first—what a commotion! Zhang Yong thought, *"Now is no time for refined manners. I must use my strength to push through; the early bird gets the worm."* With that, he spread his arms and shoved with all his might. The scene was almost comical—he sent the crowd tumbling to either side. Why? Because in this famine, people were so starved they had no strength left; the slightest push sent them sprawling. Zhang Yong rushed forward and claimed five *sheng* of grain before heading home.

On his way, he came upon two sturdy men locked in a brawl, trading punches and kicks without end. Zhang Yong hurried forward to mediate, but they paid him no heed. Only after they had fought to exhaustion did he ask, *"What are you two fighting over? Tell me."*

One man stepped forward and said, *"Old sir, you wouldn’t understand."*

This wretched scoundrel—ten years ago, when my wife wanted to burn incense at the Eastern Peak Temple, she borrowed a foot-binding strap from my woman, and he still hasn’t returned it. When I asked for it back, he claimed my wife gave it to him as a keepsake. Does that sound reasonable to you?"

Zhang Yong turned to the man and said, "You’re in the wrong. Borrowing a foot-binding strap and not returning it, then calling it a keepsake—what nonsense!"

The other man stepped forward and countered, "Old sir, you’ve only heard his side. This dog of a cuckold—seven or eight years ago, when his wife was on her monthly courses and had no grass paper, she came to my house and borrowed one hundred and fifty-eight sheets. When I asked for them back, he denied it outright, even vowing, *'May I wipe pus and blood with what I borrowed from you!'* Now you see—what he says sounds right to him, and what I say sounds just to me. Even Zhang Yong was left speechless as the two lunged at each other again.

Zhang Yong said, "If you keep fighting like this, what if one of you ends up dead? That would be no small matter!" He forced himself between them and urged, "Stop fighting, both of you. Let me mediate."

The two men ceased their brawl and listened as Zhang Yong pronounced his judgment.

Zhang Yong said, "You only want five *sheng* of rice from him—if he gives it to you, will you let the matter rest?"

The man replied, "Exactly. If I get my five *sheng* of rice, I’ll spare him."

Zhang Yong said, "What if I repay the five *sheng* of rice on his behalf? How would that suit you?"

The two men said, "We’re just collecting a cold debt—how could we trouble you, old sir? We won’t take your rice. In this famine year, death is all around us—let’s just fight to the finish!"

They lunged at each other again, but Zhang Yong held them back with all his strength, and they did not strike. After repeated pleas, he finally persuaded them to accept his five *sheng* of rice. The man took it, expressed his gratitude, and left.

After walking half an arrow’s distance, the two men suddenly turned back and asked, "We’re grateful for your kindness, but we never learned your honorable name. We’ve returned especially to ask, so we may repay you in the future."

Zhang Yong said, "This humble one is named Zhang Yong, and I live in Anle Village to the east."

The three exchanged bows and parted ways.

Meanwhile, Spring娘 had seen all the neighbors who went to redeem grain return—except her husband. Alone, she could only lean against the gate and wait. Little did she know that this Master Zhang had also risen at dawn to redeem grain in the city and had not returned until the afternoon. As he walked, he thought, *"I acted out of kindness and gave away my rice to settle their quarrel. Now that I’m going home, how will I explain this to my wife? Can I just say I gave it away?"* After some reflection, he muttered, "That’s it—that’s it."

Zhang Yong thought, *"I’ll just say it was stolen."* As the saying goes:
*"Between husband and wife, speak but three parts of the truth—
Never bare the whole of one’s heart."*

Having settled on his plan, he returned home with ease. The moment he stepped inside, he feigned anger, pounding the table and stamping his feet, wailing, "The five *sheng* of rice I redeemed—it was stolen!"

Spring娘 was utterly dismayed. She shed a few tears alongside her husband, then went to borrow a *sheng* of rice from the neighbors. Just as she was about to head to the kitchen to prepare the meal, two men hurried over. Upon seeing Zhang Yong, they exclaimed, "Many thanks! Many thanks! Such a disturbance—such a disturbance!" They bowed repeatedly, ceaseless in their gratitude.

Fearing his wife would notice, Zhang Yong quickly pulled them aside and blinked furiously. The two paid no heed. Spring娘, watching from behind the door, saw everything clearly. She stormed out, demanding, "What’s with all this sneaking around? If you’ve something to say, speak plainly!"

The two men replied, "Madam Zhang, we fought over the rice, and your husband kindly gave us his to settle the matter. That’s why we’ve come to express our gratitude—we’ve nothing to hide."

Upon hearing this, Spring娘’s eyes flashed with fury, her gaze sharp as she raged, "He said it was stolen—so he gave it to you instead!" She cursed him without end: "Dog turtle! Dog cuckold!" The two men, sensing the storm, realized they’d been deceived. "We’ve overstepped with our courtesy," they muttered, begging forgiveness as they made their exit.

Spring娘 had long harbored disloyal thoughts, and now, over the matter of the rice, she regarded her husband as a stranger, cursing him through half the night. Zhang Yong, knowing he was in the wrong, offered not a word in reply, merely retiring to bed in sullen silence. The next day, he went to the riverbank as usual.

Now, in a nearby village lived a young man named Zhang Zhen’er. A fire had once consumed his home, reducing all his family’s possessions to ashes. Later, both his parents passed away, and Zhen’er wept for three days and nights until his eyes bled dry, leaving him completely blind. When he came of age, his relatives took turns sheltering him—one household offering a meal, another a place to stay—barely keeping him alive. But with this year of famine, even those kin, struggling to feed themselves, could no longer care for him. Blind and helpless, he could only await death. After two days without a drop of water or a morsel of food, Zhen’er thought, *"This life is surely beyond saving. Better to drown in the river than starve in a ditch—at least then I’ll follow the noble path of Qu Yuan."* In a daze, he groped his way to the riverbank, wept for a while, and was about to leap into the current.

Yet, as the saying goes, heaven aids the righteous in their darkest hour—where there seems no hope, deliverance arrives. (Of how his grievances were later avenged and he attained wealth and honor, we shall speak later.) Just as Zhen’er stood at the brink of life and death, a man suddenly seized him around the waist. *"Young man, why do you seek death in the river? If you have suffered some injustice, tell me."* Zhen’er struggled but could not break free, so he stood still and said, *"I have no grievance—only that with this famine, I can bear the hunger no longer and must end my life."* The man replied, *"You don’t seem like one of low character. Have you no kin to aid you in your hardship?"* Zhen’er answered, *"Once, there were those who helped, but now, with this year of scarcity, who would still care for me?"* The man asked, *"And how did you lose your sight?"* Zhen’er said, *"When my parents died, I wept for three days and nights until my eyes bled dry, and I became blind."* The man said, *"Then you are a filial son. Judging by your circumstances, you have nowhere to turn. Would you come with me to my home?"*

Zhen’er said, *"Do not mock me. I am one who can eat but cannot work—what use am I to you?"*

The man replied, *"My household consists of only my wife and me. I go out on business, and there is no one at home to tend to the doors and yard—nothing more than that. I need no labor from you."*

Hearing the man’s words as sincere—*"Surely he is not deceiving me"*—Zhen’er bowed his head and knelt, saying, *"If you, Father, would save me, you would be my reborn parents. I would take you as my adoptive father."* The man hurried to lift him up, took his hand, and they returned together.

Now, who was this man who saved him? It was Zhang Feng, the good-hearted soul who did not fear his wife’s scolding and who had urged her to give away the rice.

Along the way, they exchanged commonplace talk about residence, origins, and names. Zhang Feng rejoiced, saying, *"We were of the same family five hundred years ago. There is no need to change your name or surname—just call yourself Zhang Zhen’er."*

Before they knew it, they had reached his doorstep. Chun Niang saw her husband bring home this strange guest and was secretly vexed. She quickly asked about his origins. Zhang Feng told her of his attempt to drown himself in the river. Chun Niang feared any eyesore, especially one who might interfere with Jing Kong’s visits, but seeing that he was blind, she grudgingly allowed him to stay, intending to deal with the matter later.

Zhang Zhen’er bowed to his adoptive mother and settled into his new life, content to pass his remaining days in peace—no more mention of him.

Now, Jing Kong, seeing that Zhang Feng was absent, visited daily, indulging in frivolous amusements without pause. One day, Zhang Zhen’er stood at the door when Jing Kong arrived. Zhen’er heard him and asked, *"Who are you?"* Jing Kong did not answer but rushed inside with a loud noise. Zhen’er shouted, *"Who dares to barge in like that? Could it be a thief?"* He waved his hands about, groping and calling out without stopping.

Jing Kong saw Chun Niang and asked, *"Who is this?"*
She replied, *"He is your own flesh-and-blood nephew."*
Jing Kong said, *"I’ve never seen you pregnant, nor have I seen you give birth—how did you suddenly raise such a grown son?"*
The two laughed.

Chun Niang then told him Zhen’er’s story in detail, and Jing Kong understood at last. When Zhen’er heard his mother and Jing Kong speaking playfully, he realized they were familiar with each other and fell silent.

Chun Niang called Zhen’er inside to meet his uncle, but instead sent him back to sit at the door while the two carried on their usual mischief.

As for Jing Kong’s visits, Chun Niang had kept them secret from Zhen’er, but this time fate had brought them together, leaving her no choice but to reveal the truth. Afterward, whenever Zhen’er heard the sound of his voice, he would call out in greeting.

For over ten days, though Zhen’er’s eyes could not discern forms or colors, his ears grew sharp in recognizing voices and tones, and he began to suspect the truth. One day, he said to Chun Niang, *"Our father is not at home, and it is thanks to my uncle that he comes daily to oversee matters. If he finds no one around, why not move in with us? We could rely on each other."*

Chun Niang said, *"Your words may make sense, but my uncle is a monk—living together would be improper in appearance."*

Zhen’er replied, *"We are blood relatives. What fear is there of others’ gossip?"*
Chun Niang gave no clear answer.

Zhen’er’s words were deliberate, meant to provoke a reaction and test her secrets. Chun Niang, unaware, occasionally let slip careless words that gave her away, and Zhen’er remembered them all.

The next day was Chun Niang’s birthday. Jing Kong brought fish and meat, brewed fine wine, and toasted her. After they ate for a while, he sent Zhen’er to warm the wine in the kitchen, then led her into the bedroom, where they indulged in their licentious pleasures like King Xu of Chu and the enchantress of Mount Yu.

Zhen’er warmed the wine and carried it to the hall, but saw no one seated at the table. Instead, he heard from the inner chamber sounds like those of a leprous toad croaking wildly on the Third Day of the Third Month, or an old man of seventy or eighty suffering from phlegm-fire, wheezing and gasping without end.

Hearing this, Zhen’er was deeply vexed—
*"One with boundless lust, yet fears no death,
One with unwavering loyalty, yet dares not live."*

「Pounding his chest and stamping his feet, Zhen’er exclaimed: *“What brother and sister! Clearly a wanton woman and a lecherous monk! My father was a man of upright virtue—now he must endure this shameless harlot’s disgrace in our home.”* He hastily set down the wine flask, then rushed to the kitchen, seizing a cleaver: *“Let me slay these two, to avenge my father’s honor!”* Just as he prepared to step out, he paused, reflecting: *“I am blind. If I enter the chamber with this knife, and they catch sight of me first, I’ll only bring greater shame upon myself. All things must be weighed carefully—never rashly.”* He left the cleaver behind and walked out again.

Chun Niang and the monk then took their seats. Chun Niang asked Zhen’er: *“When did you bring this wine flask?”*
Zhen’er replied: *“While you two were in the chamber.”*
Chun Niang’s face flushed crimson as she glanced at the monk.

Jing Kong interjected: *“It was just when I had hurriedly relieved myself moments ago.”*
With feigned excuses, the two drank a few cups in disorder before departing.

Meanwhile, Zhang Fei spent the day fishing but caught nothing. As dusk fell and mist hung thick in the air, the fish—unaware of the nets—swam in a few. After several attempts, he found that nighttime yields three times the profit of daytime. Thus, he stayed out every night.

Seeing her husband’s habits now settled into a strict routine—never late or early—Chun Niang also deduced Zhen’er must have noticed the deception. So they agreed: at dusk he would return home, at dawn he would leave, both to share the bed and to mock Zhen’er’s blind ignorance. This scheme was cleverer than Liu Bei’s six expeditions against the Qin or Zhuge Liang’s seven captures of Meng Huo, achieving two ends at once—yet it was not a good thing.
