Chunniang agreed, *“That makes sense.”*

Zhen’er then questioned her in detail about her father’s death. Chunniang, though unprompted, recounted the events in the same way Jingkong had described them.

The next day, Zhen’er handed a petition to Chunniang to submit, while Jingkong also filed his own. The magistrate, reviewing the two conflicting accusations—one claiming murder, the other conspiracy—suspected foul play. He immediately issued an order, summoning both accusers for interrogation.

Before long, they were both brought in. After recording their statements, both parties defended their claims with seemingly sound reasoning.

The magistrate asked, *“Are there others in your household?”*
Chunniang replied, *“Only a blind man remains at home.”*

The magistrate then had Zhen’er brought in for interrogation. As soon as Zhen’er entered the hall, he remained silent and instead handed up another petition—accusing *both* of them. The magistrate understood at once and ordered the two original accusers to confess.

The pair pushed blame back and forth, refusing to take responsibility. The magistrate then had Jingkong beaten with a *jiāgùn* (夾棍), striking him fifty times, and Chunniang was tortured with a *zānzi* (拶子), enduring thirty blows of the *guòchuán dīng* (過船釘). Unable to bear the pain, they finally confessed to the charge of *delinquency* (奸).

As for the murder, there was no corpse nor weapon—so the magistrate could not convict them. He released the torture implements and ordered them to be re-examined the next day. The three were then driven out together.

When they reached a secluded spot, Chunniang turned to Jingkong and said, *“We’ve been framed by Zhen’er. Now that matters have come to this, we’ve confessed to the *delinquency*, but the murder we cannot admit. If they torture us again, we’ll have to pin it on Yang Laoshi.”* The two agreed on their plan.

The next day, at the re-examination, when the magistrate threatened torture once more, they both immediately implicated Yang Laoshi. The magistrate issued an arrest warrant on the spot. Yang was brought in, beaten with the *jiāgùn*, and forced to confess—claiming he had been drowned in the river.

The magistrate then ordered their imprisonment and sentencing. A pair of *shuānglián jiā* (雙連枷) was fitted upon the *delinquent monk and wanton woman*, and they were paraded through the four city gates as a warning. *(This concludes the tale of Chunniang’s unjust suffering.)*

Now, as for Zhang Feng—after encountering Shi and Bu at the riverside, the two led him up the mountain. Upon meeting the bandit chieftain, Zhang Feng quickly bowed in greeting. The chieftain, whose name was *Niǎoshān Dàwáng* (鳥山大王), was surprisingly refined, with none of the brutishness typical of bandits. Seeing Zhang Feng kneel, he hurriedly helped him up and said, *“You are a man of righteousness. Today, after such misfortune, take comfort and stay here—I shall avenge your wrongs and clear your name.”* He then had a seat prepared for Zhang.

After tea, a feast was set before him in welcome.

The two men struck up an instant friendship, forming an unbreakable bond, and Zhang Feng was immediately appointed as military strategist.

Zhang Feng was a man of cunning—with the chieftain’s approval, he forged proclamations and wrote out arrest warrants, which delighted the bandit lord. After more than a month had passed, the chieftain dispatched several dozen henchmen to Zhang Feng’s home to seize the two individuals and subject them to interrogation.

The henchmen, having received their orders, disguised themselves as common folk. After traveling several days, they arrived in the district of Fushun. Inquiring after Zhang Feng’s residence, they waited until dusk before forcing their way inside. Searching the house thoroughly, they found no monk or woman—only an old blind man asleep by the hearth. They seized him roughly and demanded, *“There was a monk and a woman here—where have they gone?”*

The blind man, startled awake, struck his head in confusion and stammered, *“The monk and woman were put in stocks.”*

*“There’s no one here,”* the henchmen snapped.

*“They were put in stocks in the city,”* the blind man replied.

*“Zhang Feng clearly said they were outside the city—how could they be inside?”* One of them struck the blind man across the face, jolting him fully awake. He heard them mention Zhang Feng and, bewildered, asked, *“What did you just say about Zhang Feng? Have you seen him?”*

The henchmen recounted Zhang Feng’s background to him. Only then did the blind man realize they were bandits and, fearing for his own role in the affair, told them what he knew.

*“If that’s the case,”* the henchmen mused, *“how shall we report back to the chieftain?”*

One suggested, *“We’ll just take this blind man with us.”*

The blind man pleaded, *“I was about to turn against those two myself! If you take me, their punishment will be lighter!”*

The henchmen hesitated, at a loss for tangible proof, deliberating for some time.

The blind man saw that the torches in their hands had already burned out. The henchmen were thrown into disarray, unable to devise a plan. One said, *“Brothers, don’t panic! Let me tell you a story.”*

The others replied, *“When? Tell us a story!”*

The man said, *“If I tell you a story, we’ll have torches.”*

Hearing this, the henchmen had no choice but to listen attentively. The man began:

*“In the Three Kingdoms era, Guan Yunzhang, along with the two ladies, Lady Gan and Lady Mi, surrendered to the Han and stayed in an inn. Cao Cao sent someone to deliver gifts—all were prepared, except for candles, of which there was only one. This was because Cao Cao saw that Guan was alone escorting the two widows, so he devised this scheme. But who knew that Guan was a man of extraordinary wit and foresight! When he saw the candle’s flame was about to gutter out, he ordered the demolition of every wall in the inn, then set the bamboo slats ablaze, burning through the night. This is called the **‘strategy of torches’**—*fénliáo zhī cè*. Now, we have no torches, but there are walls all around us. Why hesitate?”*

The henchmen, upon hearing this, immediately sprang into action, tearing down countless walls and binding them into torches. As they demolished a wall partition, a round object tumbled out. Upon closer inspection, it was revealed to be a mirror.

Zhang Zhen’er heard it was a mirror and said to the crowd, *“Your Excellencies need not trouble yourselves—this mirror was obtained by my father while fishing. You may take it to him, and it shall serve as proof of my words.”*

The henchmen carried the mirror away and left. *(No further mention of this.)*

Now, as for Zhang Zhen’er, upon learning of his father’s fate, he thought: *“If I do not go to demand justice from them for my father’s life, how can Yang Laoshi ever be avenged? Now, I shall play the part of a beggar, and on my back, I shall bear a yellow cloth banner with the words ‘vengeance for my father’ written upon it, seeking retribution along the streets.”*

To his surprise, his business thrived. You ask why? It was because of the bold sign he bore—everyone said he was a filial son, and copper coins and grains of rice poured in, allowing him to earn enough for abundant food and clothing.

One day, as he wandered to a desolate place, he saw three men who called out to him, *“You seek vengeance for your father—now, we have come to take you to your death!”*

Zhen’er asked, *“Who are you?”*

The three replied, *“We are officials sent here.”*

Zhen’er said, *“I am precisely seeking justice—then let us go together.”*

The three retorted, *“If you go with us, you will surely die. It would be better if you did not seek vengeance, and we would let you escape alive.”*

Zhen’er declared, *“My father died unjustly, and today’s grievance, even if I must brave boiling water or tread fire, I will not refuse. I will avenge this wrong, and then I may die in peace.”*

Seeing his unwavering filial devotion, the three men, though they tested him with their words, found no way to sway him. They then said, *“Your filial heart is indeed sincere, but your eyesight is unclear, making it difficult for you to act. We have eye medicine here—let us apply it and open your eyes.”*

Zhen’er rejoiced, *“If this is so, I shall see the light of day!”*

The three men applied the medicine to his eyes, and they opened. Zhen’er looked closely and saw that they were three **Dao/Way** masters. He quickly bowed his head to the ground in reverence, knocking his forehead against the earth seven or eight times.

When he rose, the three had vanished. Zhen’er was both astonished and overjoyed, thinking, *“It must be the Three Officials of Heaven, moved by my filial piety, who have come to rescue me.”*

He then discarded his crutch and walked freely, feeling unbounded joy. *(No further mention of this.)*

Meanwhile, Yang Laoshi suffered these hardships in prison, unable to see his loved ones. His household had only a fourteen- or fifteen-year-old daughter, delicate and tender, left alone at home. Fortunately, the neighborly Madam Wang came to keep her company.

Yang Laoshi spent his days in prison without thought of returning home. Unexpectedly, Zhang Zhen’er’s eyesight became clear, and his begging business prospered. He first delivered the earnings to the prison, waiting for Yang Laoshi to eat before he himself partook, doing this daily without fail. If there was any extra silver or money, he used it to buy firewood and rice for his father’s daughter.

Truly, one man sustained two lives. *(No further mention of this.)*

Now the bandits returned to the mountain with the mirror, reporting to the Great King. They then went to see Zhang Feng, explaining the matter. Zhang Feng took the mirror and placed it in his room, then **rested there for the night**.

He saw many immortals entering in procession, gazing at the mirror in bewilderment, unable to fathom it. After pondering through the night, the next day he told the Great King of Bird Mountain, who rejoiced, saying:

*"Based on your words, this must surely be a treasure. Now the Prime Minister Qíqí has dispatched men to sketch likenesses and search the land—whoever presents the Magic Mirror of the Immortals shall be granted the princess in marriage. Why not present this mirror and seek fortune and honor? If you remain here in the mountains forever, there will be no end to it. Though I speak plainly, it is only for your own good."*

Zhang Feng reflected in silence. The visions he had seen in the Hall of the Moon Lord matched these events, so he agreed. The two decided their plan, and the next day sent two bandits to carry the mirror, packing supplies. The Great King of Bird Mountain gave fifty taels as parting gifts, prepared a farewell feast, and personally escorted them to the ten-li pavilion. They clasped hands—*(text ends here)*.

chunks.original_text: 卷三第一则（原缺） 卷三第二则（缺目） （上缺）出房，转过天井，只见屈氏与濮义老婆痴呆呆的立在那里。 友生看见，吃了一惊，连忙回转书房睡了。 屈氏与濮义老婆领了朝云，回到房中，问道：“姑爷怎么说？ ”朝云不敢隐瞒，从头直说，气得那濮义老婆捶胸跌脚道：“什么要紧，断送了我一个女儿！ ”鼻涕眼泪哭个不住。 屈氏道：“适才嘱付你的，临期须要叫喊，为何你绝不出声？ ”朝云道：“我本要叫，无奈姑爷将那蜜甜甜的舌尖儿填塞在我口中，一时叫喊不出。 ”只见那小川走过来问道：“这事怎么说？ ”屈氏将朝云的言语说与小川听了。 小川道：“既然如此，料不是个呆女眷，明日与他讲话。 ”屈氏道：“这是我们不是，与他何干？ 只是到了初六，要他拜花烛。 若还不肯，须索处治他一番，方出此气。 ”大家怨怅了一会，各各睡去。 不题。

chunks.original_text: 且说友生为这朝云，一连住了几日，每每黄昏时候，直等到二三更天，方才去睡。 想道：“我与朝云勾当，他父母若还知道，必定加之颜色。 若不知道，缘何截足不来？ 这事大有可疑。 我明日私下问他一声，方才放心。 ”候到次日下午，只见朝云独自一个在角门□□□□□。 友生四顾无人，走到身边问道：“朝云姐，为何晚间不拿茶来？ ”朝云道：“母亲知道了，连赠嫁不稳哩。 ”友生听了这两句话，不加思索，已是回报肚肠，笑道：“缘份若此，何命之蹇也！ ”这日到房就睡，想道：“不要没主意，明日回去吧，若再迟延，便落他局了。 千着万着，走为上着。 ”到了五更，穿好衣服，出房竟往后门一溜，逃之夭夭去了。 到得家中，父母尚未起床，便到房中收拾铺陈银两，叫琴司挑了，连父母也不别，雇了一只小船，往望州进发。 不题。 且说小川清早起来，差濮义去叫厨司、定戏文，家中打点，好不热闹。 大家忙了一会，只见濮义老婆慌慌张张走进来道：“昨夜失贼了！ ”后门已是大开，检点家中并不失脱。 前前后后俱已看到，只有书房失了一个女婿，连忙报与小川知道。 小川晓得他逃走回家去了，再叫濮义请来。 濮义走到陆家，见了天成，说道：“家主多拜上相公，今日要姑爷另拜花烛，特道小人来请。 ”天成道：“自那日到你家来，并不见他返舍。 ”只见管门老儿进来对天成道：“小相公天未明敲门进来，叫琴司挑着行李，不知那里去了。 ”天成即将此话覆了濮义。 濮义领命而去，回覆小川。

Meanwhile, You-sheng, on account of Chao-yun, stayed for several days in a row. Each evening, he would wait until the second or third watch before retiring to sleep.

He thought to himself, *"If Chao-yun’s parents find out about our affair, they will surely show their displeasure. If they don’t know, why has she stopped coming? There is great cause for suspicion. Tomorrow, I must ask her in private to set my mind at ease."*

The next afternoon, he saw Chao-yun alone by the side gate. Glancing around to ensure no one was near, he approached and asked, *"Chao-yun, why didn’t you bring tea this evening?"*

Chao-yun replied, *"Mother found out. Even my dowry isn’t safe."*

Upon hearing these words, You-sheng needed no further thought to understand her meaning. He smiled and said, *"If fate is so unkind, what cruel destiny is this!"*

That night, he went straight to bed, pondering, *"I must not hesitate. I should leave tomorrow. If I delay further, I’ll be trapped in their scheme. Of all plans, fleeing is the best."*

At the fifth watch, he dressed, slipped out of his room, and hurried through the back gate, escaping without a trace.

Upon returning home, his parents had not yet risen. He went to his room, gathered his bedding and silver, and instructed Qin-si to carry them. Without even bidding his parents farewell, he hired a small boat and set off for Wangzhou. (The rest is omitted.)

Meanwhile, Xiao-chuan rose early in the morning and sent Pu Yi to summon the cooks and arrange for opera performances, making the household bustle with preparations.

After a flurry of activity, Pu Yi’s wife rushed in, flustered, and announced, *"We’ve been robbed last night!"* The back gate was wide open, but nothing in the house was missing. After searching everywhere, they realized only one thing was gone—the son-in-law.

They quickly reported this to Xiao-chuan. Knowing You-sheng had fled home, Xiao-chuan sent Pu Yi to fetch him.

Pu Yi arrived at the Lu residence and said to Tian-cheng, *"My master sends his regards and requests the young master’s presence today to perform the wedding rites."*

Tian-cheng replied, *"Since he came to your house that day, he has not returned."*

Just then, the gatekeeper entered and told Tian-cheng, *"The young master knocked at the door before dawn, had Qin-si carry his luggage, and left—I don’t know where."*

Tian-cheng relayed this to Pu Yi, who took his leave and returned to report to Xiao-chuan.

chunks.original_text: 大家一场扫兴，气得十生九死，不在话下。 且说友生一程来到杭州，看见西湖景致，不胜欢喜。 盘桓数日，再四流连，又恐父母差人追寻，须索远遁才是，即便渡江。 盘山过岭，吃尽奔波，行了半月，已到江西地面，落了饭店。 想道路已远了，不必再行，思量觅一住房，安顿身子，用功读书。 只见店门前走进一个客人，也是投宿的，因来迟了没有空房，就与友生合着一个房儿，彼此拱手。 友生问道：“请问老兄贵姓大名？ 仙乡何处？ ”那人道：“小弟姓严名真，住在吴门。 ”友生也通了姓名乡贯，两人俱是同乡。 友生道：“老兄到此贵干？ ”严真道：“家兄严悦，现任吉安知府，幕中乏人，家兄特令小弟返舍，觅请幕宾，因而到此。 但不知尊兄到此何干？ ”友生道：“小弟有一敝友，在吉水作邑，特请小弟入幕。 不料中途闻报，他已丁艰回去，所以羁迟在此。 ”严真道：“不知尊兄肯到家兄敝署去么？ ”友生道：“小弟匪才，恐不堪为令兄鞭策。 ”严真见他言语温雅，人物稀奇，必是个有学问的人，要他同行，庶免归家，省却往返之劳。 遂叫店主人设下一壶一菜，两人对酌。 言语投机，竟成莫逆。 到了次日，严真替友生算还饭钱，二人雇了轿马，一路往吉安进发。 且说朝云自友生去后，朝思暮想，病了一年，把一个粉装成、玉辗就的容貌，弄得骷髅相似，服药祷赛，全无应验。 临死之时对母亲道：“孩儿大约不济事了，箱内有一题诗汗巾，千万要与我带去。 ”濮义夫妻连忙向箱中寻觅，果然有一汗巾，将来递与女儿。 朝云看了这件东西，倍增伤感，霎时间便瞑目而去。 竟与巧巧之死却无两样。 要晓得这两个魂儿，是与友生不肯干休。 果然精灵不泯，到了阴司恰好遇见巧巧。 说来都是陆友生的冤家债主，到了阎罗案前，双膝跪下，把陆友生的薄情短义，哭诉一番，还要思量回阳，与他聚首。 阎王即查姻缘簿上，陆士善与巧巧、朝云凤缘已满，无容再合； 更查得陆士善本该少年科甲，因他无故弃妻，上帝嗔怒，将他前程革去。 二人听了，哭倒在地。 阎王道：“你二人阳寿虽未该绝，但已脱胎离舍，不得回生。 且放你作浪荡游魂，遨游尘世，直到阳寿终时，再行发放。 ”二人随风化影，离了阴司，一径往吉安府来。 正是： 冤家本是前生结，来世冤家今世成。 按下不题。 且说濮小川养了这个女儿，受尽万般气恼。 女婿逃走出门，杳无音信，养着女儿，终无结局。 若还改嫁，倘若女婿回来，又费周折。 正在那里与屈氏宛转踌躇，没法布摆，闻得朝云死了。 小川道：“我们不若将朝云当作女儿开起丧来，只要瞒得陆家耳目。 ”屈氏道：“依你见识，将大乔着放何处？ ”小川道：“我有一个表亲，叫做孔方，他领我三千本钱，在吉安府开张饭铺，将女儿寄送他家，待事冷落，另择一配，岂不干净！ ”屈氏道：“只是女儿自小在我身傍，怎忍舍他远去？ ”小川道：“事到其间，不得不如此了。 ”便与濮义夫妻说知。 濮义也落得如此，即报到陆家，说大姑娘死了，殡殓成礼。 陆天成夫妇都来哭吊，信为实然。 只是苦了朝云，活也要他替，死也要他替。 不觉过了七七之期，小川另差管家濮忠夫妇，准备盘缠行李，随了大乔直到孔家。

Meanwhile, You-sheng had traveled all the way to Hangzhou. Delighted by the sights of West Lake, he lingered for several days, reluctant to leave. Yet fearing his parents might send someone to pursue him, he knew he must flee farther. Crossing the river, he traversed mountains and ridges, enduring hardships on the road. After half a month’s journey, he reached Jiangxi and took lodging at an inn. Thinking himself far enough from home, he decided to settle and find a place to stay, where he could devote himself to his studies.

Just then, another traveler entered the inn, seeking a room. As the hour was late and no vacant chambers remained, he was shown to share You-sheng’s room. The two clasped hands in greeting.

You-sheng asked, “May I inquire your honorable name and hometown?”

The man replied, “This humble one is Yan Zhen, a native of Wu-men.”

You-sheng likewise introduced himself, revealing they were fellow townsmen.

“What brings you here, sir?” You-sheng asked.

Yan Zhen said, “My elder brother, Yan Yue, is currently the prefect of Ji’an. His yamen lacks staff, so he sent me home to recruit a private secretary. And what brings you here?”

You-sheng replied, “A friend of mine serves as magistrate in Ji-shui. He invited me to join his staff, but en route, I received word that he had returned home for mourning. Thus, I’ve been delayed here.”

Yan Zhen asked, “Would you consider joining my brother’s yamen?”

You-sheng demurred, “I fear my meager talents would be unworthy of your brother’s guidance.”

Yan Zhen, however, found his speech refined and his demeanor uncommon—clearly a learned man. Hoping to spare himself the trouble of returning home, he invited You-sheng to accompany him. He called for the innkeeper to prepare wine and a dish, and the two drank together. Their conversation flowed so smoothly that they soon became fast friends.

The next day, Yan Zhen settled You-sheng’s bill, and the two hired sedan chairs and horses to set off for Ji’an.

After You-sheng’s departure, Chao-yun pined for him day and night, falling ill for a year. Her once rosy complexion and jadelike beauty withered into a skeletal semblance. Medicines and prayers brought no relief. As death approached, she told her mother, “I fear I won’t recover. There’s a handkerchief with a poem in my trunk—please be sure to bury it with me.”

Pu Yi and his wife hurriedly searched the trunk and found the handkerchief, which they handed to their daughter. Chao-yun gazed at it, her sorrow redoubling. In an instant, her eyes closed forever—her fate no different from Qiao-qiao’s.

It so happened that their spirits, unwilling to let You-sheng go, lingered on. In the underworld, they met by chance, and both proved to be his creditors of karmic debt. Kneeling before King Yama, they tearfully recounted You-sheng’s faithlessness and inconstancy, longing to return to the living and reunite with him.

The King consulted the Register of Marriages and saw that Lu Shi-shan’s predestined bonds with Qiao-qiao and Chao-yun Feng had already been fulfilled—no reunion was possible. Furthermore, he discovered that Lu Shi-shan was originally fated for early success in the imperial examinations, but for abandoning his wife without cause, the Heavenly Court had revoked his prospects. Hearing this, the two women collapsed in grief.

King Yama said, “Though your allotted lifespans are not yet exhausted, you have already departed your bodies and cannot return to life. I shall permit you to wander as unrestrained spirits in the mortal realm until your natural lifespans end, at which time you will be summoned for judgment.”

Thus, their forms dissolved into the wind, and they left the underworld, making their way to Ji’an Prefecture.

*Enemies bound in past lives,
In this life, enemies still they become.*

This aside, let us return to Pu Xiao-chuan. Having raised this daughter, he had endured endless frustration. His son-in-law had fled without a trace, and keeping his daughter at home offered no resolution. Yet if he arranged another marriage and the son-in-law returned, complications would arise. As he and Qu-shi wrestled with their dilemma, word came that Chao-yun had died.

Xiao-chuan said, “We should hold a funeral for Chao-yun as if she were our daughter, keeping it secret from the Lu family.”

Qu-shi asked, “And what of Da-qiao?”

Xiao-chuan replied, “I have a relative named Kong Fang who borrowed three thousand strings of cash from me to open an inn in Ji’an Prefecture. We can send Da-qiao to live with him. Once the situation cools, we can arrange another match—wouldn’t that be tidy?”

Qu-shi sighed, “But she’s been by my side since childhood. How can I bear to part with her?”

Xiao-chuan said, “Circumstances leave us no choice.” He informed Pu Yi and his wife, who saw no better option. They then reported to the Lu family that their eldest daughter had died, and the funeral rites were carried out. Lu Tian-cheng and his wife came to mourn, believing it to be true.

Poor Chao-yun—whether alive or dead, she was made to take the blame. After the forty-nine days of mourning had passed, Xiao-chuan dispatched his steward, Pu Zhong, and his wife to prepare travel funds and luggage. They accompanied Da-qiao to Kong’s household.

He then composed a poem on the spot:

*"Two hearts apart, each sheds its stream of tears,
Vainly the Herd-boy calls from heaven’s frontier.
The Weaving Maid’s millennial grief won’t fade,
Nor can the fairy’s Qixi sorrow be allayed.
The embroidered bower’s rain-cloud passion burns bright,
The gauze window’s wind-moon longing drifts like night.
Far as Wu Mountain, the Silver River flows—
Heartbroken, autumn’s sorrow Song Yu knows."*

**Chapter Three, Third Tale: The Handsome Scholar’s Ghostly Matchmaker**

Now, You-sheng looked up as the door opened and saw a woman of about thirty. He quickly rose, stepped forward, and bowed, asking, *"Madam, to which household do you belong? What brings you here?"*

The woman replied, *"This old one is surnamed Wei. I’ve come, perhaps presumptuously, to propose a match for you, sir."*

You-sheng said, *"I am deeply grateful for your kindness. However, I have resolved to marry only a woman of both talent and beauty."*

Wei replied, *"I’ve arranged countless matches and never once misled a family’s child. This young lady is of age and as lovely as a flower. If you marry her, how will you repay me?"*

You-sheng said, *"If she is as you say, I will certainly reward you handsomely."*

Wei smiled, rose, and took her leave. You-sheng asked where she lived, and she answered, *"Under the third archway east of the main street."*

After parting, Wei went straight to the Kong household to act as matchmaker for Daqiao. Kong’s wife said, *"I’ve turned down dozens of proposals for my daughter, as none suited me. But if Wei speaks of this one, it must be a fine match."*

Wei said, *"This Master Yan is exceptionally talented—a learned scholar of our time."*

Kong, knowing he was the prefect’s guest and thus a man of influence, immediately agreed.

The next day, You-sheng visited Wei and said, *"Regarding yesterday’s discussion, I must see the young lady in person to set my mind at ease."*

Wei replied, *"That can be arranged."* She then accompanied You-sheng to a grand household, where she asked him to wait while she went inside. After the time it takes to drink a cup of tea, two maids emerged, supporting a young woman who glided forward with graceful steps. She approached the hall, bowed to You-sheng, stood briefly, then turned and followed Wei back inside.

You-sheng, his spirits lifted and heart delighted, watched her until she passed through the inner gate before turning his gaze away. Unnoticed, she had dropped a handkerchief, which You-sheng picked up. Fearing someone might see, he hastily tucked it into his sleeve without examining it closely.

Wei emerged, and they set off. Along the way, she asked, *"Does the young lady meet your approval?"*

You-sheng replied joyfully, *"She is truly a woman of the highest refinement. But how much is the betrothal gift?"*

Wei said, *"She doesn’t care about the gift—only that you marry into her family."*

You-sheng said, *"That can be done."* They parted, and he chose an auspicious day to send the betrothal gifts and complete the marriage.

On the wedding day, You-sheng dressed in his finest, and the procession arrived. He boarded the sedan chair and was carried to the Kong household. After the nuptial rites, Wei took her leave.

You-sheng entered the bridal chamber and saw his new wife. Startled, he thought, *"Why does she not resemble the woman I saw before? There must be some mistake."* He pulled her close, scrutinizing her carefully, and suddenly erupted in fury, shouting, *"Where did this monstrosity come from!"*

Kong knew that Da-qiao’s first husband had already fled, and now seeing this one attempt to leave as well, he feared he would depart and never return—another unresolved matter. Such arrangements made it impossible to escape, even with wings. You-sheng sat in the room like a caged ape or a captive crane, with no means of flight. chunks.translated_text: Unexpectedly, Kong Fang’s fortunes took a turn for the worse. One night at the third watch, a clamor arose outside the door—robbers, their heads wrapped and faces covered, smashed through the tiles and forced their way in with torches and cudgels. Startled, You-sheng had nowhere to hide. Finding nothing of value after a thorough search, the bandits bound him and scorched his body with burning straw, demanding he reveal where his treasures were hidden. Unable to endure the torment, You-sheng at last said, "The treasure is in the upper floor at the rear." The robbers dragged him along as their guide. Having only just arrived at the Kong residence, You-sheng was unfamiliar with the layout, yet the bandits drove him forward with blows, stick after stick, until they reached the rear tower. There, they ransacked chests and overturned trunks, gorging themselves before departing. Fearing pursuit, they hauled You-sheng two or three *li* away before releasing him. He fled for his life, stumbling and staggering, collapsing in a daze only to scramble up and run again. Then, one of his shoes slipped off. As he groped about in the dark, he failed to find it but instead felt a heavy bundle, likely left behind by the robbers. He tucked it into his sash and hesitated: *"If I return, they will surely lock me in that room again. If I do not, I have no lower garments—what will I do when dawn comes?"* Just as he despaired, the moon began to sink, and the cock crowed at daybreak. Soon, the sky lightened. With no other choice, You-sheng crouched down and sat upon the ground. The locals, seeing this strange sight, gathered around in a circle, demanding his story. Growing weary of their questions, he suddenly spotted a young servant pushing through the crowd. The boy cried out, "Master, put these on!" You-sheng looked up—it was none other than the lute attendant. Hearing that his master had been seized, the boy had guessed he would be released partway, half-dressed. After the robbers left, he had taken a few garments and set out before dawn to search. By chance, he had come upon You-sheng in this very place. Dressed at last, You-sheng conferred with the boy: "Let us not return. We shall find another place to stay." The attendant replied, "But all our belongings are there—how can we abandon them?" You-sheng said, "What are belongings worth? If we go back, they will lock me in that room again. When will I ever see freedom? The imperial examinations are near. Let us go to the provincial capital, find lodging, and study for a time. After the exams, we can decide what to do next." The boy objected, "We have no traveling money—how can you take the exams?" You-sheng told him of the silver he had stumbled upon. Delighted, the attendant followed his master, and along the way, they purchased bedding. By the time they reached the provincial capital, the preliminary exams had already passed, but You-sheng was selected as a *yicai*—a candidate who had missed the main examination—and granted a place. He awaited only the three sessions of the provincial exam. After a few days, the first session arrived. You-sheng prepared himself and entered the examination hall. The sky was still dim, and the examination papers had not yet been distributed. He lowered his head and feigned sleep for a moment. Suddenly, a group of clerks shouted, "The names are being called in the hall—go, go at once!" Without explanation, they seized him and dragged him forward. Above, the names were read one by one. When the eighteenth name, Lu Shishan, was called, You-sheng stepped forward to answer. There, seated in the place of honor, an official declared, "You abandoned your wife without cause. The Celestial Court is displeased and has revoked your future prospects." Before You-sheng could explain, the clerks hustled him out.

Along the way, he mused, "That dream in the examination hall was indeed strange. This time, upon returning, I shall first reconcile with the Kong family, then bring my wife back with me, and later fetch Lady Pu to return her intact to her family." Just so:

The bitter sea knows no bounds—
Turn your head, and the shore is near.

This very thought of his had already startled the Day-Officer of Merit, who reported it to the Celestial Emperor. Thus, his prospects for official rank held seven or eight parts of promise. But this is a matter for later.

Meanwhile, after the bandits had departed, Kong Fang and his wife crawled out from beneath the bed. Taking stock of their household silver and valuables, they found a full three to five thousand taels missing, and their son-in-law gone as well. In one stroke, they had lost both person and property, and their bitterness knew no bounds. They could not but report the theft to the authorities in hopes of apprehending the culprits. Yet as the saying goes:

Robbed, then hounded by officials—
Sorrow upon sorrow.

They fell into a deep melancholy, which soon turned to illness. Fever and chills racked Kong Fang, and within days, he passed away with a final offering. His wife followed soon after. Da Qiao mourned them more grievously than if they had been her own parents. After observing three years of filial mourning, she performed all rites for their burial.

A once-prosperous household, now bereft of its two central pillars, tottered and collapsed. Though Da Qiao was of age, she had never married, and as a young woman, she could hardly keep the household in order. She could only leave matters to drift. One day, she thought, "I am already of such an age, yet master of none. Twice betrothed, and both husbands turned to empty promises. I no longer hope for any good fortune. I shall pack my things and return to see my parents one last time, then shave off these locks and take up the monastic life." She called upon the Pu couple to discuss the matter. They assented, and Da Qiao made ready. Hiring a carriage, the three set out on their journey homeward. But of this, no more.

Qin Si, frantic, approached the innkeeper to negotiate, offering to sell herself to cover the costs of her master’s funeral. Now, the waters beneath Mount Dagu were part of the Yangtze’s mighty current—where countless souls had vanished without a trace, who could ever account for them? Yet Da Qiao’s fate was not yet sealed. She drifted until she neared a moored vessel, where the boatman spied her and cried, “A woman is floating downstream! Quick, save her!” The crew rushed to action—some with poles, others into the water—and hauled her aboard. Though she clung to but a few breaths of life, the official in the cabin ordered the boatwoman to cut her bonds, change her clothes, and let her rest awhile before summoning Da Qiao inside to recount her story.

Da Qiao told of her parents’ origins, her betrothals to Zhang and Li, and how she had been waylaid by pirates. The official sighed repeatedly, “Pitiful, pitiful!” Then, eyeing her closely, he saw a face so plain that none would find her pleasing. “Now grown to such an age, still a maiden of a good family, cast adrift here—if I do not lift her up, she will surely become a ghost of the gutters.” Turning to Da Qiao, he said, “Marriage comes sooner or later as fate decrees. You must not be hasty. I shall take you as my daughter for now. Stay by my side until I find a husband of talent and looks to match you, then send you home.”

Da Qiao rejoiced, “My lord, you have given me life and will secure my future. Even if I repaid you with jade rings and bound grass in the afterlife, it would not suffice for a fraction of your kindness.” She drew a chair forward, “Father, please be seated while your child kowtows in gratitude for your rebirth of me.” The official sat without hesitation, watching her bow before rising to take his proper seat.

The next day, he hired two maids to attend Lady Da Qiao. Who was this official? None other than Chen Guozhu, father of Chen Yan—the same Chen Yan who had engaged Lu Yousheng as his tutor—now serving as Education Commissioner of Shaanxi, en route to assume his post. Da Qiao’s fortune had led her to this lifesaving benefactor, who would later bestow upon her wealth and honor. Alas, poor Master Pu and his wife had already been swallowed by the river’s fish, a pitiable fate indeed.

Upon taking office, Commissioner Chen governed with pristine integrity. Yet his unyielding nature and refusal to curry favor with superiors led to his impeachment by the provincial inspector after three years. Demoted to Prefect of Fuzhou, he set out for Fujian with Da Qiao in tow. Once settled, he sent for his family.

Meanwhile, Chen Yan—though dull-witted—had flourished under his tutor’s guidance. Their days passed in poetry and prose, their bond as close as flesh and blood, until three autumns had slipped by. One day, news arrived of his father’s demotion to Fuzhou Prefect. Though dismayed, Chen Yan took solace in the proximity of the post, where he could bring his aged parents and young siblings to share in his prosperity. Soon after, the messengers arrived, and he prepared to depart. Lu Yousheng sought to resign and return home, but Chen Yan pleaded so earnestly that he relented and accompanied them.

Upon reaching Fuzhou’s borders, porters, sedan chairs, and horses awaited. They entered the yamen, where the young lady paid her respects to her mother. Commissioner Chen recounted Da Qiao’s story to his wife, who exclaimed, “A daughter of such years, and you left her unmarried in Shaanxi for three years?” Chen replied, “She was born and raised in Wu. She must wed a man of her homeland so her parents may one day reunite.” His wife agreed, “That makes sense.”

That evening, a feast was laid, and Commissioner Chen invited his son’s tutor for conversation. Father, son, and teacher drank together. After several rounds, Chen remarked, “My son was once so unruly, but thanks to your guidance, his speech and manners have improved.” Lu Yousheng demurred, “Not at all. Your son is remarkably quick-witted, grasping ten things from one. I, long out of practice, fear I am unworthy to be his teacher. I hope you will not hold me accountable.” They exchanged tales of their journeys, discussed history and literature, and did not part until the night had deepened. The next day, the young master and his tutor resumed their studies in the rear garden.

*Though beauty and plainness differ in form,*
*Two lonely lamps burn in separate chambers.*

It was those bandits who abducted me from home—I hardened my heart and never returned. Had they not taken me, perhaps I might have relented. Now, nearing forty, I remain alone. *One misstep undoes the whole,*

My parents, now past sixty, cannot have me by their side. The fates of those two women—whether wed or widowed—I know not. Chaoyun and Qiaoqiao, unseen for twenty years, must have aged by now."*

Qiaoqiao reproached him: *"Sir, how could you be so heartless? Had you heeded my words, you would not be in this state today."*
Yousheng replied: *"I was foolish—twice deceived by others."*
Qiaoqiao said: *"Now, your destined bride is a lady of noble birth. If you repeat your past mistakes, you will never know marital bliss."*
Yousheng answered: *"I understand, I understand."*

[text missing] ...from the book chest and handed it to Chaoyun [text missing]."* Qiaoqiao then recounted the tale of their matchmaking efforts to Yousheng. He exclaimed: *"From your words, it seems you two have become ghosts of the Yellow Springs!"* Realizing they were indeed spirits, they fell silent, then vanished like the wind. He searched for the handkerchief, but it too had vanished. Reflecting on past events, he realized it had all been the work of ghosts. Though he had long treasured the handkerchief, harboring a secret dread, he now understood its origin and sighed deeply. But no more of this.

In truth, Qiaoqiao and Chaoyun had died with grievances unaddressed and wrongs unrighted, so their spirits sought to bind him to the plain woman as his wife. Though fate had decreed this union, it was their intervention that had brought it to pass. As for Lu Yousheng, upon waking from the dream, he surmised the noble lady must be Master Chen’s daughter. Why not bind our feet with the red thread and let us grow old together? Then we would both have a place in this world. And even if both consented, I have no means to approach them, nor can I ask another to propose on my behalf. To speak for myself would be improper, and if the old man refused, I would only invite humiliation, making things awkward between teacher and student. After endless deliberation, he concluded the matter was impossible—he could only *"quench his thirst by gazing at plums."* Meanwhile, the imperial examination was announced, and Master Chen’s son, wishing his tutor to assume the Chen surname and accompany him to the provincial exam, had Yousheng change his name to Chen Chong. “When I first married a man named Lu Shishan, I fled after the wedding ceremony. Later, I married Yan Yu, and again I fled. Now that I’ve wed you, sir, I feared you too would run away—so I only answered you with such hesitation.”

Yousheng replied, “From what you say, that Lu Shishan was me, that Yan Yu was me, and this Chen Chong who has married you today is also me. Could it be, my lady, that you are none other than the daughter of the Pu family and the young lady of the Kong household?”

Their words had only just crossed, and now they must make amends beneath the covers. One was a maiden past her prime yet still blossoming, the other a long-deprived virgin no longer young—what need for modesty, what cause for refusal? Their descendants flourished for ten thousand generations, proving that the affairs of the world—what man does not strive for yet comes to pass, what he does not seek yet attains—are all the work of Heaven and fate, not within mortal power. chunks.original_text: 建月宫嫦娥遭劫 诗曰： 月明风静野云间，把酒高歌乐自然。 世事如同棋一局，但存正道对苍天。 天道不正，则风雨愆期，人生灾励； 君道不正，则政治不修，民多奸诡； 人道不正，则帷薄不修，家多邪罔。 尧时廿年大水，周朝六月陨霜，汉代白虹贯日，玄宗遍野飞蝗，这是天道不正的所在。 还有君道不正的，如当初秦始皇灭了六国，天下一统，若肯忧勤惕励，修德行仁，传代子孙万世，也未可知。 忽然听信方士之言，赴海外去求神仙。 其时就有一个黄冠道士，见始皇东巡，伏谒道左，夸炫仙术，变幻神奇，历历如见。 始皇听他言语，半信半疑道：“朕因东巡，未遑接教，待回朝之日，差人召你与朕细谈。 ”道士告退，即驾一朵白云飘然而去。 始皇见他如此奇异，懊悔当面错过神仙，空劳海外跋涉，匆匆封了泰山，立时回朝。 早已这道士俯伏朝门之外，内官启奏始皇，即宣入宫，对坐谈玄，十分起敬。 始皇问他行踪，便答：“贫道苍梧北海，顷刻翱翔，那有定迹？ 只因天上玉清宫门槛，向□□檀槐梓，八宝装成，因年深日久，尽行蠹坏，贫道意□将银子筑实造成，以耐永久，并壮观瞻，不识陛下肯鉴微诚，大开弘愿否？ ”始皇道：“门槛之费能值几何！ 但不知宫门长短阔狭，也要比个数来。 ”道士道：“贫道已曾量过，长一丈一尺，阔二尺，高一尺，须得三万六千两方彀。 ”始皇即遣宫人将内帑钱粮如数发出。 即唤许多银匠，立限五日造成，四面雕凿龙凤花鸟，水□云纹，极其工巧。 始皇对道士说：“这样一条重槛，如何上得天去？ ”道士说：“不烦陛下过虑，贫道五日后亲自来领。 ”果然，到了五日之后，只见一只白鹤飞入宫来，将门槛衔于口中，犹如一苇之轻，飞向空中冉冉而上。 始皇伫目久之，见他竟入云中去了。 满宫之人，无不骇异，俱道天子福洪，有此奇遘。 始皇亦道自己福德所致，各各称扬不已。 谁知到了五年之后，那道士改扮俗妆，将一块银子到银铺内倾销。 银匠认得上有凤翅龙纹，像在皇宫所造的，即将银子兑换于他，施从所之，首告在县。 县官即差捕役多人，亲自到彼捕获。 那道士见了众人，知觉来意，将身一缩，竟入地中去了。 差人四下搜寻，并无踪迹。 直搜到大树根头，见有衣裳露出尺许，知县晓得是个妖道，即将猪狗血从空泼去。 众人掘下，这道士直僵僵立在土中，银门槛就在脚下。 众人拿起，将绳捆了，便把门槛掘开，用百数人扛拽而出，一同解赴始皇。 始皇旨下，将道士问了剐罪，银门槛依旧抬入宫来，归了内帑。 这是民生奸诡的所在。 如今单说一个人道不正的故事。 在嘉靖年间，浙江严州府遂安县地方，有个进士，姓郭名林，号仙公，曾任山东兖州太守，丁艰在家。 夫人元氏，年及五旬，生有一位公子、两位小姐。 公子名唤郭宗贤，年方一十九岁，早已采芹入泮。 大小姐年方十六，乳名珍珠，二小姐年方十二，乳名掌珠。 珍珠小姐生来情性闲雅，喜怒不形，爱吃的是清茶淡饭，爱穿的是缟衣素裳。 身面上若着一点浓艳的颜色，他就坐卧不安，必欲去之后已。 这样一个性情，要晓得体貌自然出人头地的了。
chunks.translated_text:
The Moon Palace’s Chang’e Suffers Calamity

*Poem:*
Beneath the bright moon, wind still in wild clouds’ span,
Wine in hand, I sing, delighting in nature’s plan.
Worldly affairs are but a game of chess,
Hold fast to the true Dao, and face the heavens’ span.

When the Dao of Heaven is not upright, wind and rain miss their season, and human life meets with disaster and hardship. When the Dao of the Ruler is not upright, governance falls into disrepair, and the people grow cunning and deceitful. When the Dao of Man is not upright, the inner chambers are not kept in order, and the household teems with perversity and falsehood.

In the time of Emperor Yao, there were twenty years of great floods; in the Zhou dynasty, frost fell in the sixth month; in the Han, a white rainbow pierced the sun; and in the reign of Emperor Xuanzong, locusts swarmed across the land—these were all signs of the Dao of Heaven being askew.

As for the Dao of the Ruler being askew, consider the First Emperor of Qin, who destroyed the six states and unified the realm. Had he been diligent and vigilant, cultivating virtue and practicing benevolence, his dynasty might have endured for ten thousand generations. Instead, he heeded the words of alchemists and journeyed beyond the seas in search of immortals.

At that time, a Daoist in a yellow cap, seeing the First Emperor on his eastern progress, prostrated himself by the roadside. Boasting of his immortal arts, he performed wondrous transformations, each more marvelous than the last. The First Emperor, half-believing, half-doubting, said, “As I am on my eastern tour, I have no leisure to receive your teachings. When I return to the capital, I shall send for you to speak with me at length.” The Daoist took his leave, then mounted a wisp of white cloud and drifted away.

Seeing such strangeness, the First Emperor regretted missing the immortal before him and cursed his futile journey beyond the seas. He hastily sealed Mount Tai and returned to the capital. There, the Daoist was already prostrate outside the palace gates. The eunuchs announced his presence, and the emperor summoned him into the palace. Seated in conversation on profound matters, the First Emperor held him in great esteem.

When asked of his whereabouts, the Daoist replied, “This poor Daoist roams from Cangwu to the Northern Sea in an instant—how could I have a fixed abode? The threshold of the Jade Purity Palace in Heaven was once inlaid with sandalwood, catalpa, and nanmu, adorned with the Eight Treasures. But over the years, it has rotted away. I wished to recast it in solid silver to endure forever and enhance its splendor. I wonder if Your Majesty would deign to approve this humble sincerity and generously fulfill this great vow?”

The First Emperor said, “How much could a threshold cost? But I must know its length, width, and height to calculate the amount.” The Daoist replied, “I have already measured it: eleven feet long, two feet wide, and one foot high. It will require thirty-six thousand taels of silver.”

The First Emperor immediately ordered eunuchs to deliver the sum from the inner treasury. He summoned many silversmiths and set a deadline of five days to complete the work. They carved dragons, phoenixes, flowers, birds, water ripples, and cloud patterns into it, crafting it with utmost skill.

The First Emperor asked the Daoist, “How will such a heavy threshold ascend to Heaven?” The Daoist replied, “Do not trouble Your Majesty with such concerns. This poor Daoist will return in five days to collect it.”

Sure enough, on the fifth day, a white crane flew into the palace, took the threshold in its beak as lightly as a reed, and soared into the sky. The First Emperor gazed after it for a long time, watching it vanish into the clouds. All in the palace were astonished, declaring that the Son of Heaven’s great fortune had brought about this wondrous encounter. The First Emperor, too, believed it was his own virtue and power that had wrought this marvel, and all praised him without end.

Who could have known that five years later, the Daoist would disguise himself in commoner’s garb and take a piece of silver to a silversmith’s shop to be melted down? The silversmith recognized the dragon and phoenix carvings as resembling those made in the imperial palace. He exchanged the silver but secretly followed the Daoist and reported him to the county authorities. The magistrate dispatched many constables to arrest him.

When the Daoist saw the crowd approaching, he realized their intent. With a twist of his body, he sank into the earth. The constables searched all around but found no trace of him. Only when they dug beneath a large tree did they see a foot of clothing protruding from the ground. The magistrate, knowing him to be a demonic Daoist, ordered pig and dog blood to be poured from above. As they dug, the Daoist stood stiff in the earth, the silver threshold at his feet.

They seized him, bound him with ropes, and pried open the threshold. A hundred men strained to drag it out, and together they escorted him to the First Emperor. By imperial decree, the Daoist was sentenced to death by slow slicing, and the silver threshold was carried back into the palace and returned to the inner treasury. This was a case of the people’s cunning and deceit.

Now, let us speak of a tale where the Dao of Man is not upright. During the Jiajing era of the Ming dynasty, in the region of Suian County, Yan Prefecture, Zhejiang, there lived a *jinshi* named Guo Lin, styled Xiangong. He had served as prefect of Yanzhou in Shandong but was then observing the mourning period for his parents at home. His wife, née Yuan, was fifty years old and had borne him one son and two daughters. Their son, Guo Zongxian, was nineteen and had already passed the county examinations. Their eldest daughter was sixteen, with the childhood name Zhenzhu, and their younger daughter was twelve, called Zhangzhu.

Miss Zhenzhu was born with a refined and elegant temperament, her joy and anger never showing on her face. She favored plain tea and simple meals, and preferred to wear unadorned white garments. If even a hint of bright color touched her person, she would be restless until she removed it. With such a disposition, one might well imagine her bearing to be naturally extraordinary.

chunks.original_text: 母亲见他如此妆束，常戏以嫦娥呼之。 一日中秋佳节，桂花盛开，郭仙公与夫人在厅前赏月观花，正是月映杯中，香浮席上。 酒至数巡，仙公道：“今日玉宇无尘，冰壶映彻，只少嫦娥开了月宫，幻作霓裳之舞。 ”夫人听见嫦娥二字，只道唤大女孩儿，忙对丫鬟道：“请大小姐出来。 ”丫鬟走进绣房，随了小姐行至阶下，夫人笑道：“嫦娥来了。 ”仙公将女儿定睛一看，浑身缟素□□□映花容，顾盈窈窕，宛然玉人相似。 对夫人道：“女儿虽似嫦娥，奈无广寒宫贮之。 ”只见珍珠小姐款步登堂。 见礼已毕，依傍坐下。 三人饮了几杯，看看月转西斜，收拾绮筵，归房就寝。 仙公想道：“女儿有此美质，俨似嫦娥，不若把后园起造一所月宫，将女儿贮在里面，然后招他一个状元的女婿，岂不光显门楣？ ”正是： 月中扳桂迎仙客，天下瞻云贺状元。 仙公一夜寻思，次早梳洗已毕，踱到后园，前前后后揣量一番，觉得基址蜗窄，难于布置，须得十亩闲旷之地，才可展舒。 踌躇道：“只好在城外择地便了。 ”当下随了两个家人，乘了小轿，离城数里，是个静僻去处，中有平洋大地，四望皆山，景致甚雅。 仙公差人访其业主，用价买了。 不日鸠工，费却五六千金，整整造了一年，果然十分齐整。 那时正值中秋前后，只见： 素宇横空，银河耿汉。 檐牙高琢，无须五彩施妆； 地势纡回，却借天花点缀。 管弦呕哑，常邀帝子之灵； 笑语喧和，半鼓湘妃之瑟。 明星炯炯，妆镜齐开； 冷袖□□，晓鬟初启。 脂水绝涨流之腻。 □兰霏冷艳之香。 白云片片飞出洞房，皓雪层层堆装素壁。 桂蕊散黄金之粟，蟾光吐白璧之烟。 漫拟琼楼琬室，偏宜玉女瑶娥。 却说仙公造完月宫，门楼上置一匾额，写着“广寒清虚之馆”。 珍珠小姐梳妆雅淡，点缀萧疏。 即差几房家人、十数侍女左右服事，送住在宫中，终日登山临水，赏月观花。 一日，到了黄昏，月朗星稀，云闲风静，小姐登凌霄阁上赏月。 到了二更时分，只见窗外膻风四起，草木震栗。 俄而鸦飞鹃乱，狐啸猿啼，都是伥司厉鬼，杂沓而来。 小姐即忙欲归卧房，又见临后走来却是一个白额猛虎，跳入阁中，将小姐一扑，衔了就走。 侍女在傍，惊得魂飞魄散，连忙传与苍头。 众人赶来，却不见了小姐。 大家忙了手脚，即时点走火把四山搜寻，绝夫影响。 星夜赶入城来，报知仙公夫妇。 仙公十分追悔，怨着夫人道：“好好一个女儿，将他比为嫦娥，如今离却月宫，不知那里去了。 ”夫人怨着仙公：“偌大女儿，本该放在身傍，谁人叫你造这勾魂的月宫，送了他性命！ ”两人互相怨怅，不胜悲楚，便随了家人出城来到月宫，痛哭一场。 差人满山寻觅骨殖归葬。 家人寻了数日，并不见影，也只得罢了。 仙公夫妻望空哭祭一番，将这些从人使女，依旧收拾回去，不在话下。 正是： 广寒宫里无人伴，哭杀嫦娥被虎衔。 且说山后就是兰□地方，有个樵夫姓金，原是市上卖柴为业。 夫妻二人年老无嗣。 忽一日街头遇着一个小子，年方六岁，身上衣服甚是华丽，相貌却也端庄。 两眼望着，南北张皇，东西回顾，却原来是个迷失路途，汪汪泪落。 金老领他回来，当作螟蛉之子，取名金玉。
chunks.translated_text:
Her mother, seeing her in such attire, would often jestingly call her "Chang'e." One day, during the Mid-Autumn Festival when osmanthus blooms were in full splendor, Master Guo and his wife were in the hall admiring the moon and flowers—moonlight shimmering in their cups, fragrance wafting over their mats. After several rounds of wine, Master Guo sighed, "Today the jade heavens are spotless, the crystal vase radiant and clear. Only the Moon Palace lacks Chang'e to open its gates and dance in rainbow-hued robes."

Hearing the word *Chang'e*, his wife assumed he was calling for their eldest daughter and promptly instructed a maid, "Summon the eldest young lady." The maid entered the embroidered chamber and escorted Miss Zhenzhu to the steps below. Lady Yuan smiled, "Chang'e has arrived." Master Guo fixed his gaze upon his daughter—her plain white garments set off her flower-like countenance, her graceful bearing akin to a jade maiden. Turning to his wife, he remarked, "Though our daughter resembles Chang'e, alas, we have no Guanghan Palace to house her."

Miss Zhenzhu then stepped delicately into the hall. After exchanging courtesies, she sat beside them. The three shared several cups of wine until the moon began its westward descent. The feast was cleared, and they retired to their chambers.

That night, Master Guo mused, "Our daughter possesses such beauty, so like Chang'e—why not build a Moon Palace in the rear garden to keep her there? Then we might seek a zhuangyuan son-in-law to marry her, and our family’s prestige would shine even brighter." Indeed:
*Plucking osmanthus in the moon to welcome immortal guests,*
*The world gazes in awe at the zhuangyuan’s cloud-borne glory.*

Master Guo pondered this all night. The next morning, after washing and dressing, he strolled to the rear garden, surveying the grounds. Finding the space too cramped for his vision, he muttered, "We’ll need ten acres of open land to do this properly. Best to choose a site outside the city." He then took two servants, boarded a small sedan chair, and traveled several *li* beyond the city walls to a secluded spot. There lay a vast, level expanse, surrounded by mountains on all sides—a most refined setting. Master Guo sent men to inquire about the landowner and purchased the plot at a fair price.

Construction began without delay. After spending five or six thousand taels and a full year of labor, the palace stood complete—truly magnificent. It was just before Mid-Autumn when one beheld:
*A pristine edifice spanning the sky, the Silver River gleaming bright.*
*Eaves carved high, needing no painted adornment;*
*The winding terrain, graced by celestial blossoms.*
*Music and pipes resounded, invoking the spirit of the Moon Goddess;*
*Laughter and chatter mingled, half-echoing the zither of the Xiang Consorts.*
*Bright stars glowed like mirrors arrayed;*
*Cool sleeves fluttered as morning tresses were dressed.*
*Perfumed waters flowed free of grease;*
*Orchids exhaled their icy, fragrant breath.*
*White clouds drifted from the bridal chamber,*
*Layered snow adorned the pale walls.*
*Osmanthus petals scattered golden grains,*
*Toad-light exhaled jade-like mist.*
*Though likened to jasper towers and jade halls,*
*It was fit only for moon maidens and fairy consorts.*

When the Moon Palace was finished, Master Guo had a plaque mounted above the gate inscribed: *The Hall of Vast Cold and Emptiness*. Miss Zhenzhu, with her simple and elegant adornments, lent the place a sparse charm. He assigned several households of servants and a dozen maidservants to attend her, then sent her to reside in the palace. There, she spent her days climbing hills, gazing upon waters, admiring the moon, and enjoying the flowers.

One evening, as dusk fell with a bright moon and sparse stars, the wind still and clouds at rest, Miss Zhenzhu ascended the Tower of Soaring Skies to admire the moon. By the second watch, a foul wind suddenly arose outside the window, shaking the grass and trees. Soon, crows scattered and cuckoos cried in disarray, while foxes howled and gibbons shrieked—all manner of malevolent spirits converging in chaos. Before Miss Zhenzhu could retreat to her chamber, a white-browed tiger leapt onto the terrace, pounced upon her, and carried her off in its jaws. The maidservants nearby were struck with terror, their souls scattering in fright. They hurriedly alerted the steward, and the household rushed to the scene—only to find their young mistress gone.

In a panic, they lit torches and scoured the mountains, but found no trace. That very night, they hastened back to the city to inform Master Guo and his wife. Overcome with regret, Master Guo reproached his wife, "Our fine daughter—we compared her to Chang'e, yet now she has vanished from the Moon Palace, gone who knows where." His wife, in turn, blamed him: "Such a grown girl should have stayed by our side! Who asked you to build this soul-snatching Moon Palace, sending her to her doom?" The two lamented bitterly, then followed their servants to the palace outside the city, where they wept in sorrow. They sent men to search the mountains for her remains, intending to bury them, but after days of fruitless searching, they had no choice but to abandon the effort. Master Guo and his wife offered a skyward lament before gathering their servants and maids to return home. Truly:
*In the Moon Palace, none to keep her company—*
*Chang'e weeps, carried off by a tiger’s jaws.*

Beyond the mountain lay the Lan□ region, where a woodcutter named Jin lived. He and his wife, both elderly, had no children. One day, while selling firewood in the market, they encountered a boy of about six, dressed in fine, resplendent clothes. His bearing was dignified, yet his eyes darted about in confusion, tears streaming as he wandered lost. Old Jin took him home, treating him as an adopted son, and named him Jin Yu.

chunks.original_text: 恐他晓得父母的来历，日后认得回家，金老到搬家眷入山居住，远却市上百有余里。 日常也不许他轻易在人前出口，所以山中人不知来历，竟认以为亲生儿子一般。 后来金老夫妻去世，他就接着砍柴生意，年已将近一十。 一日，早起上山砍柴，阴风惨惨，白露漫漫。 转过山湾，只见一个陷虎阱中隐隐妇人啼哭声响。 金玉上前张望，却是一个绝美妇人，珠翠满头，仰天号泣，叫道：“救命！ 救命！ ”金玉想道：“这样一个妇人，救他起来，不要说嫁我为妻，只这一头珠玉，也应谢我。 ”连忙把那阱木放开，解去绳子。 无奈这阱底有数丈之深，难于布摆。 想了一会，便向扁挑头拿条缚柴索子，解开放下。 那妇人捏定索头，随势而上。 将金玉倒头四拜。 金玉正待开口问他来历，那妇人向空□跳，变成一个老虎，咆哮而去。 惊得那金玉满地乱滚。 少顷看时，不知去向。 金玉想了，甚是诧异，依旧上山砍柴。 不说金玉一路寻思，且把这老虎的来历说个明白。 却说兰□山中□嘴崖上有个道士，姓萧，名道延。 他在这个所在，餐松食柏，养气修元，功夫已成八九。 一日魔头到来，思量要吃生人脑子。 闭目坐在崖上想道：“须是变了老虎，方得此食。 ”偶然到一庙里，佛柜之下藏着一张虎皮，道士将来穿了。 想起《云笈七签》内有黄鼠三变神咒，窣地变成一个猛虎，雄心陡发，横行山曲，见人便啖。 因此惊动地方，人人畏怖。 官府差猎户随山掘阱，即地张罗。

Fearing the boy might learn of his parents' origins and one day return home, Old Jin moved his family deep into the mountains, over a hundred *li* from the market town. He also forbade the boy from speaking freely before others, so that none in the mountains knew his true background, and all took him for their own son. Later, when Old Jin and his wife passed away, Jin Yu continued the firewood trade, and by then he was nearly ten years old.

One morning, he rose early to gather firewood. A gloomy wind moaned, and a thick white mist clung to the ground. As he rounded a bend in the mountain path, he heard faint sobbing from a tiger pit—a woman’s voice. Jin Yu stepped forward to look and saw a woman of breathtaking beauty, her hair adorned with pearls and jade, wailing to the heavens. "Save me! Save me!" she cried. The next morning, a rattling sound arose from the tiger’s throat. With a roll upon the ground, the tiger pelt fell away. The young lady rose, straightened her robes and sash, and stood as a woman of beauty surpassing even Chang’e. Overcome with joy, Jin Yu smiled at her and said, *“Now you shall come every night—”*

She blushed but made no reply. The Daoist then urged Jin Yu to act as matchmaker for the couple, and they renewed their vows with fresh wedding rites. The Daoist, having secured the tiger pelt upon himself, recited the divine incantation, leapt through the gate, and vanished into the depths of the mountains.

Little did they know that misfortune was fated for those mountains. With this creature now among them, none—man, woman, young, or old—who crossed its path escaped being devoured. Within half a year, the mountain’s beasts and the village’s people were all consumed. As its hunger grew, it took on human and demonic guises, luring prey into its jaws with ever greater cunning. Truly:

*A tiger in the marketplace is no true tiger,
A man in the mountains is no true man.
The world’s upended fortunes arise
From the collapse of rightful judgment in the home.*

This thread shall be set aside for now.

Meanwhile, Master Guo the Immortal, still grieving the loss of his daughter to the tiger and the strange events in the Moon Palace, felt deep melancholy. Some days later, a letter arrived from the capital. He opened it to find that his former classmate, Zhang Cunshu, had been newly appointed Minister of Personnel. Knowing Guo’s mourning period had ended, Zhang had sent the letter to cordially invite him to the capital to assume a new post. Overjoyed, Guo wrote a reply, dispatched the messenger, and began preparing his luggage for the journey. Within a month, he arrived in the capital and called upon Minister Zhang.

After the formalities, Zhang said, *“My elder brother’s lofty retreat and joy in the clouds mark you as a dragon among men. I, in my humble role as Minister of Personnel, pale in comparison to the likes of Du and Zheng—truly, I am ashamed.”*

Guo the Immortal replied, *“Your Excellency’s rank is as high as the Northern Dipper, your talents as towering as the Central Terrace. In this era of peace and order, you are well-placed to record worthy names in the imperial archives. Your Excellency’s wisdom and magnanimity mirror the heavens, and your promotion of the able without regard to seniority—”*

Hearing these words, Zhang sensed Guo’s willingness to return to office and said, *“Your esteemed name has long rested in my records. That is why I sent for you—”*

Guo feigned modesty before taking his leave. The next day, he returned the visit, and they discussed his appointment. The imperial decree soon arrived, and the Ministry of Personnel confirmed his post as Prefect of Fuzhou. Guo bade farewell to Minister Zhang and departed the capital. His journey home was uneventful, and upon arrival, he made preparations for his new office. Choosing an auspicious day, he set out for his post and arrived within a month.

After offering incense and opening the yamen to receive petitions, we shall set aside the account of Guo the Immortal’s governance—pure as flowing water—and turn instead to his son, Guo Zongxian. After a year in office, Guo had sent his son home to prepare for the imperial examinations. The young master returned to the prefecture after passing the preliminary trials and was en route back when, passing through Chuzhou, he encountered dark clouds gathering and thunder crashing. Unable to proceed, he said to his steward, *“The wind and rain rage together—let us take shelter in this temple.”*

Entering the temple gates, he looked up to see it was dedicated to the Great Exorcist Emperor. Guo bowed four times and sat upon the prayer mat, waiting for the rain to cease. But the storm only worsened, continuing unabated until dusk. He asked his steward, *“How far is the nearest inn?”*

*“Over ten li,”* the steward replied.

*“We shall have to stay here for the night,”* Guo said. He instructed the temple keeper to prepare the evening meal. After eating, they settled in for the night.

Meanwhile, Xiao Daoyan sat upon Iron-Beak Crag when suddenly his body was wracked with excruciating pain, as though scalding oil poured upon his crown. With a great cry, he opened his eyes to find himself surrounded by grass grown three feet deep. Xiao Daoyan thought, “A moment’s wayward thought summoned the demonic, and unknowing, I sat with eyes closed, committing two years of transgressions. Reflecting on all that came before and after, I am struck with dread. Could this have been but a dream of my soul—did I truly bring harm to the living?” He descended to villages and towns, questioning every passerby, tracing the path of his visions, and found all to match his dream in every detail. Returning to the mountain, remorse weighed heavily upon his heart: “Having harmed thousands of living beings, how can I attain true fruition? Below this Iron-Beak Crag lies an abyss of ten thousand fathoms—let me cast myself into it, shattering body and bone to atone before Heaven.” With that, he leapt. Yet midair, a wisp of white cloud bore him aloft, and he ascended in broad daylight. Only then did Xiao Daoyan realize that those mauled by the tiger had met their destined end: “Heaven merely borrowed my form to bring their fates to pass—it had naught to do with me.” Free and at ease, he departed.

Later, that tiger skin would bring about the reunion of a golden couple, but that is another tale.

As for Miss Pearl, thanks to the Daoist who had stripped the tiger skin from her, she and Jin Yu were wed. Though Jin Yu had savings, they earned no interest, and day by day their wealth dwindled. Thus, they opened a tavern before their home. One day, Jin Yu went to collect debts outside the city and returned at dusk to find Miss Pearl gone. Questioning the neighbors, he learned that her elder brother had taken her away. Jin Yu thought, “She once told me her father was a prefect and her brother a scholar. If only I knew where they had taken her, where could I even begin to search? We were wed without matchmaker or betrothal gifts—even if I found them, what could they return to me? Perhaps Miss Pearl will not forget my kindness, and we may meet again someday.” He wept day and night, but of this, no more need be said.

Meanwhile, Master Guo Zongxian, having captured the tiger demon, recovered his sister, and obtained the tiger skin—three strokes of unexpected fortune—set off for home with his retinue. Along the way, he pondered the depth of Lord Guan’s verse, its meaning only revealed in hindsight. The final line, *water’s edge, a chicken flies*, hinted at the character for “wine,” and indeed, his sister had been found in a tavern. The prophecy’s precision filled him with joy. Only Miss Pearl grew dismayed, for she had assumed her parents lived nearby and that she would reunite with them briefly before returning home. Yet after ten days of travel, they still had not dismounted. “Had I known the parting would be so distant,” she lamented, “I would have at least bid my husband farewell and secured our trunks.” Lost in hesitation, she scarcely noticed their arrival at the prefectural gate. Guo entered the yamen with his sister, and their parents, overcome with grief and joy, embraced their daughter. Miss Pearl recounted her encounter with the tiger in the Moon Palace, while Guo described the scheme by which he had captured the beast. Their parents marveled at the tale.

Now, there was a censor of the Ministry of Justice named Zhu Jinchen, whose wife, née Tao, had passed her fiftieth year. They had two sons and a daughter: the elder son, Zhu Yu; the younger, Zhu Jue. When Zhu Jinchen had first been appointed, he was assigned to serve as a judicial commissioner in Qingzhou. En route with his family, they were scattered by bandits, and Zhu Yu’s whereabouts became unknown. At the time, Zhu Jue was of marriageable age, and Magistrate Guo had betrothed Miss Pearl to him. The six rites were complete, the three matchmakers had done their work, and only the wedding date remained to be set. Then, a man and his wife approached, saying, “If... then how could I...?” Miss Pearl had pleaded with her parents repeatedly... and at last devised a plan to extricate herself from the predicament.

One evening, Miss Pearl feigned a sharp pain in her heart, crying out incessantly. Her mother, alarmed, asked what ailed her. She replied, “This is the old affliction from my time as a tiger—it will only cease if I cover myself with the tiger skin.” Her mother immediately draped the skin over her, and Miss Pearl’s cries of pain subsided. From then on, she kept the skin with her at all times.

When the wedding day arrived and the bridal sedan had come, Miss Pearl dressed herself in full finery. Her mother placed the tiger skin inside the sedan as a cushion. Miss Pearl stepped into the sedan, and Magistrate Guo saw her off as she was carried to the Zhu residence. Once there, she donned the tiger skin and recited the divine incantation. Just as the master of ceremonies began the rites and the guests lifted the sedan curtain, Miss Pearl leapt out in a bound, transforming into a tiger with several great strides before vanishing through the main gate. The guests scattered in terror, exclaiming in astonishment. Magistrate Guo, beside himself with rage, could only stare blankly at the others. Unwilling to reveal the truth, he followed their lead in feigning bewilderment, calling off the feast and ordering his sedan to return to the yamen. The guests dared not press him to stay and took their leave.

Zhu Jinchen fumed, “This is clearly Magistrate Guo deceiving me! I must draft a memorial to impeach him and vent my anger.” The guests replied, “One can feign many things, but how could one feign a tiger?” Zhu pondered this and, finding no recourse, let the matter drop.

Meanwhile, Miss Pearl, having escaped the Zhu residence, leapt over the city wall and fled with the speed of the wind. Within days, she arrived in Chuzhou. There, she shed the tiger skin and returned to her own doorstep. Jin Yu, seeing her from the shop, rushed out to greet her with unbounded joy. Once inside, Miss Pearl recounted all that had transpired. Jin Yu said, “Your devotion is most rare, my lady. But I am a man of humble station—how can I be worthy of the daughter of a prefectural governor?” Miss Pearl replied, “Since we pledged our lives to each other, what matter high or low?” Truly, there is no joy like returning home after a long absence. That night, their happiness need not be described.

As for Magistrate Guo, upon returning from the ill-fated wedding, he was nearly driven to his death by fury. His wife, seeing their daughter once more transformed into a tiger and gone, wept inconsolably. Their son said, “Do not grieve, my parents. It would be best to send the whole household to Chuzhou to inquire at the wine shop. Perhaps she, unwilling to remarry, has returned to her original husband—who can say?” They immediately dispatched a servant, who traveled without incident until he reached the wine shop. There, he asked the owner about Miss Pearl. Hearing this, she emerged from within and summoned the servant inside. She inquired after her parents’ well-being and all that had occurred since their parting, and the servant dutifully recounted everything. Miss Pearl then ordered the kitchen to prepare a meal for him, and the next day, she sent him home.

Upon his return, the servant reported all that had transpired. Magistrate Guo, left with no other choice, conferred with his wife and decided to send their son with servants to bring their daughter home, that their family might be reunited and she might be spared the hardships of poverty. His wife was overjoyed, and they summoned Guo Zongxian to inform him of the plan. The young master set out at once. Upon arriving at Jin Yu’s home, he was received by his sister, and Jin Yu came to greet his brother-in-law with every courtesy—needless to say.

The next day, Guo Zongxian relayed his parents’ wishes to the couple. Jin Yu promptly settled the affairs of the wine shop, forgoing all debts, packed their belongings, and hired porters and horses for the journey. Their departure need not be recounted here.

Meanwhile, Zhu Jinchen, having learned of Miss Pearl’s origins, prepared to welcome her home within days. He dispatched many servants and attendants to intercept her along the way. Sure enough, as Guo Zongxian’s procession returned with their carriages and horses, Zhu’s steward blocked their path and seized Jin Yu and Miss Pearl, carrying them away. The young master and his retinue gave chase, following them all the way to Zhu Jinchen’s gate, where they saw the two being taken inside. Guo Zongxian, at a loss, hurried home to report what had happened.

Magistrate Guo said, “Do not panic. If your sister submits to him, then so be it.”

Meanwhile, the servants had already concealed Miss Pearl in a bedchamber and written a calling card, sending Jin Yu to the county yamen with orders for the magistrate to execute him at once. The servants brought Jin Yu before the magistrate, who ascended the bench and received the card. After hearing the account, the magistrate summoned Jin Yu and asked, "Are you called Jin Yu?"

Jin Yu replied, "This humble one was originally named Zhu Yu. I recall my father’s name was Zhu Jinchen. He was once appointed judicial commissioner of Qingzhou Prefecture. When my family traveled to assume his post, we were set upon by bandits. It was night, and everyone fled in panic. I became lost in the region of Yanzhou Prefecture, where a family named Jin took me in and raised me—hence my name, Jin Yu."

The magistrate asked, "How old were you then?"

"Six years old. I am now twenty-three."

The magistrate found his story perplexing and thought, *"This old Zhu is causing trouble again—demanding I take the life of his own son!"* He summoned the steward and inquired further. To the steward, he said, "Seventeen years ago, did your master encounter bandits?"

The steward pondered a moment before replying, "Yes. Seventeen years ago, my master was appointed judicial commissioner of Qingzhou. While traveling with his family to Zhejiang’s Yanzhou Prefecture, our eldest young master disappeared. We assumed he had fallen into the river and drowned."

The magistrate pointed to Jin Yu. "Do you recognize this man?"

The steward rubbed his eyes and studied him closely. The face bore a resemblance. He cried out, "Could this be our young master Zhu?"

Jin Yu also recognized the steward as Zhu En and exclaimed in surprise. Zhu En rushed forward and embraced him. The magistrate then ordered the steward to take Jin Yu home to his father.

Zhu En returned with Jin Yu—*(text missing)*—long-lost kin, separated by fate, for which none could be blamed. Only the sacred verses of the Demon-Quelling Emperor had foretold all that came to pass.

Before the words were finished, the moon had crossed the western gallery, and dawn broke in the east. The feast dispersed. Truly:

*What once was a tale of demonic woe,*
*Now blooms as a bond of joyful matrimony.*

Thereafter, Zhu Yu and his two brothers engaged a tutor and studied diligently, ultimately becoming men of renown. They passed the imperial examinations and ascended to official ranks, serving in the Bureau of Appointments. Pearl was ennobled as a First-Rank Lady, while Guo Zongxian and Zhu Juan also passed the provincial examinations and entered public service. Both families were blessed with descendants for generations, their official stars shining brightly.

As for the tiger pelt, the young lady cherished it like Pearl herself, regarding it as a treasure for protection. Yet after being stored away for three years, when retrieved, it resembled a mangy dog—its hide and fur split apart. Truly a priceless gem turned worthless, not even a single coin’s value, becoming a laughingstock for later generations. Indeed:

*To see the strange and not be strange,*
*The strange will of itself decay.*

Earlier, a tale was told of the unrighteousness of Heaven’s Dao; later, another of the unrighteousness of the ruler’s Dao. This chronicle, however, recounts a story of the unrighteousness of human Dao giving rise to strange occurrences within a household.

Had Pearl’s parents regarded their daughter with ordinary affection, she might have lived in obscurity. Why, then, was she likened to Chang’e, building a vast Moon Palace deep in the mountains, only to encounter a sorcerous rogue, ensnared in his web? Fortunately, after years of hardship, she did not fall into the hands of wicked men. This, too, was predestined by the threads of fate, destined to reunite in a most wondrous way.

**Chapter One, Volume Five: The Fisherman Dwelling by the River**

*Verse:*
A bee’s sting may yet be cured with medicine,
But a woman’s jealousy knows no remedy.
Since ancient times, how many bearded men
Have bowed low before the curtains, humbled by silken sashes?

Among the mindless creatures of heaven and earth, even those harboring venom strike only when provoked, relying on claws and fangs to defend themselves—this is their nature, not malice. Yet a woman’s heart is a realm of divine transformation, ever more cunning, concealing filth where none would think to look, inflicting the cruelest harm. This is deliberate malice—how could its venom not surpass that of vipers and scorpions?

These words come from one who has suffered great injustice at a woman’s hands, venting the grievance of a wrong unredressed. For women are by nature yin and yielding: yin restrains yang, softness overcomes hardness. Thus even the most unyielding of men find their edge dulled before a woman, their brows meekly lowered. A wise woman, encountering such a man, responds with humility and courtesy, exceeding all caution. When both adjust like water to vessel, their harmony is perfect—this is a woman of virtue.

But an unworthy woman feigns airs, plays the coquette, and indulges her whims. The slightest dissatisfaction sends her into fits—refusing food and drink, raging day and night. She must have the last word, the final logic, and even then, she seeks parting verses, compares him to some distant fool, only then falling silent.

There was once a woman who, disdaining her husband’s poverty, turned her heart elsewhere and sang a different tune. The phoenix crown inlaid with eight treasures, the cloud-patterned robe woven in five colors—finery she wore with ease—she cast aside without a thought. What a pity!

This was none other than Cui, wife of Zhu Maichen of Burnt Axe Mountain, who despised her husband’s poverty and his livelihood of selling firewood. At forty-nine, her patience worn thin, she took up another’s lute, seeking mere warmth and fullness. Such is the fickleness of women, their hearts as shifting as willow catkins, lacking steadfastness. Yet it was also the fault of a household without discipline, allowing a meddling nun to sow discord and breed this calamity.

Some say: *"This woman was born under the Iron Broomstar—had she not left, Zhu Maichen would have remained impoverished forever, with no hope of prosperity."* Though such is the talk of men, the true principle is to endure hardship with one’s husband.

These old tales need not be retold.

Now let us speak of a woman most venomous—one who deceived the eyes of all, secretly conspired with monks, and brought about her husband’s death, only to meet a fate far more wretched than that of Cui. Her wickedness was twice as great.

This tale unfolds in the Zhide era of the Yuan dynasty, in Fushun County, Sichuan. There lived a scholar named Zhang Yong. His father, Zhang Lü, had been a man of considerable wealth, but both parents passed early, and the young man neglected all livelihood. For years he lived idly off his inheritance until his fortune was squandered. His wife, née Liu, styled Chunniang, was a woman of humble birth—fiercely cruel, diligent only in eating and sloth. Zhang Yong, lured by her modest dowry, and her father, drawn by his scholar’s status, sealed the match. Yet within a month of marriage, discord arose—though we need not dwell on such trifles.

At the time, the land had only just begun to recover from the chaos of the *jie ding* uprisings, when suddenly famine struck. What a dire season it was!

Silkworms reared, fields must still be sown—
No rest for young or old, the whole household worn.
Then came the plum rains, day after day,
And all the level plains stretched bleak and gray.

The deluge was fiercer than the floods of primordial times. The Dragon Gate’s waterfall became a plain; hills and mounds turned to yawning chasms. For two full months the waters raged before the skies cleared. Yet even then, the millet was lost, the floods unyielding—farmers craned their necks in despair, helpless to act. Only by early autumn did the waters recede.

Fearing tax shortages, the county magistrate toured the countryside to urge the people to till the land. Households toiled with all their might, reclaiming eight or nine parts of the drowned fields. As the shoots lengthened and greened, the farmers rejoiced, their hopes rising. But Heaven, it seemed, was bent on disaster, and the people’s fate was sealed. When they needed rain, the skies poured; when they needed sun, the heavens withheld it. So it went at summer’s end and autumn’s dawn—jewels and pearls of rain, they called it. The ditches and gullies might have drawn moisture from the rivers, but instead, the land grew parched. Bamboo leaves and banana fronds turned ashen; fish scales in the streams exhaled a ghostly mist. By then, there was no water to draw, and the fields cracked under the sun. Dragonflies swarmed, and all hope of harvest faded.

In such times, the rich hoarded grain, while the poor wailed in despair. Truly:

At home, the cauldrons gathered dust, and the hearths stood cold, their smoke long since vanished. Cries of despair filled the roads, sighs echoing through every lane. This was the work of a malevolent sun, the blight of the drought demon—half the fields drowned in floods, the rest withered by drought. Grass roots and tree bark became treasures, while a single drop of water from the ditches was as precious as nectar. The people starved until smoke seemed to rise from their mouths, their faces sallow as withered greens.

The local officials submitted reports of the famine, and the emperor, well aware of the people’s plight, read the memorial with a heavy heart. He ordered grain distributed to relieve the starving. All officials, whether in office or retired, were ranked by grade and required to donate a portion of their salaries to the relief effort.

But let us turn from the emperor’s benevolence to Zhang Yong and his wife, who faced this famine in dire straits. Liu Chunniang spent her days in a frenzy, demanding wine and food regardless of whether there was any to be had. If her wants went unmet, she would wail and weep, her tantrums unending. One day, Chunniang was quarreling with her husband, insisting he find some profitable trade. Zhang Yong was a scholar—unable to bear even light burdens, let alone heavy ones—what business could he possibly manage? Their argument escalated until blows were exchanged.

Just then, an old man passed by their door. Seeing the couple fighting, he stepped inside to mediate. This old man was none other than their former neighbor from three years past, who had since moved to the riverside after his business failed, now making a living as a fisherman. He had only one child, a daughter of twelve or thirteen. Honest and sincere, he was known to all as Yang Laoshi. Seeing the couple’s bitter quarrel, he entered out of lingering affection for their past friendship and tried to calm them.

This intervention would set in motion a chain of events:
The monkey’s death in Chu doomed the forest,
The city gate’s fire scorched the pond’s fish.
A disaster would unfold, nearly sending one soul to the Yellow Springs, leaving the west wind to bear its regret.

But that is a tale for later.

Now, Yang Laoshi stepped inside to find the couple no longer locked in blows but seated, tallying grievances one by one, their sobs unceasing.
