Old Liu asked, “How old is he this year? What is his name?”

The vegetable vendor replied, “He is thirteen this year, and his name is Wunan.”

Old Liu asked, “Why was he given such a name?”

The vendor answered, “When he was small, a fortune-teller said he would face many hardships, so we named him thus. If he were adopted by another family, he might avoid them.”

Old Liu, seeing the boy’s refined features and having just returned the golden earpick, felt nine parts out of ten of fondness for him. He asked, “If you were to have him adopted, what kind of family would you prefer?”

The vendor said, “Adoption is best with a childless family. If they already have a son, the adopted child would be treated half as a son and half as a servant—carrying books, holding umbrellas, enduring scoldings and beatings, and never valued. But if the family has no son, adopting him to continue the ancestral line, they would naturally cherish and care for him. They would send him to school in his youth, arrange his marriage when he grows up, and ensure he learns a trade to secure his future.”

Old Liu said, “For example, a family like ours—would you trust us?”

The vendor exclaimed, “Oh! How could we ever aspire to the honor of your esteemed household, Master Liu?”

Old Liu replied, “That is not what I mean. When arranging marriages, one considers whether families are well-matched in status, but for adoption, all that matters is whether the child appears capable of growth, and whether the adoptive father is honest and dependable. Wealth or poverty does not matter—it can still be settled.”

The vendor said, “Your household is certainly suitable, Master Liu. I only fear my son is not fortunate enough.”

Old Liu said, “You need not be so modest. If you are truly willing, tomorrow is the fourteenth, and the day after, I will visit Blind Li at the east end to divine a reading. We can finalize it then.”

Overjoyed at Old Liu’s words, the vendor dared not refuse and immediately said, “Master Liu, it is settled.”

Both families had made up their minds, awaiting the judgment of the gods to confirm the outcome. Chunniang, who had been standing nearby with the copper coins for some time, only handed them over once their conversation ended. The vendor took the coins, expressed his thanks, and left.

Old Liu placed the earpick back into Chunniang’s hair, then went inside with her to tell their mother about the matter. Old Mrs. Liu was overjoyed upon hearing the news, but no more of that need be said.

As for the vegetable vendor, he was none other than the younger brother of Blind Li the diviner—Li San. Li San was eager to have his son adopted by the Liu family but feared an unfavorable divination might ruin such a fine opportunity, which was hard to come by. The next morning, he hurried to inform Blind Li, explaining in detail Old Liu’s intention to adopt a son. He instructed, “If he comes to ask for a divination, do everything you can to ensure it goes well. Once my son is adopted, I will repay you generously in time.”

Blind Li replied, “That will be no trouble at all.”

In the *Nei Ze* chapter, it is written: when a boy reaches seven, he must no longer share a seat or meals with girls; after eight or nine, upon turning ten, he is to leave home for his tutor and reside outside. Know that the words in books always hold profound reason. Yet how many households today understand this principle? Carelessly and without discernment, they conceal countless transgressions and let many slip through unnoticed. Even when parents become aware, they dismiss it as a family disgrace not to be aired, and so they cover it up.

From the moment one is born, is there anything not first seen with one’s own eyes before it is understood? Is there any matter not first spoken of by others before it is grasped? Yet the stirrings of youthful desire are different. Young imps, though untaught, somehow grasp its subtle intricacies. Chunniang was now ten—an age of knowing and yet not knowing. Unavoidably, she would listen at the bedside to her parents’ intimacies, finding them intriguing, assuming such things were common knowledge and permissible for all. Within less than a year, she and Zhangtai began exchanging sly glances, their eyes speaking volumes. At first, they remained close in their parents’ presence, but gradually, their boldness grew. With mutual understanding, they sought out secluded spots, where their trysts became as effortless as reaching into a pocket for a trinket.

Their parents, noticing their absence, would merely call them back without suspicion. Unaware, they allowed the two to carry on, until at last, the pair began engaging in acts as intimate as grinding navels to share breath.

One day, Mother Liu sewed a white silk skirt for Chunniang, and no sooner had she put it on than she and Zhangtai slipped away to the rear garden to amuse themselves. They did not return until two full watches had passed. Their mother scolded them a few times, then let the matter drop. After the evening meal, the family retired to their rooms. As Chunniang approached the bed and began to remove her skirt, Mother Liu took it from her to fold. But in the lamplight, she was truly startled by what she saw:

Dots like rouge freshly dyed,
Scattered as peach and apricot blossoms adorned.
The young scholar’s greedy heart,
The fair maiden’s tender shyness—
In one morning’s chaos,
Powder faded, fragrance vanished.
Clearly, the fragrant bud had been crushed,
Its jade-like petals bruised by dew.

Mother Liu, bewildered by the stains on the skirt, grew flustered. The truth of the matter would soon be revealed.

**Book Five, Second Tale: The Alluring Seductress Embraces the Monk**

Mother Liu questioned Chunniang, “Daughter, have you developed sores or boils down there? Why didn’t you tell your mother?”

Chunniang replied, “No, I haven’t.”

Mother Liu called her daughter to the lamplight, pulled open the skirt, and demanded, “Then what is *this*?”

Chunniang looked and saw:

Peach blossoms on the verge of fading,
Seeming to drift onto her cheeks;
Fresh buds just unfurling,
Gradually blooming upon her face.
Her moth-like brows knit in distress,
Her whole body as if seated on pins and needles;
Her phoenix eyes dazed and lost,
Her heart fluttering like a startled fawn.
Her complexion unsettled,
Her words hesitant and vague.
Her face resembled a fruit vendor’s stall—
Patches of green, clusters of purple—
Yet she could not utter a single word in reply.

Mother Liu, at that moment, felt like an earthworm in the field, her belly filled with mud. She thought, *“Has my daughter’s maidenhead been taken? If not, where did this bloody stain on the skirt come from?”*

By then, Zhangtai had heard every word clearly but feigned sleep, remaining silent. Mother and daughter fussed and chattered, then finally went to bed.

That night, Mother Liu pondered the matter carefully, never suspecting Zhangtai. The next morning, after Zhangtai had left for school, she barred the door, took up a thick piece of firewood, and made Chunniang kneel before her for questioning. Chunniang, believing such matters were permissible, saw no harm in confessing and recounted everything without hesitation.

Upon hearing this, Mother Liu was so enraged she nearly died. Instead of beating her daughter, she collapsed to the ground, wailing and weeping uncontrollably. Just then, Old Man Liu returned, only to find the door shut and his wife sobbing inside. He hurriedly called for it to be opened and asked what had happened. Mother Liu told him of their daughter’s scandalous affair.

Old Man Liu, upon hearing this, stormed to the school, dragged Zhangtai back, and was about to beat the wretched boy to death. Mother Liu intervened, “Wait! Spare him this once.” She pulled her husband aside and whispered, *“Don’t beat him too harshly. If he flees in fear, we’ll only suffer the stench of the Li family’s disgrace. If the neighbors find out, the truth will spread—what face will we have left? Remember: household shame must not be aired.”*

Old Man Liu feigned alarm, though his heart secretly rejoiced. He asked, *"Why do you sigh, Master?"* The fortune-teller replied, *"Who is this young man?"* Old Man Liu said, *"My own son."* The fortune-teller said, *"Forgive my bluntness—I speak only what the calculations reveal, without concealment."* Old Man Liu said, *"A gentleman asks about misfortune, not fortune. Who needs flattery?"* The fortune-teller said, *"This young master’s fate is called 'Tiger Seated in the Hall,' scattering his family’s bones. He should not remain at home. After another year, when his败运 arrives, not a single relative will survive, and his family’s wealth will be reduced to nothing."*

Old Man Liu asked, *"What if he were adopted out?"* The fortune-teller said, *"Adoption would make no difference. His fate is burdened by two layers of the 'Flowery Canopy.' If he were to leave home and become a monk, he would spare his kin harm and might even rise in the future."* These few words sent a chill down Zhangtai’s spine, unaware of the scheme.

When the fortune-telling was done, Old Man Liu paid the fee, and the fortune-teller departed. Without delay, Old Man Liu went to see the vegetable vendor Li San. He embellished the fortune-teller’s words about his son, recounting them in full, and insisted on returning the boy. Seeing Old Man Liu’s earnestness—appearing beyond reconciliation—Li San reluctantly agreed.

Old Man Liu returned home, called Zhangtai aside, and explained the situation. He gave him his usual clothes and belongings, then personally escorted him back to Li San, restoring him like a flawless jade returned. This matter, though seemingly without plan, was executed with precision—clean and leaving no trace.

Now, Old Man Liu’s household was rid of this burden. As for Zhangtai, since his first taste of intimacy with Chunniang, though his outward appearance had suffered, he had not yet reached the true realm of bliss. Yet his heart was deeply attached. Unexpectedly, after returning home for four or five days, he fell gravely ill with lovesickness. The sickness was severe—his form withered, his complexion wan, medicine ineffective, prayers unanswered.

Seeing his son in such a state, Li San went before the gods and vowed: *"If this child’s life is spared, I will offer him to the Buddha’s gate as a monastic disciple."* This was not Li San’s own vow but one prompted by Old Man Liu’s earlier recounting of the fortune-teller’s words.

After two or three months, the illness indeed abated, and Zhangtai narrowly escaped death. Once he had regained his strength, Li San sent him to Pipaji Temple to become a monk, giving him the dharma name Jingkong.

Later, Chunniang married Zhang Yong, and both her parents passed away. The vegetable vendor Li San also died. After leaving home, Zhangtai studied scriptures under his master and lived in peace. When his master entered nirvana, Zhangtai succeeded him as abbot, managing affairs with ease.

Yet he had one flaw: the sight of wine and meat was as vital to him as life itself, and the sight of women made him forget his own life. The temple’s young monks took turns keeping him company, while the alluring courtesans outside the small gate lingered in succession. Truly:

*Within the empty gate, he cultivated the Dao,*
*Yet in the realm of wind and moon, he idled away.*

As for Zhang Yong, he had initially met Jingkong because his wife’s family was acquainted with him, and he often invited the monk to recite scriptures. When they spoke of their childhood, they addressed each other as brother and sister. Jingkong would visit often, sharing tea and idle conversation before leaving with refined decorum.

One day, Zhang Yong was not at home when Jingkong arrived. Chunniang sat with him for a while. This monk was a ravenous ghost in matters of desire, a worm gnawing at the bottom of wine cups. Seeing no one around—and recalling their past intimacy—he boldly began to press close, rubbing against her.

*"Sister,"* he asked, *"do you remember what we did in the back garden?"* Chunniang smiled faintly, lowering her head in silence. Generally, a virtuous woman, when faced with a reckless man, would rebuke him sharply at the slightest impropriety, making it clear she was untouchable. But Chunniang’s smile, though wordless, had already written her consent.

Jingkong embraced her, making countless shameless advances. Chunniang feigned resistance: *"Stop this. If someone comes, it won’t be proper."* Jingkong quickly scanned the surroundings—no one was in sight. Turning back, he knelt on both knees, begging his "sister" for favor.

*"Your brother-in-law has been gone a while,"* Chunniang said. *"He’ll likely return soon. Better come another day."* Before she could finish, Zhang Yong appeared at the door. Chunniang, sharp-eyed and quick, gave Jingkong a push. *"Your brother-in-law is here."*

Jingkong hastily sat down. Zhang Yong entered, exchanged a bow, and sat. After some dull pleasantries, he took his leave.

Zhang Yong went to Yang Laoshi’s home, fetched his casting net, and set off together. As fate would have it, his luck ran ill with Zhang Yong—business was poor, and the fish he caught barely covered their daily meals. His distress need not be told.

Meanwhile, the county magistrate, following an official decree from his superiors, distributed ten thousand *hu* of grain to relieve the people of the county. The proclamation spread through the city. Zhang Yong saw it and returned home to tell his wife, *"The government is aiding the poor. Tomorrow, I must go to the city to claim grain."*

*"You should go,"* Chunniang replied.

Zhang Yong said, "If you keep fighting like this, what if one of you ends up dead? That would be no small matter!" He forced himself between them and urged, "Stop fighting, both of you. Let me mediate."

The two men ceased their brawl and listened as Zhang Yong pronounced his judgment.

Zhang Yong said, "You only want five *sheng* of rice from him—if he gives it to you, will you let the matter rest?"

The man replied, "Exactly. If I get my five *sheng* of rice, I’ll spare him."

Zhang Yong said, "What if I repay the five *sheng* of rice on his behalf? How would that suit you?"

The two men said, "We’re just collecting a cold debt—how could we trouble you, old sir? We won’t take your rice. In this famine year, death is all around us—let’s just fight to the finish!"

They lunged at each other again, but Zhang Yong held them back with all his strength, and they did not strike. After repeated pleas, he finally persuaded them to accept his five *sheng* of rice. The man took it, expressed his gratitude, and left.

After walking half an arrow’s distance, the two men suddenly turned back and asked, "We’re grateful for your kindness, but we never learned your honorable name. We’ve returned especially to ask, so we may repay you in the future."

Zhang Yong said, "This humble one is named Zhang Yong, and I live in Anle Village to the east."

The three exchanged bows and parted ways.

Later, both his parents passed away, and Zhen’er wept for three days and nights until his eyes bled dry, leaving him completely blind. When he came of age, his relatives took turns sheltering him—one household offering a meal, another a place to stay—barely keeping him alive. After two days without a drop of water or a morsel of food, Zhen’er thought, *"This life is surely beyond saving. Zhen’er said, *"Do not mock me. I am one who can eat but cannot work—what use am I to you?"*

The man replied, *"My household consists of only my wife and me. I go out on business, and there is no one at home to tend to the doors and yard—nothing more than that. I need no labor from you."*

Hearing the man’s words as sincere—*"Surely he is not deceiving me"*—Zhen’er bowed his head and knelt, saying, *"If you, Father, would save me, you would be my reborn parents. I would take you as my adoptive father."* The man hurried to lift him up, took his hand, and they returned together.

Now, who was this man who saved him? It was Zhang Feng, the good-hearted soul who did not fear his wife’s scolding and who had urged her to give away the rice.

Along the way, they exchanged commonplace talk about residence, origins, and names. Zhang Feng rejoiced, saying, *"We were of the same family five hundred years ago. There is no need to change your name or surname—just call yourself Zhang Zhen’er."*

Before they knew it, they had reached his doorstep. Chun Niang saw her husband bring home this strange guest and was secretly vexed. She quickly asked about his origins. Zhang Feng told her of his attempt to drown himself in the river. Chun Niang feared any eyesore, especially one who might interfere with Jing Kong’s visits, but seeing that he was blind, she grudgingly allowed him to stay, intending to deal with the matter later.

Zhang Zhen’er bowed to his adoptive mother and settled into his new life, content to pass his remaining days in peace—no more mention of him.

Now, Jing Kong, seeing that Zhang Feng was absent, visited daily, indulging in frivolous amusements without pause. One day, Zhang Zhen’er stood at the door when Jing Kong arrived. Zhen’er heard him and asked, *"Who are you?"* Jing Kong did not answer but rushed inside with a loud noise. Zhen’er shouted, *"Who dares to barge in like that? Could it be a thief?"* He waved his hands about, groping and calling out without stopping.

Jing Kong saw Chun Niang and asked, *"Who is this?"*
She replied, *"He is your own flesh-and-blood nephew."*
Jing Kong said, *"I’ve never seen you pregnant, nor have I seen you give birth—how did you suddenly raise such a grown son?"*
The two laughed.

Chun Niang then told him Zhen’er’s story in detail, and Jing Kong understood at last. When Zhen’er heard his mother and Jing Kong speaking playfully, he realized they were familiar with each other and fell silent.

Chun Niang called Zhen’er inside to meet his uncle, but instead sent him back to sit at the door while the two carried on their usual mischief.

As for Jing Kong’s visits, Chun Niang had kept them secret from Zhen’er, but this time fate had brought them together, leaving her no choice but to reveal the truth. Afterward, whenever Zhen’er heard the sound of his voice, he would call out in greeting.

For over ten days, though Zhen’er’s eyes could not discern forms or colors, his ears grew sharp in recognizing voices and tones, and he began to suspect the truth. One day, he said to Chun Niang, *"Our father is not at home, and it is thanks to my uncle that he comes daily to oversee matters. If he finds no one around, why not move in with us? We could rely on each other."*

Chun Niang said, *"Your words may make sense, but my uncle is a monk—living together would be improper in appearance."*

Zhen’er replied, *"We are blood relatives. What fear is there of others’ gossip?"*
Chun Niang gave no clear answer.

Zhen’er’s words were deliberate, meant to provoke a reaction and test her secrets. Chun Niang, unaware, occasionally let slip careless words that gave her away, and Zhen’er remembered them all.

The next day was Chun Niang’s birthday. Jing Kong brought fish and meat, brewed fine wine, and toasted her. After they ate for a while, he sent Zhen’er to warm the wine in the kitchen, then led her into the bedroom, where they indulged in their licentious pleasures like King Xu of Chu and the enchantress of Mount Yu.

Zhen’er warmed the wine and carried it to the hall, but saw no one seated at the table. Instead, he heard from the inner chamber sounds like those of a leprous toad croaking wildly on the Third Day of the Third Month, or an old man of seventy or eighty suffering from phlegm-fire, wheezing and gasping without end.

Hearing this, Zhen’er was deeply vexed—
*"One with boundless lust, yet fears no death,
One with unwavering loyalty, yet dares not live."*

While Springnian and Jingkong were in tender embrace, suddenly they heard a frantic knocking at the door in their slumber. Springnian said, *"At this hour, my husband surely would not return—why does the sound resemble his?"*

In haste, she roused Jingkong, who hurriedly dressed and went to open the door. There, in the darkness, one figure slipped in, another slipped out—swift hands made quick work of it.

But who would have thought it was Zhang Fei, holding a lantern bright as snow, while Springnian opened the door. Before she could employ her *moving-star-changing-moon* trick or Jingkong could recite his *subduing-dragon-taming-tiger* mantra, they were forced to crouch behind Springnian.

Zhang Fei set down the mirror, then searched for his old shoes—his feet were damp. He found them behind Springnian, but in the shadows saw only a shaven head.

Zhang Fei asked, *"Who is this?"*
Springnian, unable to conceal him, was pushed aside. A closer look revealed Jingkong the Monk, his robe still half-drawn, a novice’s shaven head exposed at his waist.

Zhang Fei, his fury rising from the depths of his heart, his malice welling from the edge of his courage, seized him and shouted, *"You monk! To break into a man’s home at this unholy hour—whether for lechery or theft, I’ll strike you dead on the spot!"*
Springnian pleaded weakly, *"We are siblings—what lechery? What theft?"*
Zhang Fei struck her twice with his palms, knocking her senseless.

Zhang Fei called for his son, but the boy slept on, unaware. In a rage, Zhang Fei dragged the monk to the doorstep, intending to raise the alarm.

Seeing the situation was desperate, Springnian resolved, *"No turning back now—let’s finish this and spare ourselves the shame of others’ mockery."* She and Jingkong loosened their grip, then wrapped Zhang Fei’s head in a quilt, smothering him. They tied the rope that bound the mirror around his throat and, with both their strength, pulled tight.

Alas! A man of noble virtue, who had always aided the weak and rescued the troubled, now lay lifeless—his fate no grander than a *Southern Slope* dream.

The two discussed where to dispose of the body. Jingkong said, *"Let’s bury him in a muddy pit."*
Springnian replied, *"That’s not clean enough. If traces of him are found later, it could bring us grave trouble. Better we carry him to the riverside and toss him to the fish—his bones will vanish, and the deed will be done cleanly."*
Jingkong agreed, *"Most wise, most wise."*

Without delay, he rushed into the room to dress properly, and the two lifted Zhang Fei with all their might, heading toward the riverbank. Soon enough, they reached the water’s edge, and with a splash—he was gone into the *Water Crystal Palace*.

By now, it was the fourth watch of the night. The white dew glistened, the water’s surface rippled, yet lo and behold, a dark, tangled mass floated toward them. It bore Zhang Fei away.

Springnian and Jingkong, seeing this, thought it was a great fish devouring him. Overjoyed, they returned home.

The two conferred, *"The deed is done, and no one knows a thing."*
They feigned calling for the boy, but he still slept.

Jingkong said, *"What if the neighbors question us? How shall we answer?"*
Springnian replied, *"That’s no matter. We’ll say we went fishing with Yang Shengshi and never came back. In a day or two, send the boy to ask after him. Then, we’ll create a ruckus ourselves—plant the story deep in his mind, and the matter will be settled."*
Jingkong agreed, *"Most wise."*

Before she could finish speaking, the rooster crowed at dawn, and the sky brightened. In a hurry, they left the house.

「You speak of the countless fishes in the river—where do they come from to meddle in such trifling matters?
Know this: Zhang Fei is a man of noble virtue who rescues the lost and sends them to the river. Today, he meets with this great misfortune, yet the heavens secretly protect him.
This creature is none other than the **Golden-Armored Divine Man** (*Jīnjiǎ shénrén*), bearing him away.

As it is said:
*"The Void holds its own divine oversight,
The boundless azure sky brooks no deceit."*

Setting aside this matter for now—

Now comes the tale of a certain **Qíqí Prime Minister** (*Zǎixiàng*), whose authority was resplendent and whose life was one of extravagant splendor. At over fifty years of age, he still had no son, only a daughter, **Lady Luànxiāo** (*Niǎoshì*), named **Luanling** (*Luànlíng*), who was twenty-eight in years. She was skilled in calligraphy and literature, and equally adept in needlework and feminine arts. Truly, she possessed the **rapturous beauty of a fish sinking in water, a wild goose alighting** (*Chén yú luò yàn zhī róng*), and the **grace to eclipse the moon, shame the flowers** (*Bì yuè xiū huā zhī mào*).
She spent her days drinking wine among the blossoms, composing poetry beneath the moon.

One day, the spring breeze was gentle and the air stifling, so the young lady put away her embroidery and, accompanied by her maid **Xiangchun** (*Xiāngchūn*), strolled leisurely in the rear garden.
Xiangchun supported the young lady as she walked, her **golden lotus feet** (*Jīnlián*) moving with measured elegance, her **jade ornaments** (*Yùpèi*) chiming softly, until they emerged through the side gate.
Indeed, the garden presented a scene of unparalleled beauty, and they marveled at it greatly.

How did they see it? [How was it beautiful?]」

The garden was a riot of red and green, its spring splendor nearing its ninetieth day.
Jade leaves dripped emerald dew, and blossoms floated their fragrance—
the scene alone could not be captured in three strokes of the brush.

Peach and plum trees, lush and radiant, seemed to have been painted by frost descending to scatter crimson rain,
their petals dusting the verdant moss.

Swallows chattered, orioles sang—
their voices, when heard, were like reciting the *Bright Moon Odes*,
then improvising on the *Kuan-ku* and *Zhui-qi* melodies,
their highs and lows blending into a harmonious chorus.

Pavilions and terraces stood in staggered splendor,
towers and galleries curved in elegant folds.
Willows swayed as if asleep, flowers laughed in the breeze,
waters shimmered with refined grace, mountains wore their deep green.

It rivaled the *Golden Orchard* of Jia Yi,
yet did not fall short of the *Afang Palace*’s elegance.

This garden’s beauty was boundless—
its splendor could not be fully described nor exhaustively depicted.

The young lady, confined in her secluded chambers,
paused upon seeing such a vision,
her heart yearning to wander farther—
to find a place where she might be fully content.

Gazing afar at the distant garden’s charms,
she asked, *“What place is that?”*

Xiangchun replied, *“This is the inner garden; that is the outer garden.”*

The young lady said, *“If the inner garden is so splendid,
then the outer garden must be even more wondrous.
We have long wished to see it—
let us venture out for a glimpse.”*

Xiangchun answered, *“The inner garden is already forbidden by the master,
not allowing the young lady or even the servants to frolic outside—
the outer garden is beyond reach.”*

The young lady declared, *“It does not matter.
Only—do not let the master find out.”*

Xiangchun’s heart also longed to see the garden, though she spoke otherwise—her feet had already walked many steps alongside the young lady.

Before long, they reached the outer garden. The two paused to take it in: though its vistas were broader than the inner garden’s, it was desolate and forlorn. After gazing for some time, the young lady turned to leave.

Xiangchun said, *“Since the young lady wished to come, let us linger awhile longer.”*

For the young lady, a delicate maiden of secluded life, accustomed to the bustle of jade and silk, this vast wilderness—even under the radiant sun, when flowers and willows vied in splendor—felt hollow and empty. A chill sorrow seized her, and she longed to return.

Then, from behind a too-lake stone, a crimson glow emerged. The young lady hastily called Xiangchun to look, but Xiangchun replied, *“There’s nothing there.”*

Gradually, the young lady made out its form and cried, *“That’s clearly a Buddha or deity!”* Her face paled, her feet rooted to the ground, her lips moving soundlessly as she collapsed.

Xiangchun, panicked, dared not abandon her to fetch the mistress, yet could not carry her back. She cradled the young lady as she wept. After struggling, the young lady’s breath faltered.

Xiangchun, overcome, wailed aloud. Just then, an aged gardener hauling water in the garden heard the cries and rushed over. Seeing the young lady unconscious on the ground and Xiangchun sobbing beside her, he hurried to report to the mistress.

Soon, a crowd of maids and servants, along with the mistress herself, gathered. All stood stunned. The mistress called repeatedly, but there was no response. After weeping, she struck Xiangchun severely, and seven or eight men carried her inside, placing her on the bed. They summoned the physician in haste, administered medicine, and prayed to the gods, but her body remained icy. Fortunately, her spirit still flickered like a dying flame, unwilling to depart. Her kin kept vigil day and night, watching helplessly for her return to life.

*(Here, the tale pauses—leaving the young lady’s fate unspoken.)*

Now, as for Chunniang: after that night when she lost her husband, she waited three or five days before visiting Yang Laoshi’s home to inquire after him. Upon entering, she changed her expression and said, *“My master has been gone four or five days—why did you keep him here?”*

Yang Laoshi, struck like thunder from a clear sky, stammered, *“Your master went fishing last night and pulled up a mirror in his net. He took it home and hasn’t returned these days—I was just about to go fetch him.”*

Chunniang scoffed, *“Have you seen him? You two fished together—if he’s not here, I’ll demand answers from you.”*

Yang Laoshi protested, *“A man six feet tall—how could he hide?”*

Chunniang pressed, *“You mentioned a mirror—did you kill him for it?”*

Seeing her hostile demeanor, Yang Laoshi, furious and wronged, pounded his chest in despair. Chunniang then collapsed onto a stool, weeping. His daughter tried to console her, urging her to stay for tea, but Chunniang refused and left abruptly.

Yang Laoshi, unsettled by her words, frantically sent men to search, but found no trace.

Chunniang’s scheme was cunning: if neighbors questioned him, she could frame Yang Laoshi. If no one spoke of it, she could let the matter drop. From then on, she lived freely with Jingkong, reveling in their daily companionship—whether in spring or winter, night or day—her heart at ease.

Yet her indulgence proved her undoing. After ten days of illness, she finally rose to dress, using the mirror her husband had brought back to arrange her hair. The mirror was extraordinary: its surface clear as crystal, revealing the coward’s heart; its glow ethereal, summoning celestial lovers.

At first, Chunniang admired her reflection, her spirits lifting as she applied powder and adorned her hair. But soon, a dark radiance obscured her face. Before her stretched strange mountains and rivers, twisted pines and gnarled cypresses. Nestled in the valley stood grand pavilions and halls, while tigers, leopards, and wolves prowled menacingly below.

Chunniang, transfixed, forgot her hair. Her gaze locked on the mirror, tracing every detail. Then, from within the halls emerged a figure—tall and imposing, his beard broad and unkempt, his hair tied in a topknot, his chest bare. He strode forward, and Chunniang, both startled and delighted, murmured, *“This old man—I’ve never seen him before. Let me study him closely.”*

The two seized his hand and dragged him along. Only then did they realize his entire body was soaked with water, so they hastily each stripped off a garment from their own backs and exchanged them with him.

Zhang Fei said, *"If I go to the mountains, what if your lord does not welcome me? Where shall I find refuge?"*

Bu De replied, *"No need to worry. Our lord is a man of righteousness and generosity, lacking only in learning. If he gains a friend like you, he will surely yield this position to you."*

Shi En added, *"Not only will he yield it to you, but he will also avenge your wrongs for you!"*

At the words *"avenge your wrongs"*, Zhang Fei’s joy knew no bounds, and he followed the two up the mountain without hesitation.

---

**Not to be digressed.**

Now, let us speak of Miss Luan Liang, who had fainted. Her parents stood vigil by her bedside. On the following day, she suddenly awoke with a start, calling out, *"Zhang Fei! Zhang Fei! Bring me the Magic Moon Mirror!"*

Her parents called to her repeatedly, and though she barely drew breath, they forced warm broth into her mouth. Soon, her limbs grew warm, and she moved again, calling out for her mother.

Her parents were overjoyed, raising their fists and bowing in reverence to heaven and earth. They brought her food, and within three or five days, she had fully recovered. She recounted her wandering soul’s ordeal to her parents.

The Prime Minister Kui Kui immediately dispatched orders across the land, posting proclamations throughout the realm: *"To whoever presents the Magic Moon Mirror, my daughter shall be given in marriage."*

He also sent several capable officials in disguise to secretly investigate the matter. This was no small affair, and within months, the news had spread far and wide.

---

As for Jing Kong, upon hearing these words, he personally went to the city to examine the proclamation. His thoughts churned: *"My younger sister has a mirror. If someone emerges from it, it must surely be the Magic Moon Mirror. If I obtain this mirror, I can present it to Prime Minister Kui Kui and win his daughter—like a flower in full bloom—as my wife. That would be far superior to this shaven-headed nun who beats monks!"*

Thus, he returned home, not telling anyone of his plan, and resolved to trick her into giving it to him before deciding what to do next. As he walked, his mind was filled with schemes, and soon he reached the doorstep, entering to see Chun Niang.

But Chun Niang had already learned the reason for his return and had pondered it thoroughly. Jing Kong had not yet spoken when she said, *"Brother, I have a windfall fortune for you."*

Jing Kong asked, *"What windfall? Share some with your brother."*

Chun Niang replied, *"Of course, there will be some for you."* Then she spoke of the mirror: *"If you obtain ten thousand pieces of gold, I will sell it to you."*

Jing Kong struck the ground with a wooden stick, stunned for a moment, before saying, *"Who has that much silver to sell? Even if I had ten or twenty taels, it would be enough."*

He spoke idly for a while.

---

After three or four days, Jing Kong thought, *"If I want to trick her into giving me the mirror, it is utterly impossible. The common saying holds true: a thousand requests are not as good as a single theft."*

When he saw Chun Niang cooking in the kitchen, he slipped into the room, rummaging through the chests and boxes—no trace of the mirror could be found. Then he realized Chun Niang knew its value and had hidden it in some secret recess, unknown to all.

Jing Kong searched for a long while without success, so he lay down on the bed and burrowed beneath it. But Chun Niang came upon him, just as the monk was crawling under the bed like a dog, which filled her with dread.

Chun Niang quietly seized a door bolt and struck him forcefully across the waist. The monk writhed in agony, quickly retreating from beneath the bed, unable even to stand straight. He collapsed to the ground, cursing, *"Thieving harlot! Why such a cruel blow!"*

Seeing him in such distress, Chun Niang raised the door bolt again to strike him down.

Jing Kong, desperate, lunged back beneath the bed to avoid her. After two watches, the pain subsided.

Chun Niang, knowing his intent to steal the mirror, asked, *"What are you doing crawling under my bed?"*

Jing Kong replied, *"If you allow me to crawl on your bed, why not allow me beneath it?"*

Chun Niang said, *"Now, not even the bed is permitted to you."*

Jing Kong, embarrassed, forced a grin. *"But I must crawl a little."*

He grabbed her hand and pulled her onto the bed, intending to make amends with her through carnal union.

Chun Niang turned away in disgust and violently shook him off.

Jing Kong, seeing no progress in his words, flew into a rage and said, *"You dare treat me with the same tactics you used for Zhang Fei! You will not get away with it!"*

Upon hearing this, Chun Niang grew furious and declared, *"You black-hearted bald beast! You have defiled me with your touch, and you took my husband’s life. Now you have allied with this bald rascal—how could there ever be a happy ending for us? You had better leave at once!"*

Zhen’er pressed for details about his father’s death, and Jingkong recounted them all.

Seeing his unwavering filial devotion, the three men, though they tested him with their words, found no way to sway him. They then said, *“Your filial heart is indeed sincere, but your eyesight is unclear, making it difficult for you to act. We have eye medicine here—let us apply it and open your eyes.”*

Zhen’er rejoiced, *“If this is so, I shall see the light of day!”*

The three men applied the medicine to his eyes, and they opened. Zhen’er looked closely and saw that they were three **Dao/Way** masters. He quickly bowed his head to the ground in reverence, knocking his forehead against the earth seven or eight times.

When he rose, the three had vanished. Zhen’er was both astonished and overjoyed, thinking, *“It must be the Three Officials of Heaven, moved by my filial piety, who have come to rescue me.”*

He then discarded his crutch and walked freely, feeling unbounded joy. *(No further mention of this.)*

Meanwhile, Yang Laoshi suffered these hardships in prison, unable to see his loved ones. His household had only a fourteen- or fifteen-year-old daughter, delicate and tender, left alone at home. Fortunately, the neighborly Madam Wang came to keep her company.

Yang Laoshi spent his days in prison without thought of returning home. Unexpectedly, Zhang Zhen’er’s eyesight became clear, and his begging business prospered. He first delivered the earnings to the prison, waiting for Yang Laoshi to eat before he himself partook, doing this daily without fail. If there was any extra silver or money, he used it to buy firewood and rice for his father’s daughter.

Truly, one man sustained two lives. *(No further mention of this.)*

Now the bandits returned to the mountain with the mirror, reporting to the Great King. They then went to see Zhang Feng, explaining the matter. Zhang Feng took the mirror and placed it in his room, then **rested there for the night**.

He saw many immortals entering in procession, gazing at the mirror in bewilderment, unable to fathom it. After pondering through the night, the next day he told the Great King of Bird Mountain, who rejoiced, saying:

*"Based on your words, this must surely be a treasure. Now the Prime Minister Qíqí has dispatched men to sketch likenesses and search the land—whoever presents the Magic Mirror of the Immortals shall be granted the princess in marriage. Why not present this mirror and seek fortune and honor? If you remain here in the mountains forever, there will be no end to it. Though I speak plainly, it is only for your own good."*

Zhang Feng reflected in silence. The visions he had seen in the Hall of the Moon Lord matched these events, so he agreed. The two decided their plan, and the next day sent two bandits to carry the mirror, packing supplies. The Great King of Bird Mountain gave fifty taels as parting gifts, prepared a farewell feast, and personally escorted them to the ten-li pavilion. They clasped hands—*(text ends here)*.
